Chapter 5 - BOATS, DOCKS AND WATERWAYS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Public bathhouses, Ch. 7, Art. VIII; depositing refuse in waterways, § 11-5; parks and recreation, Ch. 16; boating in bathing areas prohibited, § 16-52; regulation of bathing in public parks, § 16-53; regulation of fishing in public parks, § 16-55; streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Prohibited areas for operation of power vessels. 
(a)  No person shall operate under power, any vessel, wholly or partly propelled by power within two hundred (200) feet of the New London shore where any public or private bathing beach or area is located, within two hundred (200) feet of any raft or float used for bathing purposes, or between any such raft or float and the shore except that within such areas operation at dead slow speed to a mooring and through the entrance to Alewife Cove shall be permitted. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 6-17-63, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 7-1-63) 
Sec. 5-2. - Bathing in public place. 
    No person shall bathe in any public place without suitable clothing. 
(Ord. of 8-27-23, § 4; Ord. of 3-5-45, § 19) 
Secs. 5-3-5-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HARBOR IMPROVEMENT 

Sec. 5-15. - Agency created; membership, organization. 
    There is hereby created in the city a harbor improvement agency consisting of five (5) members who are electors of the city. The members of said agency shall be appointed by the council and vacancies shall be filled by the council for the unexpired portion of the term of any member whose place shall have become vacant. The members of the agency first chosen shall be appointed for terms of one to five (5) years, respectively, and thereafter the term of office of each member shall be five (5) years. The members of said agency shall serve without compensation. Said agency shall determine its own rules of procedure. The members shall choose one of its members as chairman and one of its members as secretary. 
(Ord. of 5-6-68, § 1) 
Sec. 5-16. - Designation, purposes of agency. 
    Said agency shall be known as The New London Harbor Improvement Agency, and upon its designation by the chief executive officer, is hereby approved for the purpose of carrying out harbor improvement projects, including the planning, development, improvement, construction and installation of berthing areas, channels to berthing areas, sea walls, piers, docks, navigation aids, bridges and other related facilities and structures, pursuant to a Harbor Improvement Plan, in accordance with the provisions of Sections 14 and 15 of Public Act No. 522, entitled "An Act Concerning Community Development", 1967 Session, General Assembly. 
(Ord. of 5-6-68, § 2; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 5-17. - Duty to prepare harbor improvement plan; approval of plan. 
    The New London Harbor Improvement Agency may prepare or cause to be prepared a harbor improvement plan, and may approve such plan after (1) obtaining the approval of the planning board of the city and (2) holding a public hearing thereon, notice of which shall be published at least twice in a newspaper of general circulation in the City of New London, the first publication of notice to be not less than two (2) weeks before the date of the public hearing. 
(Ord. of 5-6-68, § 3) 
Sec. 5-18. - Contents of harbor improvement plan. 
    Such harbor improvement plan shall include: 
(a)  A description of the harbor improvement area and the condition, type and use of the structures therein; 
(b)  The location and extent of the proposed land uses and harbor uses in such area; 
(c)  The location and extent of streets and public utilities, facilities and works within the area; 
(d)  Schedules showing the number of families and businesses to be displaced by the proposed improvement, the method of relocating such families and businesses and the availability of sufficient suitable living accommodations at prices and rentals within the financial means of such families and located within a reasonable distance of the area from which they are displaced; 
(e)  Present and proposed zoning regulations in the harbor improvement area; 
(f)  A description of all land to be acquired and buildings and improvements to be demolished and removed or rehabilitated; 
(g)  A description of all improvements to be constructed, installed, or made; 
(h)  The plan's relationship to definite local objectives; 
(i)  Financial aspects of the project; and 
(j)  A ratio of the costs of the project to the benefits to be derived therefrom. 
(Ord. of 5-6-68, § 4) 
Sec. 5-19. - Submission of harbor improvement plan to state; approval by city council. 
    After approval of the harbor improvement plan by the harbor improvement agency, the plan shall be submitted to the State of Connecticut Water Resources Commission, and, if approved by said commission, may be adopted by the council of the city. 
(Ord. of 5-6-68, § 5) 
Sec. 5-20. - Modification of harbor improvement plan. 
    The harbor improvement plan may be modified at any time by the harbor improvement agency, provided such modification is consented to in writing by each purchaser or lessee of land in the harbor improvement project affected by such modification, and such modification does not substantially change the plan; otherwise, any modification to such plan shall be approved in the same manner as the plan. 
(Ord. of 5-6-68, § 6) 
Sec. 5-21. - Authority to exercise redevelopment, urban renewal powers. 
    The city and its harbor improvement agency may exercise, for the purposes of undertaking a harbor improvement project, all of the powers and authority granted to the city and to the redevelopment agency of the city for the purposes of a redevelopment or urban renewal project pursuant to Chapter 130 of the General Statutes. 
(Ord. of 5-6-68, § 7) 
Secs. 5-22-5-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - NEW LONDON PORT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 5-36. - Purpose and intent of chapter. 
    In accordance with Chapter 105, Sec. 7-329a to 7-329f of the Connecticut General Statutes, the city establishes the New London Port Authority within its confines, to be created and operated according to procedures set forth in Chapter 105, Sec. 7-329a to 7- 329f, Connecticut General Statutes. The purpose of the authority shall be: to foster and stimulate the economic development of New London's waterfront, to develop and promote port facilities within the district, create additional jobs, increase the city's tax base, provide for a more attractive waterfront and to promote the recreation and tourism based facilities within the district. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-36A. - New London Port Authority as harbor management commission. 
(a)  The city hereby appoints the New London Port Authority as a harbor management commission. Said harbor management commission shall have all those powers granted to it pursuant to General Statutes Chapter 444a, as that chapter may be amended from time to time. 
(b)  The area within the territorial limits of the city and below the mean high water that shall be within the jurisdiction of the harbor management commission shall be all that property identified on Appendix A attached hereto*, including the coastline between the City's municipal borders and extending to the centerline of the Thames River. 
(Ord. No. 11/1/10-8, § 1, 11-1-10) 
Editor's note- *Appendix A referenced in subsection (b) is available from the city clerk. 
Sec. 5-37. - Definitions. 
    In the interpretation of this chapter the following words and terms shall be taken to include the following meanings when context shall require or permit: 
    "Authority" means the body politic and corporate created by the ordinance codified in this chapter know as the New London Port Authority. 
    "Board" means the board of commissioners, consisting of five (5) voting members appointed by the Chief Executive Officer and ex-officio member. 
    "City" means the City of New London. 
    "City officials" means the chief executive officer, any member of the city council, the director of development and planning, and the harbor master for the city. 
    "Commissioner" means any single member of the board of commissioners. 
    "Connecticut General Statutes" means the revision of 1958, as amended. 
    "District" means the Port District of the City of New London. 
    "Ex officio" means nonvoting member. 
    "Federal agency" means the United States of America, and any department of, or corporation, agency or instrumentality thereof, heretofore, or hereafter created, designated or established by the United States of America. 
    "Port facilities" means wharves, docks, piers, air or bus terminals, railroad tracks or warehouses, elevators, freight handling of freights, passengers and vehicles, and the establishment of operation of a port and any other works, properties, buildings, structures or other facilities necessary or desirable in connection with the development and operation of port facilities. 
    "State agency" means the State of Connecticut, and any department of, or corporation, agency or instrumentality thereof or hereafter created, designated or established by the State of Connecticut. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 5-38. - Board of commissioners. 
(a)  The board of commissioners of the New London Port Authority shall consist of five (5) voting members. The voting members shall include the chief executive officer, and the director of economic development and three (3) members appointed by the chief executive officer. The commissioners shall serve without compensation, except for reasonable and necessary expenses. One member of the board first chosen shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. One member of the board first chosen shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. One member of the board first chosen shall be appointed for a term of one year. 
(b)  City officials who are members of the board of commissioners shall retain this responsibility through their tenure as city officials. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-39. - Board officers, committees and voting procedures. 
    The board shall elect one of their number chairman, and one vice-chairman. The secretary and treasurer do not necessarily have to be a commissioner. The board shall meet upon the call of the chairman and a majority of its members shall constitute a quorum. Any action of the board must have a least three (3) votes in favor or against in order to be considered valid. The chairman shall appoint committee chairman, committee members do not necessarily have to be commissioners, but must be approved by the chairman of the board. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-40. - Power and duties of the authority. 
    The powers and duties of the authority are those set forth in Connecticut General Statutes Chapter 105, Sec. 7-329c. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-41. - District properties. 
    The properties included within the district shall be bounded and described as set forth in schedule A and the map attached hereto and found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-42. - Regulations by the authority. 
    The authority may make and enforce any reasonable regulations which it may determine to be necessary relating to the construction, equipment repair, maintenance, use and rental of any dock, wharf, slip, bus or air terminal, rail tracks or terminal or warehouse owned or leased by any individual or corporation within the district. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-43. - Investigations. 
    The authority may make any investigation which it may deem necessary to enable it to effectively carry out the provisions of Connecticut General Statutes Chapter 105, Sec. 7-329a to 7-329f, inclusive. The authority may enter upon any lands as in its judgment may be necessary for the purpose of making surveys and examinations to accomplish any purpose authorized by said section. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-44. - Acquisition of property. 
    The authority may lease or acquire title to real or personal property and may condemn real property located within the district which it deems necessary for the development of port facilities in the district, subject to the provisions of Connecticut General Statute, Sec. 48-12. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-45. - Bylaws, rules, and regulations. 
    The authority shall have the power to adopt, alter or repeal its own bylaws, rules and regulations governing the manner in which its business may be transacted, in which the power granted to it may be enjoyed, and may provide for the appointment of such committees, and the function thereof, as the authority may deem necessary or expedient in facilitating its business. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-46. - Financial restrictions. 
    No indebtedness of any kind incurred or created by the authority shall constitute an indebtedness of the city, or any political subdivision thereof, and no such indebtedness shall involve or be secured by the full faith, credit or taxing of the city, or any political subdivision thereof. 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Sec. 5-47. - Reporting requirement. 
    The authority shall issue a report to the city council within six (6) months at which time the authority shall request the transfer of city asset(s) deemed necessary for the purposes of development port facilities and to recommend the method of payment for said asset(s). 
(Ord. No. 12-16-96-11) 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURAL APPURTENANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 11; hotels, lodging and rooming houses and convalescent homes, Ch. 12; housing and commercial structure codes, Ch. 13; streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18; moving of buildings, § 18-12 et seq.; water and sewers, Ch. 21; subdivision regulations, App. A; zoning, App. B. 
State Law reference- Appointment of building board of appeals, § 19-402, Gen. Stats.; examination and licensing of electricians, plumbers, and heating, piping and cooling contractors and journeyman, § 20-330 et seq.; Gen. Stats. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Violations of state building code. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate a provision of the state building code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or shall erect, construct, alter or repair a building or structure in violation of any approved plan or directive of the building official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of the code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding one year, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any work in or about the building after having been served with a stop order, except such work as he is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe conditions, shall be liable to a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 3-6-72) 
Sec. 6-2. - Department of building inspection created; appointment of building official. 
    There shall be in and for the city a department of building inspection which shall be under the charge of the building official. He shall be appointed by the chief executive officer in accordance with and under the provisions of section 40 of the Charter of the city and shall not be removed from office except in accordance with the provisions of section 46 of the Charter of the city. The building official shall possess the qualifications required under the General Statutes. 
(Ord. of 2-7-72, § 1) 
Sec. 6-3. - Duties of building official. 
    The building official shall enforce all of the provisions of the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code and all further rules and regulations adopted and promulgated thereunder relative to the mode or manner of construction and the materials used in the erection, addition of, alterations, repair, removal, demolition, installation of service equipment and the location, use, occupancy and maintenance of all buildings and structures except as may otherwise be specifically provided for by statutory requirements. 
(Ord. of 2-7-72, § 2) 
Cross reference- Removal of abandoned, inoperable or unregistered motor vehicles by building official, § 20-31. 
Sec. 6-4. - Responsibilities of building official. 
    The building official shall be responsible for inspection of sidewalk hatchways, signs, rooming houses, hotels and convalescent hospitals for conformance with appropriate codes and issue licenses for same; the administration of the housing code ordinance, the building zone ordinance; and the coastal area management and flood insurance programs. 
(Ord. of 2-7-72, § 3; Ord. of 4-28-86, § 1) 
Cross reference- Removal of abandoned, inoperable or unregistered motor vehicles by building official, § 20-31. 
Sec. 6-5. - Demolition code; purpose, adoption. 
(a)  Purpose: The section codified in this article is adopted for the purpose of regulating, pursuant to state statutes, the demolition of buildings and structures while providing adequate time and opportunity for public review of demolition permit applications for potentially significant buildings. 
(b)  Adoption and administration: The Connecticut State Demolition Code prepared pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 541 of the General Statutes of Connecticut Section 29-401 through 29-415 is hereby adopted and the officer to administer said code shall be the building official of the city. Pursuant to the provisions of Section 29-406(b) of the Connecticut General Statutes, this ordinance establishes a waiting period of not more than one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of receipt of a completed demolition permit application before granting any permit for the demolition of buildings or parts thereof. 
(Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1; Ord. No. 09-15-03-1(Rev.)) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1, adopted September 15, 2003, repealed and reenacted § 6-5 to read as herein set out. Formerly, § 6-5 pertained to the demolition code; adoption, enforcement, and derived from an ordinance of January 21, 1963, § 1. 
Sec. 6-6. - Duty of building official to enforce demolition code. 
    Pursuant to Section 29-401 of the Connecticut General Statutes, the building official of the city is hereby appointed to administer and enforce Sections 29-401 to 29-415, inclusive, of the state demolition code. 
    The building official is authorized to institute any and all actions and proceedings, in law or in equity, as they may deem necessary and appropriate to obtain compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. of 9-19-66, § 1) 
Sec. 6-6.1. - Permit fees for new construction, alteration, removal and demolition. 
(a)  New Construction and Alteration Generally; Signs: Pursuant to Sections 112.1 and 112.2 of the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code, a fee schedule is hereby established to read as follows: 
(1)  Building, sign, billboard, marquee, gas piping, heating, air conditioning, and electrical inspection fees: 
For buildings or structures where the actual cost of the work is to be done under the building code is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or less, the fee shall be ..... $18.16 
For buildings or structures where the actual cost of the work to be done under the building code is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more the fee shall be, for each one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or fraction thereafter ..... 18.16 
(b)  Demolition: As prescribed in Section 114.2 of the State of Connecticut Basic Building Code, the following fee schedule is hereby established: 
(1)  Demolition permit fee, per thousand of demolition cost: $18.16 
(2)  The payment of the demolition fee shall not relieve the applicant or holder of the permit from the payment of other fees that are prescribed by law or ordinance for water connections, electrical permits or other permits or inspections, both within and outside of the jurisdiction of the building department. 
(Ord. of 5-7-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-18-88, § 1; Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1; Ord. No. 09-15-03-1(Rev.)) 
Sec. 6-6.2. - Definitions, permit required; requirements. 
(a)  Definitions. The following terms shall have the meanings set forth in this section. In the event of any conflict between these definitions and the definitions promulgated under state regulations for the state demolition code the definitions of the state regulations shall control. 
(1)  "Application" means an application for a permit for the demolition of a building, which application contains the information required by this article. 
(2)  "Building" means any structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any occupancy. 
(3)  "Building official" means the person occupying the office of the building official or otherwise authorized to issue demolition permits. 
(4)  "Commission" means the City Historic District Commission/Design Review Board or HDC/DRB. 
(5)  "Demolition" means the act of pulling down, destroying, removing or razing a building or commencing the work of total or partial substantial destruction with the intent of completing the same. "Permit" means a permit issued by the building official for demolition of a building pursuant to an application. 
(6)  "Permit" means a document issued by the building official authorizing the applicant to undertake the activity proposed by this ordinance. 
(b)  Permit required. No person shall demolish any building, structure, or part thereof which is two-hundred and fifty (250) total square feet in size or larger without first applying for and obtaining a demolition permit from the building official. 
(c)  Application procedures and requirements. 
(1)  Application. All applicants shall file a demolition permit application on a form provided by the city with the office of the building official. An application for demolition of a building shall be made only by the person, partnership, corporation or realty trust which is the owner thereof at the time of such application or by an agent for the owner with the owners' consent. The applicant shall provide the building official with at least thirteen (13) copies of the application and supporting documentation including but not limited to: the HDC/DRB Referral Form, a site plan or sketch, the age of the structure, photographs of the building or structure clearly indicating what is to be demolished, and the reason(s) why the building is being demolished. 
(2)  Sign posting. The applicant shall post signage on the property to be affected by the proposed demolition in a conspicuous place visible from the public street at least fifteen days prior to the scheduled HDC/DRB meeting. This signage shall read. "Application for a permit to demolish this building pending; for information contact the building official of the City of New London". Moreover, said signage shall give the date and place of the HDC/DRB's public review of the building. This signage shall be at least two (2) feet by three (3) feet in size and will be made available to the applicant by the building official on request and upon appropriate reassurances made of its return. Said signage shall remain posted on the property until the demolition permit is granted. A report from the building official attesting to whether the above described signage was erected and maintained as required shall be made part of the file of the demolition application. Failure of the applicant to properly post and maintain the signage shall be grounds for automatic delay of the processing of the pending demolition permit application, with consideration being given to cases where weather conditions or acts of vandalism have destroyed a properly posted sign. 
(3)  Notice to neighbors. Each demolition permit application shall include a list, prepared by the applicant, of the names and addresses of the owners of all land included within the application and of all properties one hundred fifty (150) feet or less distance therefrom, all as shown on the most recent records on file in the city's tax assessor's office (or the actual owners of record if otherwise known to the applicant). The applicant shall mail notification of said pending application on a form provided by the city to at least one owner of each such property, by certified mail, return receipt requested within five (5) days of filing the application. A copy of all return certified mail receipts shall be submitted to the building official, before the HDC/DRB meeting. Notice to a condominium association alone shall be deemed notice of all owners therein. Failure to comply with any of the procedures required herein shall be deemed a valid basis to declare the application incomplete and require a refiling and proper notification. 
(4)  Notifications. Within five (5) days of receipt of the demolition application, the building official will deliver thirteen (13) copies of the demolition permit application, including the supporting documentation, to the HDC/DRB. No demolition permit shall be issued during this time. 
Likewise, within five days of the receipt of the demolition application, the building official will notify the members of the city council and by first-class mail New London Landmarks, Inc. and the New London County Historical Society. If the property lies within the downtown historic district, New London Main Street and the city center district will be notified within the same manner and time as noted above. If another organization wishes to be notified, such organization will register with the building department and indicate its desire to be notified of demolition permit applications. 
(5)  Legal notice. Within five (5) days of the receipt of the demolition permit application the building official shall publish a legal notice one time in a newspaper having substantial circulation in the city of the pending demolition permit application, giving the date and place of the HDC/DRB meeting at which the intended demolition will be reviewed. 
(6)  Review by the historic district commission. The HDC/DRB shall review the demolition application at its next regularly scheduled monthly meeting, provided the application is filed at least fifteen (15) days before the meeting. Otherwise the demolition permit application will be reviewed at the HDC/DRB's following regularly scheduled meeting. The HDC/DRB may ask the applicant to attend the meeting in order to ask the applicant questions, and members of the public may also attend the meeting and voice their opinions and concerns about the proposed demolition and to consider alternatives. 
(7)  The HDC/DRB finding. The purpose of the HDC/DRB's review of the application is to determine whether or not the subject building or structure has historic or cultural value based on the following criteria: 
1)  Historic shall include but not be limited to architectural importance (in terms of period, style, method of building construction or association with a famous architect or builder) whether by itself or in the context of a group of buildings or structures. 
2)  Cultural shall include, but not be limited to, association with one or more historic persons or events or with the cultural and social/political history of the city. 
(8)  HDC/DRB Report. Within five (5) business days after the HDC/DRB meeting, the HDC/DRB will provide written notification of its finding to the building official and to the applicant of the permit application: 
1)  If the HDC/DRB finds that the building or structure has historic or cultural value, the building official shall delay issuance of the demolition permit for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of receipt of the completed application. This will provide the HDC/DRB or other interested parties with an opportunity to seek possible alternatives to the demolition. 
2)  If the HDC/DRB finds that the building does not have historic or cultural value, the building official may issue the demolition permit without a further waiting period. 
(9)  Failure to report. If the HDC/DRB does not act on the application at the prescribed meeting or if it does not provide written notification of its findings to the building official or the applicant within five (5) business days of its meeting, the building official may assume that there are no objections to the demolition and may proceed with the issuance of the demolition permit without further delay. 
(Ord. of 2-21-84, § 1; Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1; Ord. No. 09-15-03-1(Rev.)) 
Sec. 6-6.3. - Building official determination; condition of the structure. 
    In cases where the building official determines that the condition of the structure is such that a threat to the public health, safety and welfare exists, the provisions of this ordinance concerning legal notices, the posting of signage, the notification of property owners and application requirements shall not apply. However, the building official will make a reasonable attempt to inform the chairperson of the HDC/DRB of the intention to issue a demolition permit as far in advance of the issuance of such permit as is practicable. 
(Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1) 
Sec. 6-6.4. - Issuance of demolition permit. 
(a)  No person shall be eligible to receive a demolition permit unless the building official has been furnished with: 
(1)  A certificate from a licensed exterminator which certifies the premises to be demolished are free from rodent and insect infestation; and 
(2)  Written evidence of the contractor's certificate of insurance and liability coverage required by C.G.S. 29-406(a); and 
(3)  A copy of the current valid certificate of registration issued under the provisions of Connecticut General Statutes 29-402; and 
(4)  If applicable, a copy of the certificate of asbestos inspection. 
(5)  A certificate of notice from each of the following utilities stating that the utility connections and service has been severed, removed, sealed and/or plugged in a safe manner: 
a)  Connecticut Light and Power, 
b)  Yankee Gas, 
c)  Local telephone service provider, 
d)  City Sewer, 
e)  City Water, 
f)  City public works department storm water drainage, 
g)  Local cable provider. 
(b)  No person shall remove or demolish any building or structure or part thereof without providing adequate safety measures for all workmen and suitable protections for the public in compliance with C.G.S. 29-408 through 29-413. To this end, the building official may impose such terms and conditions as he may determine reasonable and proper to insure the safety to the public safety and welfare. 
(c)  Any site where a building has been demolished or removed shall be cleaned of all debris, building materials, concrete and other items as determined by the building official or his representative upon inspection so as to insure that the lot remains free from all unsafe or hazardous conditions. The site shall be graded and if necessary fill shall be brought in to provide for natural drainage from the site. In no case shall grade next to sidewalks or on the site present a hazard to the public or anyone who may be on the site. 
(d)  The building official is authorized to deny any demolition permit application if an applicant fails to submit any of the required information during the application review period. 
(Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1; Ord. No. 09-15-03-1(Rev.)) 
Sec. 6-6.5. - Duration of permit. 
    Demolition permits issued by the building official shall be valid for a period of not more than six (6) months following the date of issuance of the permit. Any applicant may request in writing and be issued an additional six (6) month period in which to complete the demolition approved under the original permit so long as the total timeframe does not exceed one (1) year. If the demolition approved under the permit is not completed within any of the above referenced timeframes, the permit shall be considered void and a new permit application and permit approval will be required prior to the work being undertaken. 
(Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1) 
Sec. 6-6.6. - Exemption. 
    The provisions of this ordinance shall not apply to buildings containing less than two hundred and fifty (250) square feet of gross floor area as documented in the assessor's records or as certified to the building official by a licensed engineer or surveyor. 
(Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1) 
Sec. 6-6.7. - Appeals. 
    Per the provisions of C.G.S. Section 29-405, any person aggrieved by any order or decision of the building official may, within ten (10) days of such order or decision, appeal therefrom to the superior court for the judicial district of New London at New London, and such appeal shall be a privileged matter to be heard by the court as soon after the return day as is practicable. 
(Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1) 
Sec. 6.6.8. - Inspection. 
    The person, individual or corporation to whom a demolition or relocation permit is issued will, upon completion of all work on the site cause the site to be inspected by the building official or his representative. The inspector will note on the inspection report that the site is suitable in accordance with this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 09-15-03-1, § 1) 
Sec. 6-7. - Codes review committee-Established, membership, purposes. 
(a)  There is hereby established in the city a committee to be known as the "Codes Review Committee" to consist of the building official, director of health, chief of the fire department, city engineer and director of public works, director of law, the planning consultant of the city, an architect, an engineer, a member of the plumbing, heating and electrical trades respectively, and a general contractor. 
(b)  The architect, the engineer, the members of the plumbing, heating and electrical trades and the general contractor shall be electors of the city and shall be appointed by the council of the city for terms of three (3) years. 
(c)  The members of the committee shall serve without compensation and the committee shall choose from its members a chairman and a secretary. 
(Ord. of 3-21-66, § 1) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 6-8. - Same-Duties. 
    The codes review committee shall continually review the city's housing code, building, plumbing, heating and electrical codes and recommend to the council from time to time such revisions and amendments thereto as the committee deems advisable for the improvement of said codes. 
(Ord. of 3-21-66, § 2) 
Sec. 6-9. - Fire limits designated. 
    For the purpose of control of use and construction of buildings, those areas of the city included within the boundaries of the following zoning district of the city: 
(C-2)  Central Business 
    as established under an ordinance amending the building zone ordinance for the city passed December 1, 1969, and amendments thereto which may be adopted from time to time, are hereby designated "Fire District No. 1", and all areas of the city not included within the fire limits are designated "outside fire limits". 
(Ord. of 2-17-76, § 1) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 6-10. - Posting and display of numbers on buildings required. 
(a)  The purpose of this section shall be to promote public safety and convenience, by providing a rational street numbering system whereby addresses may be identified with the ease and speed which is essential to the quick response of emergency services, including police, fire fighting and medical care. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the public works department to assign a number to every residential, commercial, industrial or other structure located on premises abutting a public street or highway within the City of New London, except those structures such as barns, garages or out-buildings which are located on the same premises as the numbered structure. 
(c)  Every owner, agent, or lessee or occupant shall, within one hundred twenty (120) days of the effective date of this section, ascertain from the public works department, the number assigned to each structure owned, possessed or controlled by him/her and shall place said number upon each structure in the manner herein provided. 
(d)  The numerals used to indicate the street identification number of buildings shall be located on the exterior front of the building or on a sign, post, mailbox, or other device located between the building and street. 
(e)  Such numerals shall be of a color contrasting to the background material which they are affixed. Such numerals shall be a minimum of four (4) inches high with a minimum one-half (1/2) inch stroke. The location and size of such numerals shall be sufficient to assure their visibility from the street. 
(f)  For buildings containing more than three (3) dwelling units which have entrances from interior passageways, numerals shall be affixed within five (5) feet of every door by which the building may be entered. 
(g)  The compliance officer for enforcement of this section shall be the building official and/or fire marshal. 
(h)  Whoever shall violate any of the provisions of the foregoing subsections, or refuses or neglects to comply with the same, shall be deemed guilty of an infraction and shall be fined ten dollars ($10.00) for each offense, and each and every ten-day period of refusal or neglect to comply with the provisions of this section shall be deemed a separate offense. Penalty shall not, however, exceed the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for any one building. 
(Ord. of 8-6-84, § 1; Res. No. 04212008) 
Sec. 6-11. - Rapid entry systems required. 
    A rapid entry system shall be installed on all structures and complexes that meet the requirements of this section. The rapid entry system shall be suitable for the structure or complex for which it is used and meet the requirements of the city fire department regarding size and integrity. The rapid entry system shall be installed on all new buildings or complexes for which a building permit is issued after the date of the ordinance from which this section derives and on all existing structures or complexes that are equipped with a fire alarm system or a fire suppression system weather or not any such systems are required by the Connecticut Fire Safety Code or the Connecticut Building Code. 
    Exception: If approved by the fire chief or fire marshal the structure or complex may be exempted from these requirements for reasons of practical difficulty or an alternate means of entry is provided. 
(1)  Alterations exceeding fifty (50) per cent: If alterations or repairs are made within any period of twelve (12) months, costing in excess of fifty (50) per cent of the physical value of the structure, this section shall apply. 
(2)  Damages exceeding fifty (50) per cent: If the structure is damaged by fire or any other cause to an extent in excess of fifty (50) per cent of the physical value of the structure before the damage was incurred, this section shall apply if it is rebuilt. 
(3)  Increase in size: If the structure is increased in floor area or number of stories, the entire structure shall be made to conform with the requirements of this section. 
(4)  Physical value: In applying the provisions of this section, the physical value of the structure shall be determined by the building official and be based on current replacement costs. 
(Ord. of 6-15-87, § 1; Res. No. 04212008) 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted June 15, 1987, § 1, pertaining to rapid entry system requirements, did not specifically amend the Code, but has been included as § 6-11 by the editor. 
Sec. 6-12. - Registration of nonresident rental property owners. 
A.  Definitions. 
    Address as used in this section, means a location as described by the full street number, if any, the street name, the city or town, and the state, and not a mailing address such as a post office box. 
    Agent in charge as used in this section, means one who manages real estate, including, but not limited to, the collection of rents and supervision of property. 
    Dwelling unit as used in this section, means any house or building, or portion thereof, which is rented, leased or hired out to be occupied, or is arranged or designed to be occupied, or is occupied, as the home or residence of one or more persons, living independently of each other, and doing their cooking upon the premises, and having a common right in the halls, stairways or yards. 
    Nonresident owner as used in the section, means any owner of occupied or vacant rental real property consisting of one (1) or more dwelling units located within the city, but who does not live at the said rental property. 
B.  Registration requirements. 
(1)  Any nonresident owner shall be required to file and maintain on file in the office of the building department of the city the current residential address of the nonresident owner of such property, if the owner is an individual. If the nonresident owner is a corporation, partnership, trust or other legally recognized entity, then the current residential address of the agent in charge of the building consisting of one (1) or more dwelling units shall be filed in the office of the building department of the city. 
(2)  If such residential address changes, notice of the new residential address shall be provided by such nonresident owner or agent in charge of the building consisting of one (1) or more dwelling units to the office of the building department of the city not more than twenty-one (21) days after the date that the address change occurred. 
(3)  If any nonresident owner or agent in charge fails to maintain and/or file an address under the provisions of this section, the address to which the municipality mails property tax bills for the rental real property shall be deemed to be the nonresident owner or agent in charge's current address. Such address may be used for compliance with the provisions of subsection (4). 
(4)  Service of state or municipal orders relating to maintenance of said rental real property or compliance with state law and/or local codes concerning such rental real property directed to the nonresident owner or agent in charge at the address on file with the office of the building department of the city, or deemed to be on file in accordance with subsection (3), shall be sufficient proof of service of notice of such orders in any subsequent criminal or civil action against the nonresident owner or agent in charge for failure to comply with the orders. The provisions of this section shall not be construed to limit the validity of any other means of giving notice of such orders that may be used by the state or such municipality. 
(5)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall have committed an infraction. 
C.  Penalty. 
(1)  As provided for in Connecticut Public Act 05-223, any person who shall violate any provisions of subsection B. shall be assessed a civil penalty of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first violation and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for any subsequent violation. 
(2)  The assessor's office of the city shall mail a notice of such assessment to the nonresident owner or agent in charge of the property which is the subject of the violation. 
(3)  Any person who is assessed a civil penalty pursuant to this section may appeal therefrom to the superior court. Said appeal shall be instituted not later than thirty (30) days after the mailing of notice of such assessment by filing a petition to reopen assessment, together with any entry fee in an amount equal to the entry fee for a small claims case pursuant to § 52-259 of the general statutes, as amended from time to time, at the superior court facility designated by the chief court administrator, which shall entitle such person to a hearing in accordance with the rules of the judges of the superior court. 
(Ord. No. 04-17-06-7, § 1, 4-17-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-17-06-7, § 1, adopted April 17, 2006, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as § 6-12 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 6-13. - Violations of the city's and state's property maintenance and safety codes. 
(A)  Any person who shall (1) violate any portion or provision of any city code or ordinance, or any State of Connecticut code, which violation could result in an order being given by any city code official; or (2) fail to act on or comply with any lawful order given by any city code official, shall have committed an infraction and be fined two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(B)  For purposes of this section, "code official" shall be defined as being any member or agent of the city fire department or city building department, duly authorized to issue orders for violations of any city or state code. 
(C)  This section shall be enforced by (1) the city police department, and (2) the city manager, or his designee, jointly and severally. 
(Ord. No. 02-01-10-7, § 1, 2-1-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-01-10-7, § 1, adopted February 1, 2010, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 6-13 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 6-14-6-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIGNS AND MARQUEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning regulation of signs, App. B, § VIII. 
State Law reference- Outdoor advertising sign regulations, Ch. 411, Gen. Stats.; additional regulations are in state building code. 

Sec. 6-20. - Permit for erection, maintenance required. 
    No sign or marquee shall be erected or maintained projecting from any building into any street or highway within the limits of the city unless a permit for the erection and maintenance of such sign or marquee shall have been granted in accordance with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 1) 
Sec. 6-21. - Application for permit to erect or maintain. 
    Any person who desires a permit to erect or maintain on any building a sign or marquee projecting into any street or highway, shall make an application therefor to the building official on a blank to be furnished by him. Said application shall set forth the full name and residence and business address of the owner of the building upon which said sign or marquee is to be attached; the name and address of the person erecting said sign or marquee; the dimensions of the proposed sign or marquee and its proposed maximum extension in front of the street line and the minimum distance from the lowest point of said proposed sign or marquee to the sidewalk, together with such further information as may be required by the building official. Said application shall also contain a statement that if a permit is granted under said application, the applicant agrees that all requirements of state and city laws and ordinances insofar as they apply to the design, erection, location or maintenance of the sign or marquee therein described will be strictly complied with. Said application shall also contain an agreement on the part of the applicant to save the city harmless from any damages, costs or expenses which may arise from any claim against said city and any injury to person or property resulting from the erection or maintenance of said sign or marquee. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 2; Ord. of 10-5-66, § 2) 
Sec. 6-22. - Manner of construction; extension of marquee. 
    Any sign or marquee erected or maintained in accordance with the provisions of this article shall be substantially constructed so as not to be or become a source of danger to persons or property and shall be securely fastened to the building in a manner approved by the building official. No marquee hereafter constructed or rebuilt shall extend nearer than two (2) feet to the curbline. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 3) 
Sec. 6-23. - Action upon application for permit; appeal from denial of permit. 
    The building official shall examine all applications and plans or drawings submitted therewith and if the same conform to the provisions of this article shall grant the permit. Any applicant for a permit, who shall be aggrieved by the action of the building official in denying his application for a permit, may appeal from the decision of the building official to the building board of appeals by leaving a written notice of appeal with the building official within ten (10) days from the date of the refusal of the building official to grant the permit; and the said notice of appeal, together with the original application and papers in the matter shall be transmitted to the building board of appeals for action. The building board of appeals shall meet upon notice from the inspector of buildings. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 4; Ord. of 10-5-66, § 4) 
Sec. 6-24. - Payment of fee prerequisite to validity of license. 
    Any permit granted herein shall not be valid unless within five (5) days after the granting of the permit, the applicant shall pay to the city treasurer the proper license fee in accordance with the schedule herein set forth. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 5) 
Sec. 6-25. - Duration, expiration of permit; revocation of permit. 
    All permits issued under this article shall expire at 12:00 midnight, October fifteenth of each year. All permits under this article may be revoked by the building official at any time and any sign or marquee may be ordered removed whenever, in the opinion of the building official, public necessity, public safety or public convenience require such removal. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 6; Ord. of 10-5-66, § 6) 
Sec. 6-26. - Fees for permits. 
    The fee for a permit to maintain all signs shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for one year or any part thereof. The fee for the erection or maintenance of a marquee up to eight (8) feet in width shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for one year or any part thereof, for a marquee over eight (8) feet in width, twenty dollars ($20.00) for one year or any part thereof. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 7; Ord. of 10-5-66, § 7) 
Sec. 6-27. - Certificate of insurance prerequisite to grant of permit. 
    Notwithstanding any provision herein contained, no permit for the erection of a sign or marquee shall be granted unless the applicant shall file with the building official a policy or certificate of insurance protecting the city from any loss, liability or damage that may result or accrue from or because of the erecting or maintaining of said sign or marquee with limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury liability, and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for injury to or destruction of property. The insurance policy shall name the city as one of the insureds. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 8; Ord. of 10-5-66, § 8) 
Sec. 6-28. - Renewal of permit. 
    All permits must be renewed on or before October fifteenth, in each year, in the same manner as provided for the granting of permits except that new plans need not be filed provided the old permit is surrendered with an affidavit that the sign or marquee is structurally the same as when originally permitted and in good condition. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 9; Ord. of 10-5-66, § 9) 
Sec. 6-29. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person who shall erect or maintain any sign or marquee contrary to the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each offense, each day or part of a day on which such violation of this article is continued, shall be considered a single and separate offense. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 10) 
Sec. 6-30. - Existing signs and marquees. 
    All persons now maintaining signs or marquees shall not be subject to penalty if they make such alterations or removal of signs or marquees under the direction of the building official as necessary to make said signs and marquees and the maintenance thereof conform to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 11) 
Sec. 6-31. - Enforcement of provisions. 
    It shall be the duty of the building official to inspect each sign or marquee in the city at least once during each year and to call to the attention of the permittee any conditions in connection with said sign or marquee requiring correction, in order to protect and preserve the safety of travelers on the highway. It shall be the duty of any person maintaining a sign or marquee to at once comply with any lawful order of the building official and to make such necessary repairs or corrections ordered by him, to place the sign or marquee in good condition and upon the failure of any person to make such repairs or otherwise to conform to the order of the building official within ten (10) days from the date of such order then the permit for the maintenance of such sign or marquee may be revoked by the building board of appeals. 
(Ord. of 9-17-34, § 12) 
Secs. 6-32-6-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION IN FLOOD-PRONE AREAS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance of May 9, 1977, nonamendatory of the Code, has been included as Art. III at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 6-41. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of this article are (i) to reduce the threat to public safety and the loss of property values resulting from periodic flooding within certain areas of the City of New London, and (ii) to ensure eligibility for continued participation by the City of New London in the National Flood Insurance Program by establishing policies and permit requirements related to land use and development in areas of special flood hazard within the City of New London, consistent with regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program, as published in the Federal Register, Volume 41, Number 207, October 26, 1976. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 1) 
Sec. 6-42. - Applicability; map adopted. 
    This article shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within the City of New London. The areas of special flood hazard identified by the Federal Insurance Administrator through a scientific and engineering report entitled "The Flood Insurance Study for the City of New London," dated May, 1976, with accompanying flood insurance rate map (FIRM) and any revision thereto are hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of this article. The FIRM designations for areas of special flood hazard in the City of New London are A8 and V8 zones. The base flood (100-year flood) elevation for these zones is eleven (11) feet m.s.l. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 2) 
Sec. 6-43. - Effect on city boards, commissions. 
    All official boards and commissions of the City of New London shall take into account flood and flood-related erosion hazards, to the extent that they are known, in all official actions relating to land management and use. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 3) 
Sec. 6-44. - Building permits. 
    Prior to issuing a building permit for any new development construction or substantial improvement within A8 and V8 zones on the FIRM, the building official shall determine that the provisions of this article have been satisfied and that all necessary permits have been obtained from those federal, state or local agencies from which prior approval is required. The building official may require that the applicant provide such structure and water elevation data and construction plans as may be needed to determine proper conformance with this article. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 4) 
Sec. 6-45. - Zone regulations. 
    In all A8 zones and V8 zones as shown on the FIRM, the following provisions shall apply: 
(a)  All new construction and substantial improvements (including the placement of prefabricated buildings and mobile homes) shall (i) be designed (or modified) and adequately anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement of the structure, (ii) be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage, and (iii) be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage. 
(b)  New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems. 
(c)  (1)  New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the system into floodwaters; and 
(2)  On-site waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(d)  New construction or substantial improvement of any residential structure shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to or above base flood elevation. 
(e)  New construction or substantial improvement of any commercial, industrial or other non-residential structure shall either have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated to the level of the base flood elevation or, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, be floodproofed so that below the base flood level the structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and effects of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the standards of this subsection are satisfied. Such certification shall be provided to the building official prior to the issuance of a building permit for such structure. 
(f)  Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of the boundaries of the areas of special flood hazards the building official shall make the necessary interpretation. 
(g)  Mobile homes shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 5) 
Sec. 6-46. - Additional zone regulations. 
    In all areas designated V8 zones on the FIRM the following provisions shall additionally apply: 
(a)  All new construction shall be located landward of the reach of the mean high tide. 
(b)  All new construction or substantial improvements shall be elevated so that the lowest supporting member is located no lower than the base flood elevation level, with all space below the lowest supporting member open so as not to impede the flow of water, except for breakaway walls as provided for in subsection (h), below. 
(c)  All new construction or substantial improvement shall be securely anchored on pilings or columns. 
(d)  Pilings or columns used as structural support shall be designed and anchored so as to withstand all applied loads of the base flood flow and the applicant shall obtain certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that the structure is securely anchored to adequately anchored pilings or columns in order to withstand velocity waters and hurricane wave wash. 
(e)  Compliance with provisions contained in subsections (b), (c) and (d), above, shall be certified to by a registered professional engineer or architect. 
(f)  There shall be no fill used as structural support. 
(g)  There shall be no alteration of sand dunes which would increase potential flood damage. 
(h)  Breakaway walls for new construction or substantial improvements shall be allowed below the base flood elevation provided they are not part of the structural support of the building and are designed so as to breakaway, under abnormally high tides or wave action, without damage to the structural integrity of the building on which they are to be used. 
(i)  If breakaway walls are utilized, such enclosed space shall not be used for human habitation. 
(j)  Prior to construction, plans for any structure that will have breakaway walls must be submitted to the building official for approval. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 6) 
Sec. 6-47. - Record of elevation. 
    The building official shall verify and record the actual elevation (in relation to mean sea level) of the lowest floor (including basement) of all new or substantially improved structures and the actual elevation to which new or substantially improved structures have been floodproofed. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 7) 
Sec. 6-48. - Variances. 
    Variances to the provisions of this article may be granted by the building code board of appeals for the City of New London, in accordance with the following: 
(a)  Variances shall be issued only upon (i) a showing of good and sufficient cause, (ii) a determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship to the applicant, and (iii) a determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisances, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. 
(b)  Variances shall be issued only upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief. 
(c)  The board shall notify the applicant in writing over the signature of the building official that (i) the issuance to construct a structure below the base flood level will result in increased premium rates for flood insurance up to amounts as high as twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for one hundred dollars ($100.00) of insurance coverage and (ii) such construction below the base flood level increases risks to life and property. 
(d)  The board shall (i) maintain a record of all variance actions, including justification for their issuance, and (ii) report such variances issued in its annual report submitted to the Federal Insurance Administrator. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 8) 
Sec. 6-49. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below, words and phrases used in this article shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage. 
(a)  Development means any man-made change to improved or unimproved real estate, including but not limited to buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations. 
(b)  Flood or flooding means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from: 
(1)  The overflow of inland or tidal waters. 
(2)  The unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
(c)  New construction means structures for which the start of construction commenced on or after the effective date of this article. 
(d)  Structure means a walled and roofed building that is principally above ground. 
(e)  Substantial improvement means any repair, reconstruction, or improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds fifty (50) per cent of the market value of the structure either, (1) before the improvement or repair is started, or (2) if the structure has been damaged and is being restored, before the damage occurred. For the purposes of this definition substantial improvement is considered to occur when the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of the building commences, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the structure. The term does not, however, include either (1) any project for improvement of a structure to comply with existing state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which are solely necessary to assure safe living conditions, or (2) any alteration of a structure listed on the National Register of Historic Places or a state inventory of historic places. 
(Ord. of 5-9-77, § 9) 
Chapter 7 - BUSINESSES, TRADES AND PROFESSIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages, § 3-1; buildings and structural appurtenances, Ch. 6; restaurants, Ch. 10, Art. III; slaughterhouses, Ch. 11, Art. V; hotels, lodging and rooming houses and convalescent homes, Ch. 12; housing and commercial structures codes, Ch. 13; peddling, soliciting, advertising prohibited in public parks, § 16-48; using street stand to sell merchandise, § 18-9; using stand in Bates Woods Park to sell goods, § 18-10. 
State Law reference- Taxation, § 12-63a, Gen. Stats. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Businesses selling pistols or revolvers to keep them locked up with alarm system when closed for business. 
(a)  Any person having in his possession with intent to sell or deliver any pistol or revolver at retail and having a permit therefor issued pursuant to the General Statutes of the State of Connecticut shall, at all times, when the room, store, or place where such pistols or revolvers are sold, or offered or exposed for sale, are not open for business, keep said pistols and revolvers stored in a suitable locked vault or safe, or provide a satisfactory security alarm system connected with police headquarters and approved by the chief of police, for the purpose of preventing the theft of said pistols or revolvers. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 8-5-74, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 7-2. - Licenses for temporary private use of public sidewalks. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provision of any other city ordinance, any person who operates a commercial business within the limits of the city may apply for a limited license from the city, through its city council, to use a portion of the city's sidewalk that abuts the commercial business for the placement of temporary seating and chairs for patrons, guests and invitees of said commercial business (hereinafter "license area"). 
(b)  This city, through its city council, shall have the ability to grant or deny a license under this section in its sole and absolute discretion. Any license granted by the city, through its city council, pursuant to this section shall be subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Use of the license area shall be limited to the placement of tables and/or chairs only. Tables shall not be made of glass, and no hooks, fasteners, or holes may be made or affixed to the sidewalk in the license area; 
(2)  Music and other entertainment is prohibited on the license area; 
(3)  The license area shall be properly enclosed with a barrier to separate patrons, guests, and invitees of the commercial business and the general public. The sufficiency of a barrier shall be determined by the city council in its sole discretion, provided that said barrier be no more than four (4) feet in height and no less than two (2) feet in height; 
(4)  Applicant shall provide the city with proof of adequate insurance, naming the city as an additional insured, to cover the use of the license area. Said insurance shall be for no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per incident or occurrence. Applicant shall indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all claims, costs, and damages as a result of the applicant's use of the license area; 
(5)  All tables, chairs, barriers, and other personal property of the applicant shall be completely removed from the license area every day between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., and the license area shall be swept and/or cleaned when said items are removed; 
(6)  Applicant shall abide by the rules and regulations of all municipal, state and federal boards and agencies that may have control and oversight of the applicant's commercial business; 
(7)  Applicant shall abide by all noise ordinances and regulations of the city and state; 
(8)  Applicant shall secure all necessary permits and approvals from the health district for the city prior to using the license area, if applicable; and 
(9)  Applicant shall be responsible for the upkeep and maintenance of the license area while he/she/it is using said area. 
(c)  Upon the granting of a license under this section, the city and the applicant shall execute a written license agreement outlining all terms and conditions of said license and shall provide a plan or sketch drawn to scale illustrating the dimensions and layout of the tables and chairs to be positioned on the license area. 
(d)  The city council shall have the authority to terminate any license granted pursuant to this section in its sole discretion at any time with thirty (30) days written notice to the applicant. 
(e)  Any license granted under the authority of this section shall be personal to the applicant and may not be assigned or transferred to any other party without the express written consent of the city council. 
(f)  The city manager, or his designee, shall enforce the terms and conditions of any license agreement issued pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 08-04-08-1, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-04-08-1, § 1, adopted August 4, 2008, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as § 7-2 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 7-3-7-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AMUSEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- State licenses, § 29-129 et seq.; Gen. Stats.; outdoor carnivals, etc., §§ 165, 166, Gen. Stats. 

Sec. 7-11. - Scope of license requirements. 
    No person shall conduct or assist in conducting any exhibition, circus, menagerie, carnival, amusement park, place of amusement, entertainment, diversion or recreation to which an amusement fee is charged, or keep any pinball machine or device emitting songs or music, the use of which machines or device require the insertion of any coin, slug, or token, or for the use of which a charge is otherwise made, without a license having been obtained therefor in the manner hereinafter provided. Such license must be obtained whether the amusement fee is charged for entrance to the area in which the activities subject to this article are conducted, or for the use of any amusement, machine or device located within the amusement area and subject to this article. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 1) 
Sec. 7-12. - Application for, issuance of license. 
    Any person desiring a license to conduct any such place, device or game, shall make application therefor to the chief of police, stating his name and address, the location and character of the exhibition, circus, menagerie, carnival, amusement park, place of amusement, entertainment, diversion or recreation proposed to be conducted by him, and shall give such other information pertaining thereto as shall be required by the chief of police. Upon the approval of such application by the chief of police and chief executive officer and the payment of the fee as provided in section 7-15 hereto, the chief executive officer, or designee shall issue a license to the person applying therefor to conduct such place, device or game for such period as may be prescribed and limited by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 2; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 7-13. - Prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    Before approving any application for a license to conduct any such place, device or game, the chief of police may require such information regarding such place as he may find to be necessary to safeguard the public from all forms of lascivious conduct, immoral practices, vice or violations of the law with respect to gambling. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 3) 
Sec. 7-14. - Public liability insurance requirements. 
(a)  The chief of police, before approving the application of any person for a license provided for herein to conduct any mechanical or other device upon which people may enter or ride, and any amusement or amusement area covered under this article, except for music vending machines, pinball machines and similar devices, shall require that such applicant procure public liability insurance with an insurance company authorized to transact business in this state, which insurance shall protect the applicant and the city against any legal liability for injury (or death) to or of any person resulting from or caused by the use or operation of the device, amusement or amusement area described in the application. Such insurance shall be in a minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injury to a single person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to more than one person, or in such larger amount or amounts as the city manager may deem necessary to protect the public interest. 
(b)  The city manager may require any applicant hereunder for a license to conduct or operate pinball machines, music vending machines and similar devices to which the minimum insurance requirements above set forth are not applicable to procure and carry public liability insurance protecting the applicant and the city in such amount or amounts as the city manager may deem necessary in the public interest. 
(c)  The city manager may require any applicant hereunder to procure and carry products liability insurance and insurance protecting the applicant and the city, and insurance protecting the applicant for damage to property of others in such amount or amounts as the city manager may deem advisable for the protection of the public interest. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 4) 
Sec. 7-15. - Fees for licenses. 
    The fees for the licenses to be issued under the provisions of this article shall be and are hereby fixed as follows; to wit: 
Annual Daily Dance hall ..... $50.00 $10.00 Theatre ..... 50.00 10.00 Moving picture house ..... 50.00 10.00 Circus, carnival and/or menagerie ..... 1,000.00 100.00 Menagerie alone ..... 500.00 50.00 Mechanical ride device ..... 50.00 10.00 Music vending machine or device, each machine ..... 25.00 - Pinball machine or other device, each machine ..... 20.00 - Any other place of amusement, including a place where pinball machines, or other devices, except music vending machines, as described above are operated ..... 25.00 -  
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 5; Ord. of 7-19-82, § 1) 
Sec. 7-16. - Right to enter, inspect premises. 
    The city manager, the director of health or any police officer of the city shall have authority to enter into any place so licensed for the purpose of observing the conduct of the same and whether any laws of the state or ordinance of the city are being violated and for the purpose of protecting the public from danger of accidents in connection with the conduct of such place, device or game. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 6) 
Sec. 7-17. - Minors operating pinball machines. 
    No person holding a license for pinball machines shall permit children under fourteen (14) years of age to play or operate such machines; violation of this provision shall be deemed sufficient cause for the city manager to revoke said license. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 7) 
Sec. 7-18. - Applicability of provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be so construed as to require a license to conduct any hotel, restaurant or eating place, or to in any way modify the statutes of this state in reference to the observance of Sunday. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 8) 
Sec. 7-19. - Transferability, abandonment of license. 
    The license issued under this article shall not be transferable, and if any licensee shall voluntarily discontinue operations thereunder, all rights thereby shall terminate. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 10) 
Sec. 7-20. - Display of license. 
    Every licensee shall display his certificate of license conspicuously for public view at the place where the business so licensed is conducted. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 11) 
Sec. 7-21. - Authority of chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall prescribe a form of application to be signed by each applicant and may require such information respecting the business in which the applicant proposes to engage as he may find to be necessary to safeguard the public from all forms of lascivious conduct, immoral practices, vice or violations of the law with respect to gambling, and he may enter any place so licensed or upon the premises where such business is being conducted for the purpose of observing the conduct of any such place of amusement, entertainment, diversion or recreation so licensed. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 12) 
Sec. 7-22. - Duration, renewal of license. 
    Any and all licenses granted on an annual basis shall expire on January thirty-first of each year and must be renewed prior to February first of each year. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 13) 
Sec. 7-23. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Upon the conviction of any person licensed as herein provided, for the violation of any law or ordinance in connection with the conduct of any such place, device or game, such license shall thereupon be forfeited and revoked; and the city manager may revoke such license whenever it appears to him to be in the interest of the public welfare, morals or safety so to do. 
(Ord. of 12-29-60, § 9) 
Secs. 7-24-7-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AUCTIONEERS 

Sec. 7-35. - Scope of license requirement. 
    No person shall sell any property at public auction within the City of New London without having been licensed as an auctioneer in the manner herein provided. 
(Ord. of 10-23-22, § 1) 
Sec. 7-36. - Application for, issuance of license. 
    Any person desiring an auctioneer's license shall apply for same to the city manager who if he finds the person to be a suitable person to receive such license and the auctions to be held to be bona fide public auctions shall direct the city clerk to issue a license therefor to the person so designated by the city manager and such person shall pay to the city clerk the license fee hereinafter provided for. 
(Ord. of 10-23-22, § 2) 
Sec. 7-37. - Duration of license. 
    Such license shall continue for the period of one year from the date thereof unless sooner revoked as provided herein. 
(Ord. of 10-23-22, § 3) 
Sec. 7-38. - Fee for license; transferability. 
    The license fee to be paid for such license shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). The license issued shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. of 10-23-22, § 4; Ord. of 12-29-60) 
Sec. 7-39. - Deceptive conduct prohibited. 
    No auctioneer shall receive secret bids from the owner or agent of the property being sold, or falsely pretend to have received any bid, or knowingly receive a bid from or dispose of or sell the property to any person not a bona fide bidder, or be guilty of any other fraud or deception at any auction. 
(Ord. of 10-23-22, § 5) 
Sec. 7-40. - Exceptions to provisions. 
    This article shall not apply to any sale upon execution by a sheriff or any other proper officer by any process of law, or to a sale made by any order or decree of any court. 
(Ord. of 10-23-22, § 7) 
Sec. 7-41. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former § 7-41, which pertained to the duties of the city clerk, and derived from an ordinance of October 23, 1922, § 8, has been deleted at the direction of the city. 
Sec. 7-42. - Violations and penalties. 
    Every person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) payable into the treasury of the city, and his license as an auctioneer shall thereupon be revoked by the chief executive officer. 
(Ord. of 10-23-22, § 6) 
Secs. 7-43-7-53. - Reserved.
