ARTICLE VI. - DEALERS IN SECONDHAND OR USED ARTICLES, ETC., MADE OF PRECIOUS METALS 

Sec. 7-93. - Scope of license requirement. 
    No person shall engage in business as a buyer or trader in secondhand articles or other personal property or used articles of jewelry made of gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals unless licensed to do so as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. of 4-21-36, § 1; Ord. of 4-7-80, § 1) 
Sec. 7-94. - Application for, issuance of license. 
    Any person desiring to be licensed hereunder shall make an application to the chief of police in writing stating his name, residence, post office address and the location of his business. At the time of filing the application the applicant shall pay to the chief of police the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) as a license fee for the privilege of carrying on such business. Upon approval of the application and the payment of said fee, the chief of police shall issue a license to the applicant to engage in the business of a buyer or trader in secondhand articles or other personal property or used articles of jewelry made of gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals for a period of one (1) year from the date of issue unless sooner revoked for cause. 
(Ord. of 4-21-36, § 2; Ord. of 12-29-60; Ord. No. 4-7-80, § 1) 
Sec. 7-95. - Restrictions upon issuance of license. 
    No license shall be issued to any person unless he is found to be of good character and reputation and a suitable person to be so licensed. And no license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the crime of theft or of receiving stolen goods within five (5) years preceding the date of said application. 
(Ord. of 4-21-36, § 3) 
Sec. 7-96. - Conduct of licensees restricted. 
    All business of trading in secondhand articles or other personal property or used articles of jewelry made of gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals shall be transacted by the licensee at the place of business named in his license, and it shall be unlawful for the licensee or his agents or servants to travel from door to door or house to house soliciting or offering to buy such articles. 
(Ord. of 4-21-36, § 4; Ord. of 4-7-80, § 1) 
Sec. 7-97. - Licensees to file sworn statements. 
    Each dealer licensed hereunder shall make weekly sworn statements of all his transactions under such license, describing the goods received and setting forth the name and residence and a description of the person from whom such goods were received to the chief of police and all such goods received shall be kept by the dealer at least five (5) days after the filing of such statement. 
(Ord. of 4-21-36, § 5) 
Sec. 7-98. - Revocation of license. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to revoke the license of any person licensed hereunder upon his conviction of violating the terms of this article or in the event he is convicted of theft or of receiving stolen goods. 
(Ord. of 4-21-36, § 6) 
Sec. 7-99. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person who shall engage in the business of dealing or trading in secondhand articles or other personal property or used articles of jewelry made of gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals without being licensed as herein provided or who, being licensed, shall fail to comply with the provisions of this article relating to said business shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than three (3) months or both. 
(Ord. of 4-21-36, § 7; Ord. of 4-7-80, § 1) 
Secs. 7-100-7-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDDLERS AND HAWKERS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-16-94-4, adopted May 16, 1994, repealed and reenacted article VII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article VII pertained to peddlers and itinerant vendors, and derived from an ordinance of January 3, 1961, §§ 1-6; an ordinance of March 17, 1980, § 1, and Ord. of May 17, 1982, § 1. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate peddlers, §§ 7-194(34), 21-37, Gen. Stats. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-106. - Applicability. 
(a)  Except as exempted from regulation by the provision of this ordinance or any state statute, it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in vending, peddling, hawking or any other sales of any goods, wares, or other merchandise, including the solicitation of funds or money, which serves the general public outdoors on any publicly or privately owned parcel or lot, any sidewalk or city street, or from house to house, within the city without first obtaining a permit from the city in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall obviate any other requirement of any law, article or regulation adopted by any federal, state or local agency. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4; Ord. No. 06-18-07-1, § 1) 
Sec. 7-107. - Definitions. 
    Peddler. Any person who operates from one location and/or who goes from place to place, from house to house or from street to street selling or bartering, or carrying for sale or bartering, or exposing therefore, any food, goods, wares or merchandise, including the solicitation of funds or money, either on foot or from any animal, vehicle or any other type of conveyance. Activities such as, but not limited to, sidewalk cafes, street musicians and entertainers, sidewalk sales and displays, food vendors, vending carts, pushcarts, stands and kiosks shall be considered as regulated under the provisions of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4; Ord. No. 06-18-07-1, § 1) 
Sec. 7-108. - Exemptions. 
    The following activities shall be exempt from all provisions of this article: 
(a)  Sales, distribution and delivery of milk, teas, coffees, spices, groceries, meats, bakery goods and newspapers. 
(b)  Sales by farmers and gardeners or the produce of their farms and gardens. 
(c)  Tag sales or garage sales on premises devoted to residential use for no more than eight (8) days in any calendar year. 
(d)  Any person, firm or corporation operating any business on any state highway or land abutting any state highway pursuant to a contract with the state. 
(e)  When in the opinion of the chief executive officer the activity is for eleemosynary, philanthropic, ecclesiastic, non-profit or any other similar purposes and of limited duration. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4) 
Sec. 7-109. - Special event permits. 
(a)  A special events permit may be issued to persons engaged in the sale of products or foodstuffs at parades, sidewalk sales, Sail Festival and other special events as recognized by the chief executive officer. 
(b)  A special event permit may, at the discretion of the chief executive officer be issued to the sponsor of a special event. The sponsor shall be responsible for providing a list to the chief executive officer identifying all persons who will sell goods or products during the event. This list must be submitted not later than five days before the special event. 
(c)  All activity licensed under a special event permit will be limited to the hours and the location of the special event and shall be otherwise except from the requirements of this ordinance except for the requirements to obtain a permit and to provide insurance and indemnity coverage as specified in section 7-111. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4) 
Sec. 7-110. - Requirement for obtaining a permit. 
(a)  No vendor or peddler shall operate within ten (10) feet of any driveway, bus stop, fire hydrant, crosswalk, handicapped parking space or access ramp or within twenty-five (25) feet of any intersection. 
(b)  No activity permitted under the provisions of this ordinance shall obstruct pedestrian or motor vehicle traffic, cause undue noise or offensive odors, be detrimental or injurious to the public safety or interfere with the use of any street, sidewalk or public place by the public at large. In making this determination the chief executive officer shall only grant permits for activities after considering the width of the sidewalks, the proposed location of the activity and the nature of the activity and insuring an unobstructed clear passage area for pedestrians between any pushcart, stand, display, chair, table or any other obstruction including light poles, sign poles, building fronts, trees and street furniture and any street or highway. 
(c)  No person shall peddle or vend within the city between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., unless specifically authorized by the city council. 
(d)  No person shall peddle within five hundred (500) feet of the main entrance to any school or its playground area on any day while school is in session. 
(e)  No person shall vend or peddle except where the motor vehicle is lawfully parked or stopped and no person may peddle to a person standing in the roadway. 
(f)  No vehicle, pushcart or stand or any other equipment related to the operation of a peddling or vending business shall touch, lean against or be affixed to any building or structure, including but not limited to lamp posts, parking meters, mailboxes, traffic signal structures, fire hydrants, benches, bus shelters, refuse baskets or traffic barriers. 
(g)  No peddler shall be permitted to operate in any of the public parks of the city without first obtaining the written approval of the parks and recreation commission or the city council, whichever is appropriate. 
(h)  No person other than the permittee shall engage in peddling or vending under a permit issued under the provisions of these regulations. 
(i)  The permittee shall maintain all areas adjacent to and including the areas where the peddler is located in a clean and sanitary manner, including but not limited to providing and maintaining appropriate trash receptacles as well as sweeping at least once a day the full area where the permittee is located and immediately cleaning away any spilled liquid, food, debris, broken glass, and any other trash from the immediate area. 
(j)  The permit operating area must be located within a commercial zone unless the vendor continually moves the operation from place to place and does not operate from one location for more than one-half hour in any twenty-four-hour period, provided, however, that the city council may specifically authorize vending in a non-commercial zone without continual movement every one-half hour. 
(k)  The length of any vending cart or pushcart shall not exceed eight (8) feet. 
(l)  No motor vehicle shall be used in the central business district (CBD) for hawking, peddling, selling or vending, unless specifically authorized by the city council. 
(m)  The operating area for an activity regulated under this ordinance shall generally not exceed twenty-five (25) square feet of area, however, the chief executive officer may approve exceptions to this requirement for sidewalk sales and displays under the condition that no sidewalk display or sale shall exceed an area equal to 1.5 times the linear length of the building frontage. The requirements of this section of the article shall not apply to sidewalk cafes. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4; Ord. No. 06-18-07-1, § 1; Ord. No. 05-20-13-6, § 1.A., B., 5-20-13) 
Sec. 7-111. - Application for permit. 
(a)  The fee for such license shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year, or portion thereof, for residents of the city and shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year, or portion thereof, for nonresidents of the city, except that the chief of police is authorized to issue a temporary license for which the fee shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per day; and, unless sooner revoked, all licenses shall expire on the thirty-first day of December succeeding the date of issue thereof. 
(b)  Any person requesting a license pursuant to this ordinance shall file an application with the chief of police not less than five (5) days before the proposed solicitation of funds or money, which application shall include the person's name, including any aliases and maiden names, current address, current telephone number, a photo identification, such as, an operator's license or a passport and the name of all other municipalities where said person previously solicited funds or money. 
(c)  Upon receipt of any application, the chief of police shall review the application and investigate the applicant's background to the extent necessary to protect the public good and shall forward the application and a copy of his report to the chief executive officer who shall: 
(1)  Endorse on any application found unsatisfactory his disapproval and the reasons therefore and hand deliver or return same to the applicant by certified mailing; or 
(2)  Endorse on any application his approval, and hand deliver or return same to the applicant by certified mail that he or she can obtain a permit upon providing the chief of police with the following, except where otherwise provided: 
a.  The appropriate permit fee; 
b.  Conclusive proof of the possession of a valid state sales and use tax permit in accordance with General Statute § 12-409, as amended; 
c.  An executed agreement in a form acceptable to the city law director to indemnify and hold harmless the city and its officers, employees, agents and assigns from any and all claims, actions, injuries and damages of every kind and description which may accrue to or be suffered by any person by reason of or related to the permit issued by this article; 
d.  All peddlers shall file a certificate of insurance naming the city, its officers, employees, agents, and assigns as the additional named insured. The certificate of insurance shall be in a minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) against any and all damage and injury to property of persons by reason of, or related to, the licensee's use of public streets, sidewalks or other places used under the permit issued by this article. Said insurance shall be maintained throughout the duration of the permit period and failure to do so shall be a violation of this article; 
e.  When applicable, a copy of a valid health department certificate enforceable for the same period of time as the requested license; and 
f.  When applicable, a copy of a certificate from the state sealer of weights and measure indicating that all weights and measures used by the applicant in his business have been approved and stamped. 
(d)  If an application is made after July 1 of any year the amount of any application fee for a permit may be reduced by the chief executive officer to one-half of the normally required fee. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4; Ord. No. 06-18-07-1, § 1) 
Sec. 7-112. - Identification of permit. 
    Each person licensed hereunder shall, on exercising his vocation, wear conspicuously on his left breast a suitable badge designed and furnished by the chief of police with the words "licensed vendor" and the number of his license and the year such license is in force, in numerals, plainly inscribed thereon; and each person so licensed, when using for the purpose for which he is licensed, a wagon, cart or vehicle, shall have plainly displayed on both sides of such wagon, cart or vehicle, a sign designed and furnished by the chief of police bearing the number of his license and the year in which such license is in force in numerals and the words "Licensed Vendor" in Roman letters, each numeral or letter to be at least three (3) inches in height, such badge and sign to be furnished by the chief of police without expense to the person so licensed. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4; Ord. No. 06-18-07-1, § 1) 
Sec. 7-113. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The chief executive officer may revoke the permit of any individual authorized under the provision of this ordinance for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Violation of any requirement of this article; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for a permit or made in the course of carrying on the permittee's business; 
(3)  Conviction of any felony or any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
(4)  Violation of any laws or regulations which occur during or are related to the permittees' operations; 
(5)  Conducting the activity here in regulated in such a manner as to constitute a breach of peace or constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of the revocation of a permit, setting forth specifically the grounds for permit revocation shall be sent to the permittee by certified mail. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4) 
Sec. 7-114. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief executive officer in denying his or her application or by revoking his or her permit shall have a right of appeal to the city council. Such appeal must be received, in writing, by the chief executive officer within five (5) days of the date of the occurrence of any appealable action. 
(b)  After notice of the appeal shall have been filed with the chief executive officer the city council shall schedule a hearing within thirty (30) days from such filing. Notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be mailed to the appellant at the home address appearing on his application. At the conclusion of the hearing, the council shall render a decision granting or denying the appeal modifying the action which has been appealed. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4) 
Sec. 7-115. - Violation and penalties. 
(a)  The city police department and the chief executive officer, or his duly authorized agent, shall be responsible for the enforcement of this ordinance. When it has been determined that a violation has occurred it shall constitute an infraction of a local ordinance and shall be prosecuted as such. 
(b)  Any person who shall engage in the business aforesaid without being duly licensed as herein provided, or who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4; Ord. No. 06-18-07-1, § 1) 
Sec. 7-116. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be considered a separate violation of this article. 
(b)  If any provision of this ordinance or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of any other part of this article which can be given effect without the invalid provisions of applications; and to this end, the provisions of this article and the various applications thereof are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 05-16-94-4; Ord. No. 06-18-07-1, § 1) 
DIVISION 2. - ITINERANT VENDORS 

Sec. 7-117. - Definitions. 
(a)  Itinerant vendor. The term "itinerant vendor" shall mean any person, whether acting as principal or agent, or engages in a temporary or transient business, either in one location or traveling from place to place, selling goods, wares, or merchandise, and who, for the purpose of carrying on such business, hires, leases, or occupies any building or structure in the city for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares, or merchandise. 
(b)  Temporary or transient business. The term "temporary or transient business" shall mean any exhibition and sale of goods, wares, or merchandise which is carried on in any tent, booth, building, or other structure unless such place shall be open for business during usual business hours for a period of at least nine (9) months in each year. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-06-1, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 02-04-08-10, 2-4-08) 
Sec. 7-118. - Exemptions from this division. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall not apply to sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business, or to bona fide sales or goods, wares and merchandise by sample for future delivery, or to hawkers on the streets or peddlers from vehicles, or to any sale of goods, wares or merchandise on the grounds of any incorporated agricultural society during the continuance of any annual fair held by such society, or to any general sale, fair, auction or bazaar held or sponsored by an ecclesiastical or eleemosynary society or church corporation, or to municipally sponsored events as approved by city council, or to tag sales or garage sales on premises devoted to residential use and where permitted by law. 
(b)  No street vendor or itinerant vendor shall be relieved or exempted from the provisions or requirements of this division by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, auctioneer, trader, or merchant, or by conducting any temporary or transient business in connection with or in the name of any local dealer, auctioneer, trader or merchant. 
(c)  The city council, by five affirmative votes of the seven members, may waive the provisions of this division for any itinerant vendor. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-06-1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 7-119. - License-Required; term. 
(a)  No itinerant vendor shall do business in the city unless he or she shall have first obtained a license to do so issued by the chief executive officer, or designee. 
(b)  Such license shall be issued in the name of the itinerant vendor only and shall not be transferable. 
(c)  Each itinerant vendor's license shall remain in force as long as the licensee continuously keeps and exposes for sale in the city his stock or goods, wares, or merchandise, but not later than the first day of October following its date. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-06-1, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 7-120. - Same-Application. 
    Each person desiring to secure a license as an itinerant vendor shall file with the chief executive officer, or designee, in duplicate, a sworn application which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address; 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the products to be sold and the trade name, if any, under which such business will operate; 
(4)  If this application is to be employed by or associated with another licensee, permittee or applicant therefore, the name of such other person; 
(5)  Reserved. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(7)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, including misdemeanors and motor vehicle violations, the nature of the offense, if any, and the punishment or penalty assessed therefore; 
(8)  Reserved. 
(9)  A fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) to defray the cost of investigating and processing the application and a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to defray production costs of the license; 
(10)  Reserved. 
(11)  A description of the temporary or transient business location where sales will be made. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-06-1, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 7-121. - Requirements for obtaining license. 
    Upon receipt of such application the director of the office of development and planning, or his designee, through the chief of police, shall within twenty-one (21) days, investigate the applicant's background to the extent necessary to protect the public good. Upon completion of such investigation he shall: 
(1)  Endorse on any application found unsatisfactory his disapproval and the reasons therefore and return same to the applicant by mailing to his or her address listed thereon; or 
(2)  Endorse on any application his approval, and notify the applicant by mail that he or she can obtain same upon providing the city clerk with the following: 
(a)  A license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); 
(b)  Conclusive proof of the possession of a state sales and use tax permit; 
(c)  The applicant's state itinerant vendor's license, to be recorded in full by the city clerk after said clerk has endorsed thereon the words "local license fees paid" and affixed thereto his official signature and the date of such endorsement; 
(d)  A bond running to the city in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) executed by the applicant as principal with two (2) sureties upon whom service of process may be made in the state, said bond to be in a form approved by the director of law, conditioned that said applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the city and statutes of the state and shall pay all judgments rendered. Said bond shall be held by the city for a period of three (3) months beyond the expiration of the license or the surrender of the same to the city; and 
(e)  An instrument nominating and appointing the city clerk the true and lawful agent of the applicant with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of the applicant for all business transacted pursuant to the license or for the performance of the conditions of the bond or for any breach thereof. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-06-1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 7-122. - Revocation of license. 
    The director of the office of development and planning, or his designee, may revoke the license, of any person for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Violation of any provision of this division; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for a license; 
(3)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in the course of carrying on the licensee's business; 
(4)  Conviction of any felony or any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
(5)  Violation of any laws or regulations which occur during or are related to the licensee's business operations. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-06-1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 7-123. - Appeal re license denial or revocation. 
    Any persons aggrieved by the action of the city manager in denying his or her application by revoking his or her license shall have the right of appeal to the council of the city, or their delegates. After notice of the appeal shall have been filed with the city clerk, the council, or their delegates, shall schedule a hearing within fourteen (14) days from such filing. Notice of time and place of the hearing shall be mailed to the appellants at the address appearing on his or her application. At the conclusion of the hearing, the council, or their delegates, shall render a decision denying or granting the appeal or modifying the action taken by the city manager, which decision shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-06-1, 3-6-06) 
Sec. 7-124. - Fines, conflicts, severability, miscellaneous provisions. 
A.  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall receive a citation and be fined one hundred ($100.00) dollars. 
B.  Each day on which a violation occurs or continues after the time for correction of violation given in any order has elapsed shall be considered a separate violation of this article. 
C.  All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are hereby repealed. 
D.  If any provision of this article or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of any other part of this article that can be given affect without the invalid provisions or applications; and to this end, the provisions of this article and the various applications thereof are declared to be severable. 
E.  This article shall become effective fifteen (15) days after notice of its passage is duly published. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-06-1, 3-6-06) 
Secs. 7-125-7-127. - Reserved.

ARTICLE X. - SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS 

Sec. 7-164. - Scope of permit requirements. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to go in or upon any private residence, apartment or premises in this city for the purpose of soliciting from the occupants thereof, or to canvass for orders for goods, wares, merchandise or services of any character or description, or for the purpose of offering to give or furnish or giving or furnishing any goods, wares, merchandise or services to any such occupants to induce or invite such orders, without having first applied for and received from the chief of police a solicitor's permit so to do. 
(Ord. of 7-25-38, § 1) 
Sec. 7-165. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to secure such a solicitor's permit shall apply therefor in writing over his or her signature to the chief of police on forms provided by the city, and such application shall state the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the person, firm or corporation by whom employed, the length of service of such applicant with such employer, the place of residence and nature of the employment of the applicant during the last preceding year, the nature or character of the goods, wares, merchandise or services to be offered by the applicant, and the personal description of the applicant. 
(b)  Such application shall be accompanied by such credentials and other evidence of the good moral character and identity of the applicant, as may be reasonably required by the chief of police. 
(Ord. of 7-25-38, § 2) 
Sec. 7-166. - Issuance, duration of permit. 
    If the chief of police shall determine after reasonable investigation that the applicant is of good moral character and proposes to engage in a lawful and legitimate commercial or professional enterprise he shall then issue the permit applied for which permit shall expire on the thirty-first day of December of the year in which such permit shall have been issued. 
(Ord. of 7-25-38, § 3) 
Sec. 7-167. - Duty to carry, exhibit permit. 
    Such permit shall be carried at all times by the applicant to whom issued, when soliciting or canvassing in the city, and shall be exhibited by any such applicant whenever he or she shall be requested so to do by any police officer or any person solicited. 
(Ord. of 7-25-38, § 4) 
Sec. 7-168. - Revocation of permit. 
    Any such permit may be revoked by the chief of police for violation by the holder thereof of any of the ordinances of the city or of any state or federal law, or whenever the holder of such permit shall in the judgment of the chief of police cease to possess the character and qualifications required by this section for the issuance of such permit. 
(Ord. of 7-25-38, § 5) 
Sec. 7-169. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. Every day upon which such violation shall occur or upon which such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. of 7-25-38, § 6) 
Secs. 7-170-7-180. - Reserved.

Chapter 7.1 - CRIME PREVENTION AND POLICE PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 15; police department, § 15-16 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 7.1-1-7.1-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AUTOMATIC ALARM SYSTEMS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 7.1-11-7.1-15. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BURGLARY AND ROBBERY SYSTEMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- An Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1, amended the Code by adding a new Chapter 22, entitled "Crime Prevention and Police Protection," consisting of Art. I, §§ 22-1-22-9, providing for regulation of burglary and robbery alarm systems. For purposes of preserving Code format, the editor has redesignated said provisions as Div. 2, §§ 7.1-16-7.1-25; with the city's permission, and for purposes of classification, the editor at his discretion has varied the section order of the provisions as enacted. 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 15; police department, § 15-56 et seq. 

Sec. 7.1-16. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to set forth regulations governing burglary and robbery alarm systems connected to police headquarters and to require permits therefor, establish fees, standards of performance and provide punishment for violations of provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-17. - Definitions. 
    Audible alarm means a device which is designed for the detection of unauthorized entry on premises and which generates an audible sound heard outside the premises when it is activated. 
    Central station alarm means any alarm which is connected to a private alarm or security business. 
    False alarm means an alarm signal necessitating response by the police department where an emergency situation does not exist. 
    Police alarm system means any mechanical or electrical device which is designed or used for the detection of: 
(1)  An unauthorized entry into a building, structure or facility, or 
(2)  Commission of a robbery, and which alerts the police department of the commission of a crime within such building, structure or facility. The alarm transmits a signal to police headquarters. 
    Devices which are not connected directly to police headquarters are not defined as a police alarm system. 
    Proprietor alarm means an alarm not connected to police headquarters or an alarm company. 
    Subscriber means any person, corporation or firm, who or which maintains an alarm system connected to police headquarters. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-18. - Use of automatic alarm calling devices limited. 
    No person except a public utility engaged in the business of providing communications services and facilities shall use or operate, attempt to use or operate, or cause to be used or operated, or arrange, adjust, program or otherwise provide or install any device or combination of devices that will upon activation, either mechanically, electronically or by other automatic means, initiate an intrastate call and deliver a recorded message to any telephone number assigned to any agency of the city by a public telephone company without prior approval of the appropriate city agency. 
    Conditions for approval of such device shall be subject to the same requirements, restrictions and penalties as applied to police alarm systems. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-19. - Notice, permit requirements. 
(a)  Audible alarms. Every person maintaining an audible alarm shall post a notice containing the names and telephone numbers of the persons to be notified to render repairs or service and secure the premises during any hour of the day or night that the burglar alarm is actuated. Such notice shall be posted near the alarm in such a position as to be legible from the ground level adjacent to the building where the alarm system is located. In addition, such person shall register with the police the names and telephones of persons to be notified. 
(b)  Central and proprietor alarms. No permit is required for central and proprietor alarm systems. 
(c)  Police alarm system. A permit is required for a police alarm system. Persons desiring to become a subscriber shall file an application with the police department requesting a permit to install a police alarm system. Such application will be on a form prescribed by the police chief. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-20. - Permit fees. 
    The fee for an alarm system shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) and shall not be prorated. February first shall be the anniversary date for all such permits. Such permit issued on February first shall expire three (3) years after said issuance. Such permits issued subsequent to any February first shall expire three (3) years after said February first. Applications for renewals of permits shall be processed in the same manner as applications for the initial permit. The fee for renewal of such a permit shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each successive three-year period. (Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-21. - Denial of permit. 
    A permit shall be denied by the police chief if: 
(a)  The character or reputation of the applicant is determined to be inimical to the safety or general welfare of the community; 
(b)  The alarm business installer does not comply with the standards and regulations adopted pursuant to this article; 
(c)  The applicant, his employee or agent has knowingly made any false, misleading or fraudulent statement of a material fact in the application for a permit, or in any report or record required to be filed with any city agency; 
(d)  The applicant had a similar type of permit previously revoked for good cause within the past year, unless the applicant can show a material change in circumstances since the date of revocation; or 
(e)  The alarm system does not comply with standards and regulations adopted pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-22. - Police alarm system standards and regulations. 
(a)  Construction and maintenance; inspection. The police chief may prescribe minimum standards and regulations for the construction and maintenance of the police alarm systems installed within the city. These standards and regulations shall become effective upon adoption thereof by resolution of the city council. All devices shall meet or exceed such standards and regulations before permits may be issued pursuant to this article. The police chief may require inspection and approval of all police alarm systems installed within the city in accordance with existing ordinances. 
(b)  Performance. The police chief shall establish minimum standards of performance for police alarm systems and will institute regulations to insure a minimum number of false alarms. The police chief may exercise sanctions against subscribers who do not comply with the standards, which may result in suspension or revocation of the subscriber's permit. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-23. - Suspension and revocation of permit. 
    The following shall constitute grounds for suspension and revocation [of a permit issued pursuant to this article]: 
(a)  The violation of any of the provisions of this article; 
(b)  The failure to comply with standards or regulations pursuant to this article; 
(c)  The alarm system actuating excessive false alarms and thereby constituting a public nuisance; 
(d)  The applicant or permittee, his employees or agent having knowingly made any false, misleading or fraudulent statements of a material fact in the application for a permit, or in any report or record required to be filed with any city agency; or 
(e)  The applicant or permittee having had a similar type of permit previously revoked for good cause. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-24. - Appeals from decisions of police chief. 
    A subscriber may appeal the decision of the police chief within fifteen (15) days of notification but an appeal shall not deter police action pending appeal. Appeals shall be directed to the city manager. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-25. - Violations of police alarm system provisions. 
(a)  Prohibitions. 
(1)  No person shall possess or operate a police alarm system without first applying for and obtaining an alarm permit therefor in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  No subscriber shall operate a police alarm system during the period when his permit has been suspended or revoked. 
(b)  Penalty. The penalty for operating a police alarm system without a permit shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the first offense, and fifty dollars ($50.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1) 
Secs. 7.1-26-7.1-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REMOTE STATION PROTECTIVE SIGNALING SYSTEMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- At the city's request that Ord. of July 7, 1986, pertaining to remote station protective signaling systems, be included in Ch. 7.1 of the Code, such provisions have been designated herein as Div. 3, §§ 7.1-31-7.1-39. For the specific derivation of each section, the user's attention is directed to the history note parenthetically enclosed following the particular section. 

Sec. 7.1-31. - Defined. 
    A remote station protective signaling system is an installation using a supervised dedicated circuit, installed in accordance with National Fire Protection Association Standards, to transmit an alarm, supervisory and trouble signals from one (1) or more protected premises to a remote location at which appropriate action is taken. 
(Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1) 
Sec. 7.1-32. - Application of standard. 
    This standard [division] deals with the installation, maintenance, testing and use of a remote station protective signaling system which serves properties under various ownership from a remote station (hereafter called vendor). 
(Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1(q)) 
Sec. 7.1-33. - Equipment generally. 
    All devices, combinations of devices, appliances and equipment installed in conformity with this standard shall be listed for the protective signaling purpose for which they are used. 
(Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1(a)) 
Sec. 7.1-34. - Listed equipment. 
    [Listed equipment shall be] equipment or materials included in a list published by an organization acceptable to the fire marshal and concerned with product evaluation, that maintains periodic inspection of production of listed equipment or materials and whose listing states either that the equipment or material meets appropriate standards or has been tested and found suitable for use in a specified manner. 
(Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1(b)) 
Sec. 7.1-35. - Notification of fire marshal prior to installation or alteration. 
    The fire marshal shall be notified prior to installation or alteration of equipment or wiring. At his request, complete information regarding the system or system alterations, including specifications, wiring diagrams, and floor plans shall be submitted for approval. 
(Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1(c)) 
Sec. 7.1-36. - Manner of installation. 
    All systems shall be installed in a workmanlike manner and in accordance with applicable standards and with the approval of the fire marshal. 
(Ord. of 7-7-86(f)) 
Sec. 7.1-37. - Acceptance tests required. 
    Upon completion of an installation, or alterations, satisfactory tests of the entire system shall be made. All functions of the system shall be tested, including operation of the system in various alarm and trouble modes for which it is designed (e.g., open circuit, grounded circuit, power outage, etc.). 
(Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1(d)) 
Sec. 7.1-38. - Maintenance and testing. 
(a)  All systems shall be under the supervision of qualified persons. Those persons shall cause proper tests and inspections to be made at prescribed intervals. 
(b)  The owner shall provide for proper maintenance of the system. A maintenance agreement with specialists may be used in lieu of developing staff specialists. 
(Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1(e)) 
Sec. 7.1-39. - Permit required; annual application, fee. 
(a)  Application. The vendor whose equipment is installed in the New London Communications Center shall make annual applications for permits by June first to the fire marshal. 
(b)  Fees. The fee for each individual circuit terminating in the Communications Center shall be thirty-six dollars ($36.00) and shall not be prorated. July first shall be the anniversary date for all such permits. Such permit issued on July first shall expire one (1) year after said issuance. Applications for renewals of permits shall be processed in the same manner as applications for the initial permit. The fee for renewal of such a permit shall be thirty-six dollars ($36.00) for each successive one-year period. 
(Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1(h))

Chapter 9 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and structural appurtenances, Ch. 6; fire limits designated, § 6-9; false fire alarms, § 14-17; fire department, Ch. 15, Art. II; fires in public parks, § 16-51. 
State Law reference- Appointment of fire marshal required, § 29-45, Gen. Stats. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Inspections of premises by fire department. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to inspect or cause to be inspected by fire department officers or members, as often as may be necessary, but not less than twice a year in outlying districts and four (4) times a year within the fire limits, all buildings, premises and public thoroughfares, except the interiors of private dwellings, for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire or any violations of the provisions or intent of any ordinance of the city affecting fire hazard. 
(Ord. of 10-9-16, § 1) 
Sec. 9-2. - Order to remedy dangerous conditions. 
    Whenever any officer or member shall find in any building, or upon any premises or other place, combustible or explosive matter or dangerous accumulation of rubbish or unnecessary accumulation of waste paper, boxes, shavings or any other highly inflammable materials especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger property, or shall find obstructions to or on fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors or windows, liable to interfere with the operations of the fire department, or egress of occupants in case of fire, he shall order the same to be removed or remedied and such order shall forthwith be complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or buildings, subject to appeal within forty-eight (48) hours, to the chief executive officer, who shall within ten (10) days review such order and file his decision thereon, and unless the order is revoked or modified it shall remain in full force and be obeyed by such owner or occupant. 
(Ord. of 10-9-16, § 2; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 9-3. - Duty to comply with order. 
    Any owner or occupant failing to comply with the order provided for herein within ten (10) days after said appeal shall have been determined, or, if no appeal is taken, then within ten (10) days after the service of the said order, shall be liable to a penalty as hereinafter stated. 
(Ord. of 10-9-16, § 3) 
Sec. 9-4. - Service of order. 
    The service of the order provided for herein shall be made upon the occupant of the premises to whom it is directed by either delivering a true copy of same to such occupant personally or by delivering the same to and leaving it with any person in charge of the premises, or in case no such person is found upon the premises, by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on the door to the entrance to said premises. Whenever it may be necessary to serve such an order upon the owner of premises, such order may be served either by delivering to and leaving with the said person a true copy of the said order, or, if such owner is absent from the jurisdiction of the officer making the order, by mailing such copy to the owner's last known post office address. 
(Ord. of 10-9-16, § 4) 
Sec. 9-5. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person or persons, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter or any of its sections, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, forfeit and pay a fine to the treasury of the City of New London, of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each offense, and not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for every day thereafter so long as the said violation exists. 
(Ord. of 10-9-16, § 5) 
Sec. 9-6. - Outdoor fires-Permit required. 
    No person shall, without written permission of the chief of the fire department of the city or of the fire marshal, kindle or cause to be kindled any outdoor fire within the limits of the city, except that such permission shall not be required for the kindling of a fire in a covered metal container with no opening larger in dimensions than one inch by two (2) inches or in a fireplace constructed of incombustible material and provided with a flue screen. 
(Ord. of 2-7-55, § 1) 
Sec. 9-7. - Same-Application; issuance. 
    Written application for such permission shall be made to the fire marshal or to the chief of the fire department, who shall issue a permit stating when and where such fire may be kindled if, having regard to weather conditions, the materials to be ignited, the location and the supervision of the fire, he deems that the public safety will not be endangered. 
(Ord. of 2-7-55, § 2) 
Sec. 9-8. - Penalty for violation of section 9-6 or 9-7. 
    Any person violating the provisions of section 9-6 or 9-7 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. of 2-7-55, § 3) 
Sec. 9-9. - Private fire hydrants; maintenance and standards. 
(a)  Definition. All hydrants not owned by the City of New London shall be deemed private fire hydrants, whether or not they are supplied water by the city water supply or water from another source. 
(b)  Maintenance. It shall be the responsibility of the owner to maintain each hydrant in order to ensure proper performance. A written record of all maintenance work performed shall be mailed to the fire marshal. Where maintenance has been neglected or if the private hydrant's performance is impaired, the fire marshal may order the owner to make appropriate repairs at the owner's expense. All maintenance shall include proper service, flushing, draining, lubrication and inspection according to the manufacturer's requirements. All work performed shall be done by a contractor qualified to perform the required services. Included in maintenance shall be the keeping of the hydrant free from all obstructions or vegetation for a minimum of five (5) feet in all directions. 
(c)  Minimum standards. All private fire hydrants installed or replaced shall meet the minimum standards of the city as established by the city engineer. The hydrant(s) shall be painted "fire engine red" with a reflective white paint on top. Where special conditions exist, modification of the above standard may be granted by the city engineer. 
(Ord. of 8-3-87, § 1) 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as Ord. No. 08-03-87-1, § 1, adopted Aug. 3, 1987, did not specify manner of codification, such provisions have been designated by the editor as § 9-9. 
Cross reference- Unlawful acts concerning fire hydrants, §§ 14-13, 14-14, 14-20; water charges for private fire service, §§ 21-31, 21-33. 
Sec. 9-10. - Open burning prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Open burning is the kindling of an outdoor fire to burn any material but shall not include barbecues or fireplaces using wood, charcoal or gaseous fuels for the cooking of food for human consumption. 
    Open burning official is a person appointed by the city manager and certified by the state fire commissioner as in conformance with Connecticut General Statutes § 22a-174(f). 
(b)  The outdoor burning of any material, hereinafter referred to as open burning, shall be prohibited. 
(c)  The open burning of brush on residential property conducted by the resident of the property or the agent of the resident is allowed provided a permit is obtained from the open burning official. 
(d)  An open burning permit may be obtained from and issued by the open burning official in accordance with the Connecticut General Statutes and the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection regulations and guidelines. See Connecticut General Statutes § 22a-174(f). 
(e)  Any person wishing to obtain an open burning permit shall complete an application in a form satisfactory to the open burning official. If an open burning permit is issued, a copy of the permit shall be forwarded to the health department and the police department. Any such permit may impose restrictions and limitation so as not to create a nuisance or fire hazard. 
(f)  All permitted open burning must be conducted in accordance with Section 22a-174-17 of the Regulations of Connecticut State Agencies, as amended. 
(g)  Anyone that conducts open burning without an open burning permit or violates any conditions of an open burning permit shall be fined ninety dollars ($90.00), enforceable by citation, and the fire shall be extinguished by the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 10-02-00-8) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-02-00-8 did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 9-10 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 9-11. - Fire department authorized to bill and charge for services. 
(a)  The city fire department shall be authorized to bill and charge for any of the following services: 
(1)  Fire suppression with documented property loss in any building or vehicle of any type; 
(2)  Rescue services: 
a.  Involving the use of any special equipment; or 
b.  Having a duration of longer than one hour; 
(3)  Response to any call involving hazardous materials: 
a.  Involving the use of any special equipment; or 
b.  Having a duration of longer than one hour; 
(4)  Service calls: 
a.  With documented property loss in any building; 
b.  Involving the use of any special equipment; or 
c.  Having a duration of longer than one hour. 
(b)  On or before January 1st of each year, the fire chief shall establish and publish a schedule of rates for each of the services listed in subsection (a). The fire chief shall post a copy of said schedule at the fire department headquarters and shall provide a copy to the city manager's office by January 1 st each year. In addition, the fire chief shall also establish and/or revise billing and collection policies as needed to collect such funds and handle any uninsured or underinsured service recipients. 
(Ord. No. 08-09-04-24) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-09-04-24 did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 9-11 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 9-12. - Retail sale or distribution of novelty lighters. 
(a)  Novelty lighters-Prohibitions; inapplicability. The retail sale, offer of retail sale, gift or distribution of any novelty lighter within the territorial jurisdiction of the city is prohibited. This prohibition is inapplicable to: 
(1)  Novelty lighters which are only being actively transported through the city; or 
(2)  Novelty lighters located in a warehouse or distribution center closed to the public for purposes of retail sales. 
(b)  Novelty lighter-Definition. "Novelty lighter" means a lighter which is especially attractive to children due to a toy-like design or other features, such as buttons or devices that initiate visual effects, flashing lights, or musical sounds that might encourage a child to use the lighter and any lighters that resemble guns or other weapons 
(c)  Exceptions. The term novelty lighter excludes: 
(1)  Any lighter manufactured prior to 1980; and 
(2)  Any lighter which lacks fuel or a device necessary to produce combustion or a flame. 
(d)  Enforcement. The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the fire marshal, any police officer, any code enforcement officer, and any other city official authorized to enforce any provision of this Code. 
(e)  Violation-Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this chapter is guilty of an infraction in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 12-03-08-7, 12-3-08) 
Sec. 9-13. - Loading of fireworks onto barges and/or floating platforms-Permit required. 
(a)  No person shall conduct any operations involving the loading of fireworks onto barges and/or floating platforms within the city without first obtaining a permit for such operation from the office of the fire marshal for the city. 
(b)  Said permit shall specify: 
(1)  The date(s) and hour(s) of operation for the loading of tubes, racks and other equipment associated with firework displays on any barges and/or floating platforms; 
(2)  The date(s) and hour(s) of operation for the loading of fireworks on any barges and/or floating platforms; 
(3)  The date(s) and hour(s) of operation for the unloading of any tubes, racks, and other equipment associated with firework displays from any barges and/or floating platforms; and 
(4)  The date(s) and hour(s) of operation for the unloading of any fireworks from any barges and/or floating platforms. 
(c)  A copy of said permit shall be carried by the licensed shooter of the firework display at all times and a copy of said permit shall be given to the captain in charge of transporting any barges and/or floating platforms loaded with fireworks. 
(d)  Unless specifically stated on the permit or during an emergency requiring the cancellation of the fireworks display, fireworks shall not be loaded and unloaded the hours from sunset to sunrise. 
(e)  A non-refundable fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be paid at the time that an application is filed for said permit. 
(f)  Any violation of the conditions of any permit issued by the office of the fire marshal for the city shall subject the permittee to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for reach violation and be cause for said permit to be revoked. Any permit that is revoked for any violation shall not be reissued until a full and complete inspection is conducted by the office of the fire marshal for the city, or his designee, to ensure that said barge and/or floating platform fully comply with the issued permit. 
(g)  The city may impose a fee to recover the costs of providing any inspection and protection services as may be required by any state or federal statute. Said fee shall be stated in writing and shall be the responsibility of the permittee and/or the sponsor of the firework display. The city shall develop a schedule of fees or appropriate guidelines to establish fees. 
(h)  A permit from the office of state fire marshal pursuant to Connecticut General Statute § 29-357 shall be required by any person applying for a permit from the office of the fire marshal for the city and all regulations established pursuant to Connecticut General Statute § 29-357 shall be fully compiled with by the permittee. 
(i)  It shall be the sole responsibility of the permittee and/or the sponsor of the firework display to pay for the cost of inspection services and fire watch services that are required pursuant to all regulations established pursuant to Connecticut General Statute § 29-357. 
(j)  Any violation of Connecticut General Statute § 29-357 and/or any regulations established pursuant to said statute shall be reported to the office of state fire marshal as required. 
(k)  All Code of Federal Regulations and United States Coast Guard Regulations shall be compiled with in full by any permittee and sponsor of the firework display. 
(l)  A United States Coast Guard permit shall be carried by the licensed shooter of the firework display at all times. 
(Ord. No. 09-23-02-8, § 1) 
Sec. 9-14. - Fee schedule for fire department fire prevention division services. 
    The city fire department shall be authorized to bill and charge for any of the following services: 
(1)  Requests for permits and registrations required by the Connecticut Flammable & Combustible Liquid Code, the Connecticut Liquefied Petroleum Gas & Liquefied Natural Gas Code, and the Code for Storage, Transportation and Use of Explosives and Blasting Agents:
