(3)  Plan review, permit issuance, and inspection for sale and/or use of any sparklers, fireworks or pyrotechnics. The businesses that must comply with this section shall include, but not be limited to, any business with a seasonal store display for the sale of fireworks, including storefronts, any facility that may legally sell fireworks, and any location that intends to have pyrotechnics displays, whether indoors or outdoors. The applicant shall submit a complete inventory list of product(s) and site plans for initial review. Fee: One hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00). 
(4)  Any fire department incident report, fire marshal report or file information. Fee: Two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) for the first page plus one dollar ($1.00) for each additional page. 
(5)  Digital photographs printed on regular paper. Fee: Three dollars ($3.00) per page. 
(6)  General research. Fee: The hourly rate of the individual performing the research plus the current city surcharge as said surcharge is established from time to time by the city. 
(Ord. No. 11-05-07-1, § 1) 
Secs. 9-15-9-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OIL BURNERS 

Sec. 9-20. - Scope. 
    This article shall apply to any and all installations, and to the maintenance of oil burners in stoves and ranges or similar devices, and the storage and handling of kerosene oil or oil known to the trade as stove oil in connection therewith, within the city. 
(Ord. of 11-21-32, § 1) 
Sec. 9-21. - Licensing of installers. 
    No person shall install or cause to be installed, or service, or engage in the business of installing any apparatus covered under this article, unless he shall have obtained a license to do so. Any person desiring a license to install or service oil burners to be used in stoves, ranges or similar devices shall file written application, on a form to be furnished by the fire marshal, with the fire marshal and shall report for examination as to his knowledge of range oil burner installation and his fitness and skill in connection with such installation, at such time within one week after the filing of the application as may be fixed by the fire marshal. After the examination of such applicant the fire marshal shall endorse on the application his approval or disapproval of the application and shall present the application to the council, which may grant or refuse the license to the applicant. Such application shall state the name and address, or place of business of the applicant and be accompanied with a fee of two dollars ($2.00), for the use of the city, which fee shall be returned to the applicant if a license is not granted. 
(Ord. of 11-21-32, § 2) 
Sec. 9-22. - Permit for installations. 
    No person shall maintain in any building any oil heating or cooking apparatus in a stove or range or similar device unless he shall first obtain from the fire marshal a written permit authorizing the installation and maintenance of the apparatus. Application for such permit shall be made in writing to the fire marshal upon a form furnished by him for this purpose. Such application shall contain the name of the applicant and the address of the premises where it is proposed to locate the oil heating or cooking apparatus, and the name of the licensed person who is to make such installation, and contain a further agreement on the part of the applicant to comply with all the conditions of this article, and be accompanied with a fee of fifty (50) cents for the use of the city. The fire marshal shall inspect the application and agreement and if the same conforms to the provisions of this article, shall grant the permit. 
(Ord. of 11-21-32, § 3) 
Sec. 9-23. - Revocation of permits and licenses. 
(a)  Whenever the fire marshal shall have reason to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises, inflammable conditions, dangerous to the safety of such building or premises, he shall investigate such condition, and if the same is found by him to be caused by the improper installation or maintenance of an oil heating or cooking apparatus, or the improper storage of oil used in connection therewith, he may revoke the permit for such installation or maintenance by sending a written notice of such revocation to the holder of the permit by mail at his last known address. 
(b)  Whenever the fire marshal shall have knowledge that any licensed installer of oil burners has become incompetent or that by his negligence or improper workmanship such licensee has caused to exist conditions dangerous to the safety of buildings or premises in which the licensee has installed or is installing, or repairing or servicing oil heating or cooking apparatus, the fire marshal may temporarily suspend the license of such person and notify the council of the city. The council shall thereupon notify the licensee that it is proposed to permanently revoke his license and shall hold a hearing in the matter, at which time the licensee shall have the right to appear and be heard. At the conclusion of the hearing the council may take such action in connection with the license as it may deem proper. 
(Ord. of 11-21-32, § 6) 
Sec. 9-24. - Appeal of fire marshal decisions on permits. 
    Any person claiming to be aggrieved by the action of the fire marshal, relative to the issuance or revocation of any permit as herein provided, may appeal from such action to the council. 
(Ord. of 11-21-72, § 7) 
Sec. 9-25. - Storage containers. 
    No person shall keep or store kerosene oil or stove oil in any building, for use in stoves or ranges in connection with fuel oil heating or cooking, except in tight tanks of a capacity not to exceed fifty-five gallons, to be constructed of galvanized steel, basic open hearth steel, or wrought iron, of not less than sixteen (16) gauge, U. S. Standard, in thickness, except that tanks or containers not exceeding six (6) gallons in capacity may be used for such keeping and storage when substantially constructed. Storage tanks in excess of six (6) gallons capacity shall be equipped with either a suction pump or a self closing faucet to be approved by the fire marshal. No storage of kerosene or stove oil as specified, in excess of six (6) gallons for each heating or cooking unit shall be made above the first floor of any building. In no case shall the storage of stove oil in containers as above specified exceed fifty-five (55) gallons in any single-family dwelling and two hundred seventy-five (275) gallons in any multiple family dwelling or tenement house. 
(Ord. of 11-21-32, § 4) 
Sec. 9-26. - Inflammable vapor and warning devices prohibited. 
    No oil shall be used in any fuel oil heating or cooking apparatus which emits an inflammable vapor below one hundred (100) degrees Fahrenheit, to be ascertained by any standard closed cup tester, and no benzine or gasoline shall be used as a priming or warming device in connection with any fuel oil burner. 
(Ord. of 11-21-32, § 5) 
Sec. 9-27. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article or fail to comply therewith, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. of 11-21-72, § 8) 
Secs. 9-28-9-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GAS APPLIANCES 

Sec. 9-39. - Gas water heaters. 
(a)  All gas water heaters hereafter installed in any building shall be connected to a chimney, of the kind provided for by section 26 of the "Ordinance Relative to the Construction and Equipment of Buildings and Prevention From Fire and Other Damages," or to a masonry chimney which, in the opinion of the inspector of buildings, is adequate and safe therefor, by a metal flue pipe, the free flue area of which shall be not less than the area of the vent connection of the appliance connected thereto and served thereby. No person shall install hereafter any gas water heater in any closet or bathroom. The inspector of buildings shall give to any applicant a written permit for the installation of any gas water heater when the same is to be installed in accordance with this article and no gas water heater shall be installed until such permit has been obtained. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 5-4-31, §§ 1, 2) 
Secs. 9-40-9-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OIL HEATING APPARATUS 

Sec. 9-51. - Defined. 
    For the purpose of this article, oil heating apparatus shall mean any device for burning certain oils hereinafter described, as a substitute for other fuels, in steam, hot water or hot air heaters located in the cellar or basement of buildings, for the sole purpose of furnishing warmth within the buildings. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 1) 
Sec. 9-52. - Permit required for installation. 
    No person shall hereafter install or cause to be installed in any building any oil heating apparatus unless there shall be first obtained from the fire marshal a written permit authorizing the installation of the apparatus. Application blanks may be secured at the office of the fire marshal. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 2) 
Sec. 9-53. - Amount of oil requiring compliance with article. 
    No person shall hereafter keep, store or use in any building in connection with oil heating apparatus installed in accordance with the terms of this article oil in any amount in excess of ten (10) gallons thereof, except in accordance with this article, nor unless a permit has been obtained from the fire marshal. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 3) 
Sec. 9-54. - Inflammable vapor prohibited. 
    No oil shall be used in any oil heating apparatus which emits an inflammable vapor below one hundred (100) degrees Fahrenheit to be ascertained by any standard closed cup tester. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 4) 
Sec. 9-55. - Licensing for keeping or selling of oil. 
    No person shall manufacture, use in manufacture, keep on sale or storage, or sell within the limits of this city any oil as above described unless licensed to do so by the council of the city after a thorough investigation made by the fire marshal of the premises in which the oil is to be stored or kept and certified on his part that all requirements of the city ordinances have been faithfully complied with, and that in his opinion the location of such place of storage will be such as not to imperil the safety of the public or adjoining property. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 5) 
Sec. 9-56. - Construction specifications for oil storage tanks. 
(a)  Oil for use in connection with oil heating apparatus shall be stored in tight tanks conforming to American Petroleum Institute (API) standards, American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) standards, and shall bear the label of an independent testing laboratory such as Under-writers' Laboratory (UL) or Illinois Testing Laboratory (ITL). 
(b)  Tanks for systems under pressure shall be designed for four (4) times the maximum working pressure, and tested to twice the maximum working pressure. 
(c)  Underground steel tanks shall be thoroughly coated on the outside with tar, asphaltum, or other suitable rust-resisting material, dependent upon the condition of the soil in which they are placed. Where soil conditions contain corrosive substances, appropriate special protection shall be provided. Where soil conditions require, cathodic protection shall be provided. 
(d)  Inside or aboveground steel tanks, including auxiliary tanks, shall be coated with good quality, rust-resisting paint. Tanks installed on the ground or closer than six (6) inches to the lowest floor of a building shall be coated on the bottom with tar, asphaltum, or other suitable rust-resisting material. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 6; Ord. of 3-6-78, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-78, § 1) 
State Law reference- Ord. of 3-6-78, § 1, repealed former § 9-56, which provided construction specifications for oil storage tanks; another Ord. of 3-6-78, § 1, amended the Code by adding new construction specifications for oil storage tanks. 
Sec. 9-57. - Location of oil storage tanks. 
    Tanks containing oil for the purpose of oil heating apparatus shall be located as follows: 
(1)  Tanks having capacity of not more than two hundred and seventy-five (275) gallons may be placed in the cellar or basement of any building above the level of the cellar floor without any fireproof covering, but shall be placed not less than seven (7) feet from any open fire or flame. 
(2)  Tanks having capacity from two hundred and seventy-five (275) gallons to one thousand (1,000) gallons may be placed in the cellar or basement of any building above the level of the cellar floor, if completely enclosed by not less than twelve (12) inches in thickness of cement, concrete or some similarly substantial fire-proof material and not less than six (6) inches in thickness of sand, or such tanks may be placed not less than two (2) feet below the level of the cellar floor provided that the floor immediately above the tank shall be of reinforced concrete at least four (4) inches in thickness or some other type of construction of equivalent strength and fire resistance extending at least one foot beyond the outline of the tank in all directions and provided with ample means of support independent of any tank, or such tanks may be located underground outside of buildings provided that they are placed so that the top of the tank shall be not less than two (2) feet below the surface of the ground. 
(3)  Tanks having capacity of more than one thousand (1,000) gallons may be located inside of any building provided they are placed so that the top of the tank shall be not less than two (2) feet below the surface of the cellar floor, and provided that, the floor immediately above the tanks shall be of reinforced concrete at least nine (9) inches in thickness, or some other type of construction of equivalent strength and fire resistance, extending at least one foot beyond the outline of tanks in all directions, and provided with ample means of support independent of any tank, or such tanks may be located underground, outside of any building provided that they are placed so that the top of the tank shall be not less than two (2) feet below the surface of the ground. Oil shall be drawn from such tanks, whether located inside or outside of buildings, by means of a pump with suction pipe draughting through the top of the tank. If possible, storage tanks shall be located outside, underground, with top of tank below the level of the burner. Where conditions are such that top of tank is above the burner, adequate provisions to prevent siphoning shall be provided. For small installations where pipe lines are one inch or less, provisions which will break the siphon at time of fire, such as an air inlet held closed with fusible metal located at top of bend, are permitted. Weighted foot valves; enlarged pipe section on discharge side of siphon; or air inlets at top bends controlled by pump pressure, are provisions which are permitted in any size piping, depending upon the elevation of the tank, and upon specific approval of the fire marshal. 
(4)  In frame buildings, the gross capacity of inside aboveground tanks shall not exceed one thousand (1,000) gallons. In frame and ordinary buildings, the gross capacity of inside underground tanks shall not exceed five thousand (5,000) gallons. In fire-resistive buildings the gross capacity of inside underground tanks shall not exceed ten thousand (10,000) gallons. However, in ordinary buildings, other than frame and in fire-resistive buildings if tanks are located in a fire-resistive room, cut off vertically and horizontally in an approved manner from other floors of the main building, the gross capacity of tanks shall not exceed twenty thousand (20,000) gallons, with an individual tank capacity not exceeding ten thousand (10,000) gallons, provided the insulating sand specified in subsection (2) shall be increased to twelve (12) inches on sides and eighteen (18) inches on top. 
(5)  The gross capacity of outside underground tanks located as provided in subsection (3) shall not exceed twenty thousand (20,000) gallons. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, §§ 7, 9) 
Sec. 9-58. - Special equipment required for tanks in certain locations. 
(a)  All tanks for use in connection with oil heating systems shall if possible, be located below the level of the burner. Where conditions are such that top of tank is above the burner an antisiphoning valve or weighted foot valve shall be installed to prevent siphoning or gravity flow in case of damage to piping. 
(b)  All tanks for use in connection with oil heating systems except as otherwise herein provided shall not be located above the lowest story, cellar or basement of the building. Storage tanks so located within a building shall be provided with a fusible link shut off valve located in the oil supply pipe as near the oil storage tank as possible. Such fusible link shall be located at the cellar level immediately in front of the heater and such fusible link shall be so attached to shut off valve as to automatically close such shut off valve at a temperature at least one hundred sixty (160) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(c)  If oil storage tank is located in the ground outside the walls of the building above the level of the burner there shall be installed in the oil supply pipe from such oil tank as close to the inner wall of the building as possible the same type of fusible link shut off valve. 
(d)  In addition a similar automatic shut off valve shall be placed in the oil supply pipe as near the burner as possible. Where burners are provided with an approved automatic shut off device as an integral part of the machine the additional automatic shut off valve in the oil supply pipe may be omitted. 
(e)  Control valves of approved type shall be provided near each burner and also close to the tank in pipe lines to burner. Remote control of the flow of oil to the burner should be provided for use in emergency by means of a switch in the motor supply circuit for electrically driven equipment or a quick closing valve placed in the oil supply pipe line so arranged as to be operated from a safe location, preferable outside the building. The point of control should be clearly marked with an indicating sign. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 10) 
Sec. 9-59. - Oil tank filler and vent requirements. 
    All tanks for the purpose of oil heating apparatus shall have a filler pipe extending from the tank to a point outside the building near the grade of the surrounding land convenient for filling tank, and which shall be kept properly capped and locked when not in use. They shall also have a vent pipe not less than one inch in diameter extending from the tank to the outside air, terminating in a gooseneck pointed downward, six (6) feet or more from the surface of the ground, the opening to which shall be kept covered with thirty (30) mesh non-corrodible wire screen. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 8) 
Sec. 9-60. - Auxiliary supply tanks. 
(a)  Auxiliary supply tanks may be of the gravity or pressure type if suitable automatic safeguards to prevent abnormal discharge of oil at the burner are provided. 
(b)  If located within a building, a gravity tank shall not be within seven (7) feet or pressure tank within ten (10) feet, measured horizontally from any fire or flame. 
(c)  A gravity or pressure tank shall be substantially and rigidly installed on incombustible supports in such a manner as to insure protection against mechanical injury. 
(d)  Tanks for systems under pressure shall be designed for four (4) times the maximum pressure and be tested and proven tight at twice the maximum working measure; maximum working pressure shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds; tanks shall be provided with a reliable pressure gauge and an automatic relief valve piped to discharge outside of the building. 
(e)  Gauging device or test wells, the breaking of which would permit the escape of oil or vapor within the building, shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 11) 
Sec. 9-61. - Chimneys; dampers. 
(a)  No oil heating apparatus shall be connected with any chimney unless the chimney is so constructed as to maintain a strong natural draught, constant at all times. 
(b)  Dampers which may entirely close the chimney uptake are prohibited. Damper area should be carefully determined in each case but in no case shall it be greater than eighty (80) per cent of the internal cross area of the uptake. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 12) 
Sec. 9-62. - Certain explosible gases prohibited. 
    The use of acetylene or any other gas possessing a wider range of explosibility in admixture with air than coal gas, water gas or oil gas is prohibited for use in a gas pilot light or an oil heating system. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 13) 
Sec. 9-63. - Pipe specifications. 
    All pipes used in oil heating installations shall be of standard full weight brass, iron or steel, with suitable brass or malleable iron or steel fittings. No rubber nor other packings, and no flanges, shall be used. If unions are used, at least one face must be of brass, with close fitting conical joints. Litharge and glycerin, shellac or other suitable material shall be used on pipe joints; the piping to run under cellar floor wherever possible and be protected from injury. 
(Ord. of 2-23-26, § 14) 
Sec. 9-64. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former section 9-64, which pertained to hand fire extinguishers and sand pail required, and derived from an ordinance of February 23, 1926, § 15, has been deleted in its entirety at the direction of the city. 
Secs. 9-65-9-80. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former §§ 9-65-9-69, which pertained to the installation of oil furnaces, and derived from an ordinance of February 23, 1926, §§ 16-20, and an ordinance of March 6, 1978, have been deleted at the direction of the city. 
ARTICLE V. - GASOLINE AND OTHER INFLAMMABLE FLUIDS 

Sec. 9-81. - Definition. 
    Whenever the word "gasoline" is mentioned in this article it shall be understood as including the substances known as naphtha, benzole, benzine, gasoline and any fluid that will give forth inflammable vapor at a temperature of less than one hundred (100) degrees Fahrenheit to be ascertained by the application of the Tagliabue, AbelPensky, or Pensky-Martens Methods of testing. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 1) 
Sec. 9-82. - License required for manufacture, sale, storage or transporting; fees. 
(a)  No person shall manufacture, use in manufacture, refine, keep for sale or storage, or sell, within the limits of this city, any gasoline or other volatile inflammable fluid as above described in quantity exceeding five (5) gallons, unless licensed to do so by the council of the city after a thorough investigation made by the fire marshal of the premises in which the gasoline or other volatile inflammable fluid is to be stored or kept, and a certificate on his part that all requirements of the city ordinances have been faithfully complied with, and that in his opinion the location of such place of storage will be such as not to imperil the safety of the public or adjoining property. 
(b)  No person shall transport for sale or delivery on the streets within this city, any of the products covered by this article or any oil commonly called range oil or fuel oil, in tank cars, tank wagons or any other vehicle wherein the same may be contained, without obtaining a license to use such vehicle for such purpose from the council. Before any license to use a vehicle for the foregoing purposes is granted, the vehicle shall be inspected by the fire marshal for the purpose of ascertaining if it conforms to the provisions of this article. In order to be licensed for the foregoing purposes, each such vehicle shall be equipped with a proper tank constructed of not thinner than No. 12 U. S. Standard gauge galvanized steel or 3/16 of an inch black steel, which tank shall be securely fastened to the chassis of said vehicle. The faucets used for draining said tank shall be guarded by a heavy metallic guard rail and said truck shall be equipped with a fire extinguisher containing a liquid suitable for extinguishing oil fires, and said fire extinguisher to be of not less than one (1) quart capacity. 
(c)  Applicants for licenses issued under the provisions of this part of this ordinance shall pay annual fees as follows: To store in aboveground storage plants gasoline in quantities not exceeding sixteen thousand five hundred (16,500) gallons, twenty-five dollars ($25.00); to store in aboveground storage plants gasoline in quantities of sixteen thousand five hundred (16,500) gallons, but not exceeding thirty-three thousand (33,000) gallons, fifty dollars ($50.00); to store in aboveground storage plants gasoline in quantities in excess of thirty-three thousand (33,000) gallons, but not exceeding ninety-nine thousand (99,000) gallons, one hundred dollars ($100.00); to store in aboveground storage plants gasoline in quantities in excess of ninety-nine thousand (99,000) gallons, but not exceeding one hundred and ninety-eight thousand (198,000) gallons, one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00); to store in aboveground storage plant gasoline in quantities in excess of one hundred and ninety-eight thousand (198,000) gallons, two hundred dollars ($200.00); for each tank wagon used for transportation of gasoline in highways of the city, five dollars ($5.00); for each underground tank, not exceeding one thousand sixty-five (1,065) gallons in capacity, fifteen dollars ($15.00); for each underground tank in excess of one thousand sixty-five (1,065) gallons in capacity and not exceeding two thousand (2,000) gallons in capacity, thirty dollars ($30.00); for each underground tank in excess of two thousand (2,000) gallons and not exceeding three thousand (3,000) gallons in capacity, forty-five dollars ($45.00); for each underground tank in excess of three thousand (3,000) gallons and not exceeding four thousand (4,000) gallons in capacity, sixty dollars ($60.00); for each underground tank in excess of four thousand (4,000) gallons and not exceeding five thousand (5,000) gallons in capacity, seventy-five dollars ($75.00); for each underground tank in excess of five thousand (5,000) gallons and not exceeding six thousand (6,000) gallons in capacity, ninety dollars ($90.00); and for each underground tank in excess of six thousand (6,000) gallons and not exceeding ten thousand (10,000) gallons in capacity, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(d)  Limited licenses for the storage and sale of gasoline for a period of not to exceed six (6) months from the date of issue of the license, may be granted by the council upon the recommendation of the fire marshal. The license fee in each such case shall be one-half of the annual fee prescribed herein for a similar kind of storage plant. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, §§ 2, 3, 32; Ord. of 3-6-78, § 1; Ord. of 7-19-82, § 1) 
Sec. 9-83. - Licensing of pumps and tanks. 
(a)  No person shall place or maintain any pump, tank or other similar apparatus to be used in connection with the sale or distribution of gasoline, in any highway in the city without a license therefor as provided herein. 
(b)  No license shall hereafter be granted for the maintenance of any highway pump within the fire limits as described in the building code; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to revoke the licenses already given, nor to prevent the re-licensing for existing pumps and tanks and similar apparatus within the fire limits. 
(c)  The fire marshal subject to the approval of the council may issue licenses to suitable persons to place and maintain at suitable places in the highways of the city, suitable pumps, tanks or other similar apparatus to be used in connection with the sale or distribution of gasoline. Every such license shall be in writing and shall specify the person licensed and the place where such pump, tank or other apparatus may be placed or maintained, and shall be signed by the fire marshal and continue in force for the period of one year from the date of issue, unless sooner revoked by the fire marshal for any proper cause. 
(d)  No such license shall be issued, however, until there shall have been paid into the treasury of the city therefor a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each pump, nor until the licensee shall have furnished a bond in the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to the city with at least one good and sufficient surety to the satisfaction of the fire marshal, conditioned that such licensee shall indemnify and save the city harmless from all actions, damages, costs and expenses to which it may be subjected in consequence of any such pump, tank or other apparatus being placed or maintained in such highway under such license. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 2, §§ 1-4) 
Sec. 9-84. - Delivery to licensees only. 
    No person shall sell or deliver or cause to be sold or delivered within the limits of this city gasoline in larger quantity than five (5) gallons to any person who is required by this article to secure a license and has failed to do so; nor shall any person sell or deliver, or cause to be sold or delivered, to any person, gasoline in excess of the maximum amount such person is authorized to have by the license issued to him. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 5) 
Sec. 9-85. - Approved containers required. 
    No gasoline or other inflammable volatile fluid in quantity exceeding five (5) gallons shall be stored except in safety containers or tanks approved by the fire marshal. No such fluid shall be stored by any person in larger quantity than the maximum amount authorized by the license issued to him under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 4) 
Sec. 9-86. - Portable wheel tanks. 
    No portable wheel tank for the handling of gasoline inside buildings shall exceed sixty (60) gallons capacity, such tank must be of iron or steel, three-sixteenths inch thick, with all openings at top and screened with thirty (30) by thirty (30) mesh or equivalent brass wire screen. The wheels of such tank must be rubber-tired and the tank so hung as not to be tipped over in ordinary usage. The gasoline must be drawn from the tank by means of a tight-fitting pump. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 10) 
Sec. 9-87. - Tank construction specifications. 
(a)  Gasoline shall be stored in tight tanks conforming to American Petroleum Institute (API) standards, American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) standards, and shall bear the label of an independent testing laboratory such as Underwriters' Laboratory (UL) or Illinois Testing Laboratory (ITL). 
(b)  Underground steel tanks shall be thoroughly coated on the outside with tar, asphaltum, or other suitable rust-resisting material, dependent upon the conditions of the soil in which they are placed. Where soil conditions contain corrosive substances, appropriate special protection shall be provided. Where soil conditions require, cathodic protection shall be provided. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, §§ 20-23; Ord. of 3-6-78, § 1; Ord. of 3-6-78, § 2) 
Editor's note- Ord. of 3-6-78, § 1, repealed former § 9-87 pertaining to gasoline tank construction specifications; another Ord. of 3-6-78, § 2, amended the Code by adding new gasoline tank construction specifications. 
Sec. 9-88. - Accessories required for tanks. 
(a)  Each underground gasoline storage tank shall be provided with a filling pipe, a draught pipe, and a vent pipe, and shall have a gauge pipe, the opening to which shall be protected to the satisfaction of the fire marshal. 
(b)  When a gasoline tank is located under a building the filling pipe and the vent pipe must run to the outside of such building. The vent pipe shall be of galvanized wrought iron not less than one inch in diameter and shall run from the top of the tank and shall terminate not less than twelve feet above the surface of the ground, and not less than ten feet measured horizontally and vertically from any window or other opening in any adjacent building. It shall terminate with a double gooseneck opening downward, which opening shall be protected by a brass wire screen not coarser than thirty (30) by thirty (30) mesh or equivalent. 
(c)  Gasoline or other volatile inflammable fluid shall be drawn from the tank by means of a suction pump which shall have a tight shut-off valve. The pump or drawing off device shall not be located on a floor above the ground floor of a garage or other building and must be in a well ventilated portion thereof. There shall not be a return waster pipe to the tank unless the same is approved by the fire marshal. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, §§ 24-26) 
Sec. 9-89. - Installation of gasoline storage tanks. 
(a)  The location of all tanks must be approved by the fire marshal; all outside tanks aboveground, except portable tanks, must be electrically grounded. Tanks more than one foot above the ground must have foundation and supports of noncombustible materials, except wooden cushings, and no combustible material shall be permitted under or within ten (10) feet of any aboveground storage tank. 
(b)  Installation shall conform to the latest edition of National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Code 30. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 12; Ord. of 3-6-78, § 3) 
Sec. 9-90. - Outside storage tanks required; exceptions. 
    Except as otherwise permitted in this article the storage of gasoline shall be outside buildings in underground tanks or above-ground tanks; except that the storage in tanks aboveground and outside buildings is prohibited within the fire limits of this city as fixed by the building code; however, that for existing tanks within such limits which are properly safe-guarded and do not introduce a distinct hazard to other property a permit shall be granted. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 11) 
Sec. 9-91. - Underground tanks inside buildings. 
(a)  If impracticable to locate a gasoline storage tank outside of a building, it may be placed underground inside the building, but the top of the tank shall be located at least three (3) feet below the basement floor level, and the entire tank shall be encased in concrete to the satisfaction of the fire marshal, so as to be absolutely leak proof. 
(b)  No gasoline tank having a total capacity in excess of five hundred and sixty (560) gallons shall hereafter be installed underground inside a building unless such building is of fire proof construction as fixed by the building code. 
(c)  Where two (2) or more gasoline tanks are installed underground inside of a building they shall not be located less than three (3) feet apart. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, §§ 17-19) 
Sec. 9-92. - Capacity of underground tanks limited. 
    No underground gasoline tank shall have a capacity in excess of ten thousand (10,000) gallons. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 29; Ord. of 3-6-78, § 4) 
Sec. 9-93. - Inspection of underground tanks prior to covering. 
    No underground gasoline tank shall be covered from sight until all connections have been made thereto and have been inspected and approved by the fire marshal. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 30) 
Sec. 9-94. - Foundation of tanks; covering of underground tanks. 
    All tanks shall be placed upon a substantial foundation to the approval of the fire marshal. All underground tanks shall be satisfactorily covered with asphalt or other suitable rust-resisting material. The top of such underground tank shall be at least three (3) feet below the surface of the ground and below the level of the lowest pipe in any building to be supplied. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 15) 
Sec. 9-95. - Embankments to surround aboveground tanks. 
    All outside storage tanks located aboveground containing gasoline, kerosene or crude petroleum, shall be surrounded by an embankment or wall. Such embankment or wall shall have a storage capacity of not less than that of the tank surrounded, except that in case of gasoline the storage capacity made by the embankment shall equal one and one-half times the capacity of the tank surrounded. Such embankment shall be of earth or of cement and shall at all times be kept in good the capacity of the tank surrounded. Such embankment shall be, in the opinion of the fire marshal, insufficient or out of repair, or if any tank used for the storage of gasoline, whether above or below ground, becomes dangerous or out of repair, the fire marshal shall suspend the license given for the use of the tank and shall cause the owner thereof to draw off all gasoline therein contained in a safe manner and report his action to the council. Failure to obey such order of the fire marshal shall be a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 13) 
Sec. 9-96. - Inspection of tanks; abatement of dangerous conditions. 
    The fire marshal shall from time to time inspect all tanks and the premises on which the same are located and shall report to council all dangerous conditions that may come to his attention. If in his opinion dangerous conditions exist, it shall be his duty to order the discontinuance of the use of such tanks until the matter has been heard by the council, and in such circumstances it shall be the duty of the owner of such tank to draw off the gasoline therein contained and care for same in safe manner. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 14) 
Sec. 9-97. - Protection of tanks from leakage; location near cellar walls. 
    A tank containing gasoline, if located within ten (10) feet of a building having a cellar or basement and not placed below the level of the floor of such cellar or basement shall be protected from leakage in such manner as shall be directed by the fire marshal and to his satisfaction. No tank having a capacity of one hundred and ten (110) gallons shall be located less than ten (10) feet from a cellar wall; no tank having a capacity of five hundred (500) gallons shall be located less than fifteen (15) feet from a cellar wall; and no tank having a capacity from one thousand (1000) to two thousand (2000) gallons shall be located less than twenty (20) feet from a cellar wall, provided, however, that if each underground tank be coated on the outside with asphalt or other rust-resisting material, and be embedded in and surrounded by at least twelve (12) inches of Portland Cement, concrete composed of two (2) parts of cement, three (3) parts of sand, and five (5) parts of stone, it may, with the approval of the fire marshal, be located within the prohibited distances of cellar walls mentioned in this section. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 16) 
Sec. 9-98. - Storage in dwellings limited. 
    No person shall store, keep or have in possession for any purpose or use in any building, the whole or any part of which is used as a dwelling within this city, more than one gallon of gasoline. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 6) 
Sec. 9-99. - Use of fire retardants. 
    Where gasoline is kept, used or handled, dry sand, ashes, chemical extinguishers or other fire retardants shall be provided in such quantities and with such pails, scoops, and other fire appliances as may be directed by the fire marshal. Sawdust shall not be used to absorb oils or grease in any building where gasoline is used. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 7) 
Sec. 9-100. - Keeping near fire prohibited. 
    The handling or storing of gasoline within dangerous proximity to open flame or fire is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 8) 
Sec. 9-101. - Smoking prohibited where vapors are present. 
    In all rooms or parts of buildings which contain gasoline in open containers or in which the vapors from gasoline are present, or in which gasoline is used in manufacturing process, the lighting of matches and smoking are prohibited. Suitable signs lettered "Smoking prohibited by order of the fire marshal," shall be displayed. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 9) 
Sec. 9-102. - Motor vehicle to be turned off when tank is being filled. 
    When the gasoline tank of any motor vehicle is being filled the engine of such vehicle shall be stopped, and shall not be restarted until the tank has been properly closed. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 27) 
Sec. 9-103. - Exception to article provisions for tanks on automobiles. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit the keeping of gasoline in tanks affixed to automobiles. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 28) 
Sec. 9-104. - Appeal of fire marshal decisions. 
    Any person aggrieved by any action of the fire marshal under this article may appeal to the council not later than the second meeting thereof after action of the fire marshal complained of, and the action of the council in approving or disapproving the action of the fire marshal shall be final and binding. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 1, § 31) 
Sec. 9-105. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) payable to the treasurer. 
(Ord. of 4-7-24, Pt. 3, § 1) 
Chapter 10 - FOOD AND FOOD PRODUCTS[1] 
Footnotes:

Sec. 10-1. - Prohibited sales.

(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 26) 
Sec. 10-2. - Fees for inspection of meat and meat products. 
    Fees for the inspection of meat and meat products in slaughterhouses are hereby established as follows: 
For all beef animals ..... $1.00 
For calves, or sheep ..... 0.25 
(Ord. of 11-17-58, § 1) 
Sec. 10-3. - Collection of fees for meat inspections. 
    The fees provided for herein shall be collected by the meat inspector at the time of slaughter when inspected and shall be paid to the city treasurer for the use of the city. 
(Ord. of 11-17-58, § 2)

ARTICLE II. - MILK AND MILK PRODUCTS 

Sec. 10-15. - Definition. 
    The term, "milk", as used in this article is defined to include milk, skim milk, buttermilk, cream or flavored milk. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 10) 
Sec. 10-16. - Scope of license requirements. 
    No person shall, by himself, or by his servant or agent, or as the servant or agent, of any other person, firm or corporation, have in his possession with the intent to sell, offer or expose for sale or exchange, or sell, or deliver for sale or consumption within the city any milk without first obtaining a license therefor from the director of health. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 1) 
Sec. 10-17. - Issuance of license; duration, renewal. 
    Said license may be issued by the director of health on application in writing giving such information as the director of health may require and on payment of a fee in accordance with the schedule provided in this article, to be paid into the treasury of the city. No such license shall be issued unless the applicant exhibit to the director of health his receipt for registration for the current period issued by the State Department of Agriculture. The applicant shall also produce a statement from said commissioner that he is properly equipped for the purpose of preparing milk to be delivered for consumption in New London at wholesale or retail. Said license shall be effective until the first day of April next ensuing unless sooner revoked and may be renewed for one year on application and payment of said fee as aforesaid. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 2) 
Sec. 10-18. - Identification required on vehicles of licensees. 
    Any person, who by himself, or by his agent or servant, or as agent or servant of any other person, firm or corporation, has obtained a license according to the above provisions shall display, on both sides of all vehicles used by him for the transportation of milk within the limits of the city the number of his license in figures, the height of which shall be at least four (4) inches. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 7) 
Sec. 10-19. - Suspension, revocation of license. 
    Any license issued according to the provisions of this article may be suspended or revoked by the director of health if he finds the milk sold or delivered by said licensee or possessed by him with the intent to sell or deliver the same is injurious or likely to be injurious to public health, or if any order of the director of health regarding the care, sale or handling of milk is not obeyed within a reasonable time after the issuance thereof, or in case of the violation of any of the above provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 8) 
Sec. 10-20. - Effect of suspension or revocation of license. 
    Any person whose license has been suspended or revoked by order of the director of health shall not sell or deliver any milk in the city until said license has been renewed by the health officer or until the order of the health officer has been set aside by some proper court. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 9) 
Sec. 10-21. - License fees. 
    The schedule of license fees to be paid annually shall be as follows: 
Wholesale dairies, milk depots, processing plants, or other distributors whether wholesale or retail ..... $25.00 
Retail outlets ..... 5.00 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 12) 
Sec. 10-22. - Processing standards for milk and cream. 
    No milk or cream shall be sold or delivered to any individual, family, grocery store, market or shop within the city unless the same shall have been processed at the source of production or at a dairy or milk depot in standard milk containers and tightly capped nor shall any milk, or cream be sold or delivered to any milk depot, creamery, hotel, restaurant, bakery or for manufacturing purposes within said city unless the same shall have been so processed or unless in bulk and in quantities of not less than ten (10) quarts and in containers of a capacity not larger than is sufficient to hold contents. No cork or wooden plug shall be used as a stopper or cover for any bottle or milk container used for the sale or delivery of milk within the said city. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 3) 
Sec. 10-23. - Duty to furnish information pertaining to suppliers. 
    No person shall by himself, or by his servant or agent, or as the servant or agent of any other person, firm or corporation sell or offer for sale or deliver any milk which he has procured from any source other than his own dairy, or from a person licensed under the provisions of this article without filing with the director of health a written statement, within twenty-four (24) hours, of the name and post office address of each person, firm or corporation from whom and the localities from which, such supply has been or is to be obtained. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 4) 
Sec. 10-24. - Prohibited sales. 
    No person shall by himself, or by his servant or agent, or as the servant or agent of any other person, firm or corporation, sell or offer to sell or offer for sale within the limits of the city, any milk that contains any foreign matter, preservative, coloring matter or thickening or any milk drawn from cows fed on food or water forbidden by the director of health or any milk which has been condemned or the sale of which has been forbidden by order of the director of health, or any milk drawn from cows known to be diseased or from cows known to have sore or ulcered udders, or from cows within fifteen (15) days before and five (5) days after parturition. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 5) 
Sec. 10-25. - Milk to be from cows free of tuberculosis. 
    No milk or cream shall be sold in the city, unless the same has been produced from cows free from tuberculosis as determined by the official tuberculin test and retest made in a manner and by a veterinarian approved by the Commissioner of Agriculture. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 6) 
Sec. 10-26. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the foregoing provisions shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00), payable to the treasury of the city. 
(Ord. of 11-16-64, § 11) 
Secs. 10-27-10-37. - Reserved.
