Chapter 11 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Food and food products, Ch. 10; hotels, lodging and rooming houses and convalescent homes, Ch. 12; housing and commercial structures codes, Ch. 13; water and sewers, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Municipal health authorities, § 19-74 et seq., Gen. Stats.; child day-care council, § 19-43c, Gen. Stats. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 11-1, 11-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former sections 11-1 and 11-2, which pertained to the department of health and the duties of the director of welfare, respectively, and derived from an ordinance of May 3, 1926, an ordinance of December 29, 1960, and an ordinance of April 17, 1961, § 1, have been deleted at the direction of the city. 
Sec. 11-3. - Keeping offensive substances. 
(a)  No person shall keep, after notice to remove the same by the city manager, or any health or police officer upon his premises or elsewhere, any offal, putrid substances, decaying animal or vegetative matter, or any unwholesome or offensive substance or liquid. 
(b)  Grease rendering vats shall be maintained in a manner so as not to create a nuisance. Fifty-five gallon drums used for grease rendering are not approved unless a rim locking or sealing device is used to prevent a loose fitting lid, prevent overflow from rainwater, spillage, and to allow the barrel to be relocated or moved without the hazard of grease spillage. 
(c)  No person shall keep or permit the accumulation of stagnant water, stagnant rainwater gutters, or stagnant swimming pools likely to afford breeding places for mosquitoes within the city. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 29; Ord. No. 07-07-03-17) 
Sec. 11-4. - Depositing refuse on private property. 
(a)  No person shall, except in accordance with the regulations of the council, throw, place or drop or permit to be brought from premises occupied by him, to be thrown, placed or dropped within or about any dumpster on property not occupied by him or upon any street, sidewalk or public place, any waste, rubbish, offal, filthy matter, shells, ashes, dirty water or any other refuse whatever. 
(b)  Every person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section and the preceding section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall pay a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, §§ 27, 35; Ord. of 12-29-60; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. of 9-18-89, § 1) 
Sec. 11-5. - Depositing refuse in public places, waterways. 
(a)  No bottles, paper, glass, tins or other rubbish or refuse shall be left in or thrown on any of the beaches, parks or streets in this city, except in receptacles provided by the city for such purpose or at such places specially designated by public authority by a sign marked "public dump"; nor shall any such rubbish or refuse be thrown or cast into any rivers, coves or other waterways or watercourses in the city. Nothing herein shall be construed to interfere in any way with the dumping of rubbish by littoral or riparian owners in the lawful reclamation, filling or use of the waters adjacent to their own land. The eating of picnic meals, or the eating or drinking of any articles of food or beverages, or the bringing of glass bottles or containers, crockery, glass or glassware or any part thereof, or any tin or metal container or metallic substance on the sand beach or bathing area at any of the public beaches in the city is prohibited. Bottles and cans must be separated from other rubbish and placed in special containers designated for glass bottles, jars and tin cans. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) payable to the treasury of the city. 
(Ord. of 8-27-23, §§ 1, 5; Ord. of 7-2-65, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Cross reference- Boats, docks and waterways, Ch. 5; streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Secs. 11-6-11-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former section 11-6, which pertained to prohibited interments and derived from an ordinance of August 1, 1881, §§ 1, 2, an ordinance of June 5, 1989, and an ordinance of November 27, 2005, has been deleted at the direction of the city. 
ARTICLE II. - REMOVAL OF NIGHT SOIL, CONTENTS OF CESSPOOLS, ETC. 

Sec. 11-18. - Permit required. 
    No person shall remove night soil, or the contents of a cesspool, or a septic tank unless he has obtained a permit from the Ledge Light Health District. 
(Ord. of 4-1-57, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Sec. 11-19. - Application for, issuance of permit. 
    Application, in writing, for permit referred to in the foregoing section, shall be made to the Ledge Light Health District. 
Sec. 11-20. - Delivery for treatment and disposal. 
    All night soil or contents of a cesspool or septic tank, shall be delivered to the night soil receptor station at the sewage treatment plant for treatment and disposal. 
Secs. 11-21-11-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former sections 11-21 and 11-22, which pertained to applications for treatment and disposal, violations and penalties, respectively, and derived from an ordinance of April 1, 1957, §§ 4, 6, an ordinance of January 3, 1961, an ordinance of March 2, 1964, § 1, and an ordinance of June 5, 1989, have been deleted at the direction of the city. 
ARTICLE III. - GARBAGE, RUBBISH AND TRASH COLLECTION; COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- An Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1, repealed former Arts. III and IV of Ch. 11, §§ 11-34-11-38 and §§ 11-50-11-59, respectively. Former Art. III pertained to collection of garbage, rubbish and trash and was derived from Ord. of 11-18-40, §§ 1-4; Ord. of 11-16-42; Ord. of 11-15-54; Ord. of 12-4-61, § 1; Ord. of 11-18-63, § 1; Ord. of 2-17-69, § 1; Ord. of 9-15-69, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-73; § 1; and Ord. of 6-28-76, § 1. Former Art. IV pertained to collection and disposal of solid waste and was derived from Ord. of 6-21-71, §§ 1, 2(a)-(d), 3, 4, 5(a)-(e), 6; Ord. of 7-21-71, § 1; Ord. of 3-18-74, § 1; Ord. of 8-7-75, § 1; Ord. of 12-15-75, § 1; Ord. of 4-18-77, § 1; and Ord. of 5-16-77, § 1.  In lieu of said former provisions, another Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1, added a new Art. III, §§ 11-46-11-60 to Ch. 11. The editor has reserved §§ 11-34-11-45 as a portion of Art. II, and has reserved §§ 11-61-11-70 as Art. IV, for purposes of maintaining Code format. 
State Law reference- Authority, § 7-94(14), Gen. Stats.; littering, § 53-51a, Gen. Stats. 

Sec. 11-46. - Definitions. 
    Ashes are the residue of the combustion of any type of solid fuel such as wood, coal, coke, charcoal or like substances. 
    Building or construction wastes are materials resulting from the construction, alteration or repair of structures and consist of plaster, metal, brick, concrete, lathing, roofing, earth, structural members and like material. Such material will not be collected or disposed of by the city. 
    Bulky wastes shall include, but not be limited to old household furnishings such as stoves, refrigerators, stuffed chairs or couches, bedsprings and mattresses, etc. 
    Business proprietor shall be an individual who owns or operates a nonresidential property. 
    Combustible waste consists of those wastes having a low flash point or explosive potential such as rubber dust or shreds, paints, oils and other flammable liquids, etc. In any case of dispute, the ruling of the fire marshal shall be final. 
    Commercial property shall include all commercial or industrial facilities, condominiums and apartment buildings with more than six (6) dwelling units. 
    Commercial solid waste hauler means any person, company or agency who holds him/herself out to collect, haul transport or dispose of solid waste from residential, business, commercial and other establishments. 
    Contractor shall be an individual or company with a contractor's license who performs work of the trades upon his property or property of others. 
    Extraordinary commercial wastes are wastes of the above enumerated nature, in excess of that defined as ordinary commercial wastes. 
    Garbage is all waste animal, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetable matter produced from or resulting from the use and storage of food for human consumption and includes spoiled food and dead animals found within the city limits. 
    Industrial wastes are the refuse that accumulates in or upon the land used for manufacturing, industrial, wholesale and slaughtering purposes. Such materials will not be collected by the city. 
    Ordinary commercial wastes are the general and usual wastes that accumulate from operation of retail stores, restaurants, clubs or any commercial establishment for profit, schools, institutions and government buildings, but not exceeding ten (10) thirty (30) gallon barrels per collection day. 
    Ordinary noncommercial wastes are general and usual wastes that accumulate from operation of residential homes and small apartment structures including garbage, rubbish and recyclable materials, but not exceeding ten (10) thirty (30) gallon barrels per collection day. 
    Recyclable materials are those materials collected by the city for ultimate sale or reuse rather than disposal. These materials include paper products, glass and metals, leaves and oils as further defined below: 
(a)  Recyclable paper products include: 
(1)  Newsprint. All paper items received with an ordinary newspaper, including advertisement circulars, comics, and other supplements. 
(2)  Computer paper. Original printouts and copies, untreated and noncarbonized. 
(3)  Corrugated/Kraft. Boxes, cartons and similar constructed of corrugated Kraft paper or pasteboard; sheet Kraft paper or pasteboard; unwaxed only. 
(4)  White office paper. Used or discarded highgrade white paper included but not limited to paper utilized for file folders, tab cards, writing, typing, printing, computer printing and photo-copying, which is suitable for recycling and which has a minimum of contamination. Office paper generated by households is excluded. Voluntary recycling here is encouraged. 
(b)  Recyclable glass and metal products include: 
(1)  Glass. Unbroken glass containers of all sizes and color, as is, lightly rinsed of all food or product residue with lids removed. Neck rings and labels can remain on. 
(2)  Cans. Metal cans of all sizes, aluminum and steel or any combination thereof, as is, with product residue removed and without requiring the removal of labels. 
(3)  Aluminum products. Aluminum foil and products of thin sheet aluminum such as trays for packaged foods, as is, with minor product residue removed. 
(4)  White goods. White goods are those items of bulky waste constructed mostly of light metals such as appliances, lawn chairs, bicycles, etc., which have a potential resale value as bulk metal. The city does not collect white goods but does provide a disposal location at the city's landfill or a designated landfill. 
Recyclable glass and metal products do not include all ceramic, china, and plastic items, whether used as food containers, or not, plate glass and window glass, mirrors, aerosol cans of any type, paint cans, and heavy metal or glass objects. 
(c)  Recyclable oils include low volatility oils such as lubricating and fuel oils, and mineral based greases, but exclude high volatility items such as kerosene and gasoline. Recyclable oils may contain minor contamination from ordinary use but shall be free of excessive metal/particulate and acid contamination. 
(d)  Leaves. The term leaves means the foliage of trees. 
Leaf collection-Leaves will be collected on the regular day of refuse collection except during the fall when special leaf collection days may be designated. Leaves should be put in refuse containers or in biodegradable paper bags. Leaves will not be collected in plastic bags. No more than ten (10) bags of leaves will be collected at any one home at any one time. Bags of leaves will not exceed fifty (50) pounds each. 
    Resident shall be an individual who resides in a residence with a New London address. 
    Residential property means real estate containing one or more dwelling units but not more than six (6) and shall not include hospitals, motels or hotels, apartment buildings, nursing centers and condominiums. 
    Rubbish consists of wood, nonrecyclable paper, rags, excelsior, straw, leaves, grass, shrubbery trimmings, leather, crockery, scrap metal, auto parts, and other glass, ceramic, metallic or earthenware substances exclusive of those defined as combustible, and those defined as recyclable materials. 
    Semi-automated collection shall mean the collection of residential solid waste utilizing specialized containers and container tipper equipped collection equipment. 
    Tires are outer casings and inner tubes, and substantial parts thereof, exclusive of wheels or rims, from automobiles, trucks, buses, bicycles, tractors, trailers, etc. Rubber shavings, rubber dust and shredded parts of tires are excluded from this category of waste. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-84, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. No. 08-04-03-7, § 1) 
Sec. 11-47. - Preparation of wastes for collection; private haulers. 
(a)  Ordinary wastes (commercial and noncommercial), except rubbish and recyclable materials, shall be stored in watertight containers, total weight not to exceed fifty (50) pounds. Neither plastic nor cloth nor paper bags shall be used as containers for garbage, nor for rigid, heavy objects, nor for sharp objects which could cause failure of the bag by puncture or tear. 
(b)  Biodegradable paper bags may be used for the storage of leaves and grass; total weight of each bag not to exceed fifty (50) pounds. Baskets and other suitable open containers may also be used for such material subject to the same weight limitation. 
(c)  Tree trimmings and brush shall be tied in bundles of not over four (4) feet in length, capable of being handled by one (1) man. No loose material will be collected by the city. 
(d)  Recyclable materials shall be prepared for collection as follows: 
(1)  Newsprint shall be placed in tightly packed Kraft paper grocery bags or tied in bundles not exceeding fifty (50) pounds in weight. (During periods of heavy rain or snow, newsprint will not be set out for collection but will be held by the producer until the next collection day.) 
(2)  Computer paper and white office paper shall be placed in tightly packed Kraft paper grocery bags or tied in bundles not exceeding fifty (50) pounds in weight. (During periods of heavy rain or snow, computer paper will not be set out for collection but will be held by the producer until the next collection day.) 
(3)  Corrugated boxes and containers must be flattened, but need not be tied into bundles. (Sheet corrugated and pasteboard may be placed with flattened boxes and containers.) Flattened corrugated shall be placed under trash containers so that it will not blow about. Kraft paper shall be placed in tightly packed Kraft paper grocery bags or tied in bundles not exceeding fifty (50) pounds in weight. (During periods of heavy rain or snow, Kraft paper and flattened corrugated will not be set out for collection but will be held by the producer until the next collection day.) 
(4)  Glass, cans, and aluminum products shall be treated as a single product for collection. The mixture of glass, cans, and aluminum products, frequently called kitchen mix, shall be stored in recycling containers or standard refuse containers designated for recycling and easily identified as such by a label or with a large red dot. The container so marked shall only be used for recyclable materials and shall not be used for ordinary waste. A plastic or paper bag may not be used for ordinary waste. A plastic or paper bag may be used as a liner for the container, but nothing else except kitchen mix shall be placed in the container. 
(5)  Recyclable oils are not collected by the city. See section 11-52 for preparation and disposal instructions. 
(e)  No person shall dump solid waste into recyclable dumpsters nor shall they dump recyclables into a dumpster that is not designated for that particular recyclable material. Every person who shall violate the provisions of this subsection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall pay a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(f)  Collection of recyclables by private haulers. Private collectors shall collect required recyclable items from commercial establishments according to the city and state regulations and will deliver all recyclables to the designated recycling collection site (intermediate processing center, recycling center or paper collection site) or transfer station. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-6-81, § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83, § 2; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. of 9-18-89, § 1) 
Sec. 11-48. - Disposal of extraordinary commercial wastes. 
(a)  Extraordinary commercial wastes, the origin or source of which lies totally within the limits of the city, will not be collected by the city, but may be disposed of at the appropriate city facility by the producer at his own risk and upon the following terms and conditions, to wit: In consideration of the foregoing grant and the privileges herein specified, said producer of extraordinary commercial wastes shall, as a condition precedent, release the city from any right of action, claim or demand which may accrue to it/him by reason of the loss of any of its/his property made in, upon or about said premises of the city, and further agree for such consideration to indemnify said city and save it harmless from any claims, demands, damages, actions, costs and charges which the city may be subject to or which it may have to pay by reason of any injury to any person or property or loss of life or property suffered or sustained by any agent or employee of the extraordinary commercial waste producer while in, upon or about any part of said city premises, whether such loss arises from the negligence of the employees, agents or servants of the city or otherwise. 
(b)  Extraordinary commercial waste generated in part or in whole from outside the city may be disposed of at the city's solid waste transfer station by the producer subject to the above conditions and upon payment of a fee in accordance with section 11-54. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Sec. 11-49. - Disposal of building or construction wastes, ashes, rubbish and solid waste (bulky). 
(a)  The disposal of building or construction wastes through the New London transfer station is prohibited. The acceptance of such wastes at the Town of Waterford's bulky waste transfer station shall be subject to the ordinances, rules and regulations of the town. 
(b)  The New London solid waste transfer station shall be available to the following users: 
(1)  Residential property owners, tenants, landlords and business proprietors wishing to bring acceptable solid waste generated by them to the solid waste transfer station. 
(2)  Qualifying contractors wishing to bring acceptable solid waste generated within the city. 
(3)  All of the above wishing to bring recyclable items. 
(c)  All qualified residential property owners, tenants, landlords, business proprietors and contractors with bulky waste items which cannot be accepted at the New London Transfer Station will be granted permission to use the Waterford Transfer Station. Such items would be asphalt shingles, wallboard, CFC appliances, brush, logs, oversized furniture and building or demolition debris. All persons disposing of items in Waterford shall pay the prevailing rate as established by the Town of Waterford and shall comply with all rules and regulations established for their facility. 
(d)  No such waste originating in whole or in part from outside the limits of the city regardless of quantity, shall be disposed of at New London transfer station or at the Waterford bulky waste landfill. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79; § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83; § 3; Ord. of 9-4-84, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. No. 08-04-03-7, § 1) 
Sec. 11-50. - Disposal of tires. 
(a)  Tires must be removed from rims. Tires are recyclable and may be delivered to the transfer station for a disposal fee. 
(b)  Fees for the disposal of tires are as follows: 
(1)  Passenger tires, each ..... $2.00 
(2)  Truck tires, each ..... 5.00 
(3)  Equipment tires ..... 50.00 
(c)  Tires with wheels or rims attached will not be accepted for disposal under subsections (a) or (b) above. 
(d)  No load of tires originating in whole or in part from outside the limits of the city, regardless of quantity, shall be disposed of through any of the methods outlined above. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 7-7-80; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Sec. 11-51. - Disposal of industrial waste. 
    Industrial wastes shall be handled through city facilities to the maximum extent that such wastes can be safely and efficiently handled and to the extent that such wastes do not adversely affect the operation of city facilities, as determined by the director of health and the fire marshal. No quantity of industrial waste originating in whole or in part from outside the limits of the city shall be disposed of through any city solid waste facility. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Sec. 11-52. - Disposal of combustible waste. 
    Combustible waste disposal shall be totally a function of the producer with the city providing neither collection nor disposal except for recyclable oils. Recyclable oils may be brought by the producer to the waste oil tank at the public works garage for eventual disposal. No quantity of such products originating in whole or in part from outside the limits of the city shall be disposed of through this tank. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83, § 4; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Sec. 11-53. - Disposal of ordinary commercial waste, garbage, rubbish, and solid waste (nonbulky). 
(a)  Ordinary commercial and noncommercial waste, garbage, and small quantities of rubbish will be collected and disposed of by the city subject to restrictions and requirements set forth in sections 11-47 and 11-56 and herein. The city reserves the right to refuse to collect waste which has not been properly separated and prepared, particularly with respect to the separation and preparation of recyclable materials. Uncollected waste may be disposed of without fee at the transfer station if brought there by the producer. 
(b)  The city will not collect more than ten (10) barrels of garbage or their equivalent placed at the curb by any one establishment on any scheduled collection day. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit the disposal of combustible rubbish and garbage in the home or commercial establishment without the necessity of storage and collection. 
(d)  Household incinerators may be utilized if they produce no smoke or odors that are classed as nuisances or hazards, and if they comply with the quality control regulations of the State of Connecticut. 
(e)  Such waste, produced in whole or in part from outside the limits of the city, may be delivered only to the solid waste transfer station of the city. Such waste may be accepted subject to all rules and requirements set forth in section 11-47 as if it originated within the limits of the city, and shall be charged for in accordance with the fee schedule set forth in section 11-54. 
(f)  The grinding of food wastes into water-carried pulp, which is then transported to the household or commercial plumbing system and thence into the sanitary sewer system, is permissible. This applies to the disposal of fresh food wastes as produced in the home or commercial establishment, prior to its storage in any garbage can for collection. 
(g)  All materials delivered to the transfer station must have all recyclables separated from the rubbish. 
(h)  The use of wood burning stoves for the incineration of garbage and rubbish is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83, § 5; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. No. 07-07-03-17; Ord. No. 08-04-03-7, § 1) 
Sec. 11-54. - Fees. 
(a)  In addition to the fees established under sections 11-50 and 11-58(d), the following fees shall apply: 
(1)  Permit fees. 
Day permit, per day ..... $5.00 
Annual (resident, landlord, proprietor), per year ..... 25.00 
Annual (contractor), per year ..... 50.00 
(2)  Disposal fees. 
Car, pick-up and/or trailer, per load ..... 15.00 
10,000 GVW Dump Truck, per load ..... 25.00 
Commercial waste delivered to Preston ..... Tipping fee 
(3)  Resident fee waiver. city residents shall be granted an annual waiver of the disposal fee for four (4) car, pick-up or trailer loads of acceptable bulky waste generated from their residence. The year shall be consistent with the City fiscal year of July 1 to June 30. The City reserves the right to confirm residency and material origin. 
(b)  Separated recyclable materials shall be exempt from these fees. 
(c)  Fees for regular, established users of the solid waste transfer may be set up on a monthly billing basis at the convenience of the city. All other fees shall be paid at the time of dumping. Monthly fees shall be due and payable on the 1st of the month immediately following the month of dumping. Fees which remain unpaid more than thirty (30) days after the due date shall thereafter become delinquent and bear interest at the same rate and in the same manner as is provided for property taxes. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 12-17-79, § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83, § 6; Ord. of 6-4-84, § 1; Ord. of 6-16-86, § 1; Ord. of 10-6-86, § 1; Ord. of 5-16-88, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. No. 08-04-03-7, § 1) 
Sec. 11-55. - Confiscation of containers. 
    Containers not conforming to the requirements set forth by this article or which shall be deemed a sanitary or accident hazard may be confiscated by the city and disposed of. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Sec. 11-56. - Collection schedule. 
(a)  All residential establishments in the city shall receive one (1) collection per week by dividing the entire city into five (5) sectors and collecting one (1) sector each day, Monday through Friday, as scheduled on the map entitled "Department of Public Works, Schedule of Collections of Refuse and Garbage", dated July 20, 1971, on file in the office of the department of public works and utilities. 
(b)  All business and commercial establishments within commercial or industrial zones shall receive two (2) collections per week on Tuesdays and Fridays. 
(c)  Bulky waste shall be picked up curbside by appointment only. The director of public works shall designate who, within the department of public works, shall coordinate appointments for such bulky waste pickup. Fees for such curbside bulky waste pickup shall be established by the city council. Any resident or business proprietor scheduling an appointment for curbside bulky waste pickup shall be required to prepay any applicable fees. 
(d)  The city will not make any collections on the following holidays: 
New Year's Day 
Martin Luther King, Jr., Day 
Lincoln's Birthday 
Washington's Birthday 
Good Friday 
Memorial Day 
Independence Day 
Labor Day 
Columbus Day 
Veterans Day 
Thanksgiving 
Christmas Day 
(e)  In the event a holiday listed under subsection (d) falls on a collection day, the collection for such holiday shall be eliminated and collection made on the following day unless the holiday falls on a Friday when the collection shall be made on the day previous to normal collection. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 6-18-79, § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83, § 7; Ord. of 6-4-84, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. No. 08-04-03-7, § 1; Ord. No. 11-20-17-1, § 1) 
Sec. 11-57. - Location of containers. 
(a)  Garbage containers shall be kept clean, covered, and in such a place as not to constitute a nuisance or otherwise be objectionable to neighborhood properties. Garbage containers shall not be permanently positioned at the front of the waste producers' dwelling. Containers shall not be stored at the front side corner of a dwelling unless a screening device by the use of fencing or shrubbery is provided prevent the scattering of litter. If a screening devise is not used garbage containers shall be positioned for storage at the rear of the premises. Visibility of ordinary noncommercial wastes and garbage from the city streets or sidewalk shall be deemed unsightly to the public's view. 
(b)  All containers shall be placed on the sidewalk area abutting the property of the producer at the street curb or curbline by said producer on the morning of the day set forth under the collection schedule before 8:00 a.m. 
(c)  All containers shall be removed from the sidewalk by the owner after the solid waste has been collected, and before 8:00 p.m. of the collection day. 
(d)  All waste which has not been collected in accordance with section 11-53 shall be removed from the sidewalk area before 8:00 p.m. of the collection day. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83, § 8; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. No. 07-07-03-17) 
Sec. 11-58. - Private collections. 
(a)  Any citizen or business establishment may, at his option, elect to utilize the services of a private collector rather than city forces. When the amount of waste generated exceeds the provisions of section 11-53 of this article, such private collection must be utilized. 
(b)  Private parties, firms or corporations may be authorized by the director of public works to collect solid wastes at no cost to the city, providing that such collection is performed in accordance with the provisions of this article and produces no objectionable conditions in and on the streets of the city, and provided said waste is removed from places dispensing food in containers used for storage of same daily. Containers used for all such collection service shall be watertight and have tight-fitting covers. The covers on such containers must be kept closed at all times except when waste is actually being deposited into the container. 
(c)  Private collectors of bones and fat from markets and slaughterhouses shall be required to have the same license as private solid waste collectors. Said bones and fats shall be carried through the streets of the city in watertight containers which shall be clean inside and out and left odorless. These containers shall have tight-fitting covers. 
(d)  Private collectors shall, before engaging in such business, be licensed by the director of public works and shall conduct their work so as to ensure the safe and sanitary transportation of waste materials through the city. Before a license is issued by the director of public works, the applicant shall be required to pay the city treasurer a fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per year, or any part thereof, for each vehicle used in such service. Such licenses may be revoked or suspended by the director of public works or by the health officer at the time either of them finds that the manner of collection or disposal is not in conformity with the requirements of this article. Private collectors shall collect garbage only in such part of the city as may be designated in the license of the director of public works. 
(e)  The total number of such private collectors shall be limited by the director of public works to such a number as may be deemed by him to be most satisfactory and in the best interests of the city. 
(f)  Whenever the director of public works or director of health determines that there are reasonable grounds to revoke or suspend a license pursuant to any provision of this article, he shall give notice of such alleged violation to the licensee responsible therefor, as hereinafter provided. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Include a statement of the reason why the license is being revoked or suspended; and 
(3)  Be served upon the licensee or his agent, as the case may require; provided that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such licensee, or agent, if a copy thereof is sent by registered mail to his last known business address. 
(g)  Any licensee affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this article may request, and upon the payment of a ten dollar ($10.00) fee, payable to the treasurer of the city, shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the chief executive officer, or his designate; provided that such licensee shall file in the office of the chief executive officer a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the grounds thereof within ten (10) days after the day the notice was served. Upon receipt of such petition the chief executive officer shall set a time and place for such hearing and shall give the petitioner five (5) days' written notice thereof. At such hearing the petitioner shall be given the opportunity to be heard and to show why such license should not be revoked or suspended. The hearing shall be commenced not later than thirty (30) days after the day on which the petition was filed. 
(h)  Collection of recyclables by private haulers. Private collectors shall collect recyclable items from commercial establishments according to the city and state regulations and will deliver all recyclables to the designated recycling collection site (intermediate processing center, recycling center or paper collection site) or transfer station. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 3-1-82, § 1; Ord. of 3-21-83, § 9; Ord. of 5-5-86, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Sec. 11-59. - Private scavenging. 
    Private scavenging on the streets of the city is prohibited, except upon permit to be issued by the chief executive officer. Such permit may be revoked by the chief executive officer, if its practice is deemed by him unsatisfactory or not to be in the best interests of the city. No person, firm or corporation shall engage in private scavenging on, nor shall collect, remove or take any solid waste from, any municipal fill or dump area, so-called. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Sec. 11-60. - Violations and penalties. 
1.  Citations. 
A.  In accordance with the provisions of Connecticut General Statutes, Subsection 7-148 (c)(10)(A), in addition to other available methods of enforcement, the provisions of the City Code may be enforced by citation. 
B.  The officers and employees designated herein shall be authorized to issue citations for violations of the provisions of the City Code. 
The director of health, a city police officer, the building official, the chief sanitarian, the sanitarian II, the sanitarian I, the housing inspector, or other duly appointed agents of the chief executive officer. 
C.  Citations shall be issued only by designated citation officers and employees and only after the issuance of a written warning in the form of a notice of intent to cite. Said warning shall provide notice of the specific violation(s) to be corrected and shall explain the citation enforcement procedures which may be used if the alleged violations go uncorrected within the time provided for in the said notice. The warning notice may contain language providing specific actions to be taken to correct the alleged violation. 
D.  The warning may be hand delivered to the person in violation, mailed certified, return receipt requested, or posted in a conspicuous place, or in a conspicuous manner at or on the property where the alleged violation has occurred or where it is actually occurring. 
E.  Should a properly issued warning go unheeded and the alleged violation go uncorrected within the specified time stated in the warning, a citation may be issued to the violator by a citation officer. 
F.  Fines and penalties: 
(1)  Any person who violates an ordinance section listed under paragraph H. of this ordinance, after a proper warning notice of intent to cite has been provided, or who fails to comply with a warning by correcting the violation described therein, shall be fined fifty ($50.00) dollars. 
(2)  Any person who violates an ordinance section listed under paragraph H. of this ordinance within one year of being fined fifty ($50.00) dollars for the same shall be fined one hundred ($100.00) dollars. 
(3)  Each day on which a violation occurs or continues after time for correction in any citation has elapsed shall be considered a separate violation. 
(4)  Fines and penalties shall be made payable to the treasurer of the city and shall be deposited into the general fund. 
G.  Failure to Respond. Failure to respond to a notice of violation by paying the fine(s) or by requesting a hearing to contest liability is an infraction violation under Section 51-164p of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
H.  The following ordinances shall be subject to citation under this section: 
 Ordinance 03-02-92-1 Dog feces 
 Ordinance 07-21-99-1 Commercial/Industrial dumpsters and trash cans, and litter control (TLC) plans 
 Ordinance 12-03-96-1 Environmental requirements: Natural growth 
 Chapter 4 Sec. 4-3 Animals and Fowl 
 Sec. 6-10(e) Street Numbering on residential and commercial property 
 Sec. 9-6(a) Open burning prohibited: Bonfires 
 Sec. 11-3 Keeping of offensive substances 
 Sec. 11-4 Depositing refuse on private property 
 Sec. 11-5 Depositing refuse in public places, waterways 
 Sec. 11-47 Preparation of wastes for collection 
 Sec. 11-53 Disposal of ordinary commercial waste, garbage, rubbish, and solid waste (non-bulky) 
 Sec. 11-57 Location of containers 
 Sec. 11-87 Prohibited emissions 
 Sec. 11-112 Litter disposal generally 
 Sec. 11-113 Accumulation of litter on private property or adjacent sidewalks 
 Sec. 11-114 Maintenance of dumpster premises by private garbage disposal contractors. 
 Sec. 11-115 Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevents scattering 
 Sec. 14-27 Removal of graffiti required; enforcement, penalty 
Property maintenance (BOCA) codes: 
 PM 303-8 Motor Vehicles. 
 PM 303.1 Sanitation 
 PM-303.2 Grading and drainage 
 PM-303.4 Weeds 
 PM-303.5 Rodent Harborages 
 PM-306.1 to 306.3.2 Rubbish and Garbage 
2.  Hearing procedure for citations. 
A.  Pursuant to Connecticut General Statutes 7-152c, as those sections may be amended or recodified from time to time, the city manager shall appoint one (1) or more individuals who shall serve as hearing officers to conduct hearings into the violation of ordinances, rules, or regulations of the city. Said hearing officers shall be electors of the city. No member of the city police department, member of the corporation counsel's office or any employee empowered or authorized to issue citations for the violation of an ordinance of the city shall be permitted to serve as a hearing officer pursuant to this subsection. 
B.  Within twelve (12) months from the expiration of the final period for the uncontested payment of any fine, penalty, cost or fee levied as the result of a violation of any provision of the City Code or any other regulation adopted as subject to citation by the city council, notice shall be sent to the violator, the owner of the property which is the subject of the violation in question, or such other person as may be appropriate. Such notice shall inform the owner and/or other person: 
(1)  That a warning for the cited violation had been properly issued; 
(2)  Of the allegations of the citation and the amount of the fines, penalties, costs or fees due; 
(3)  Of the right to contest liability at a hearing before a citation hearing officer by delivering, in person or by mail, written notice of such intent within ten (10) days of the date thereof; 
(4)  That a failure to request such hearing will result in the prompt entry of an assessment and judgment against the person or persons named in the citation; 
(5)  That such judgment may issue without further notice; and 
(6)  That failure to respond to this notice of violation shall result in the issuance of an infraction citation to the violator. 
C.  Admission of liability. 
(1)  If any person who is sent notice pursuant to subsection B of this section wishes to admit liability for any alleged violation, that person may, without requesting a hearing, pay the full amount of the fines, penalties, costs or fees admitted to in person or by mail at the address specified in the notice. Such payment shall be inadmissible in any proceedings, civil or criminal, to establish the conduct of such person or other person making the payment. 
(2)  Any person who does not respond to the notice provided in subsection B of this section by paying the fines and penalties set forth therein or by requesting a hearing within ten (10) days thereafter may be issued an infraction citation by a duly authorized individual based upon the original municipal ordinance violation and said person shall be deemed to have admitted liability. The designated municipal official shall certify such person's failure to respond to the hearing officer. The hearing officer shall thereupon enter and assess the fines, penalties, costs, or fees provided for by the applicable ordinances. 
D.  Hearing procedure. 
(1)  Any person who requests a hearing pursuant to Subsection B of this section shall be given written notice of the date, time and place of the hearing. Hearings shall be during normal business hours. Such hearing shall be held not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days from the date of the mailing of the notice, provided that the hearing officer shall grant, upon good cause shown, any reasonable request by an interested party for postponement or continuance. The hearing officer may accept from any person contesting liability copies of police reports, investigation and citation reports and other official documents by mail and may determine thereby that the appearance of such person at a hearing is unnecessary. If the person or persons cited otherwise fail to appear, the hearing officer shall enter an assessment by default against them upon a finding of: 
(a)  Proper notice. 
(b)  Liability under the applicable provision of the ordinances. 
(2)  An original or certified copy of the initial notice of violation issued by the issuing official or police officer shall be filed and retained by the municipality and shall be deemed to be a business record and evidence of the facts contained therein. The presence of the issuing official or police officer shall be required at the hearing if any interested party so requests. 
(3)  A person wishing to contest liability shall appear at the hearing, unless excused from so doing by the hearing officer, and may present evidence. The defendant has the right to request the presence of the issuing citation officer. The issuing officer, corporation counsel or his designee may present evidence on behalf of the city but the presence of corporation council is not required. The hearing officer shall conduct the hearing in the order and form and with such methods of proof, as that officer deems fair and appropriate. The rules regarding the admissibility of evidence shall not be strictly applied, but all testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation. 
(4)  The hearing officer shall announce the decision at the end of the hearing. If the hearing officer determines that the person is not liable, the matter shall be dismissed and the determination entered in writing accordingly. If the hearing officer determines that the person is liable for the violation, the appropriate fines, penalties, costs or fees shall promptly be entered and assessed against such person as provided by the applicable ordinances. The hearing officer shall have the authority to modify the violation or reduce the penalty and/or fee assessable against any person if, in the hearing officer's discretion, such modification is warranted based upon the facts elicited during the hearing process. 
(5)  If any hearing officer has entered an assessment by default against any person with respect to any matter, no hearing officer shall reconsider that matter until the person against whom such assessment has been imposed has submitted a written request to open said assessment by default explaining the basis for the person's failure to appear at the scheduled hearing and paid a nonrefundable fee for said request in the amount of ten dollars ($10) to the city; and said request has been considered on its merits and granted by a hearing officer. The decision to grant or deny such a request shall rest in the sole discretion of the hearing officer. 
E.  If such assessment is not paid on the date of its entry, the hearing officer or the issuing citation officer shall send by first class mail, postage prepaid, a notice of the assessment to the person found liable and shall file, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than twelve (12) months after such mailing, a certified copy of the notice of assessment against such person in favor of the municipality with the clerk of a superior court facility designated by the chief court administrator within the boundaries of the judicial district of New London, together with such entry fee as may be required by the superior court. Notwithstanding any other provisions, the hearing officer's assessment, when so entered as a judgment, shall have the effect of a civil money judgment, and a levy of execution on such judgment may issue without further notice to such person. Said judgments may be referred to the city attorney for collection actions. 
F.  Should a civil money judgment and levy of execution on such judgment be sought and awarded, municipal officials and department heads, having regulatory cognizance and the authority to collect fees, issue licenses, and permits may deny applications and withhold said licenses and permits for unpaid judgments. Licenses and permits shall include business licenses, licenses in general, building, zoning, and special use permits, and certificates of occupancies, where required by city ordinance. Said licenses and permits shall not be suspended or revoked. Only the renewal or issuance may be withheld until such time as the civil money judgment is paid to the treasurer of the city. 
This provision of this section may be executed when the violation occurred on property where certificate of occupancies, business licenses, building permits, zoning permits, and special use permits are required by ordinance. 
G.  A person against whom an assessment has been entered pursuant to this section is entitled to judicial review by way of appeal. An appeal shall be instituted within thirty (30) days of the mailing of notice of such assessment by filing a petition to reopen assessment, together with such entry fee as may be required by the superior court, in the superior court for the geographical area 10, which shall entitle such person to a hearing in accordance with the rules of the judges of the superior court. 
H.  Conflict: All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this ordinance are hereby repealed. 
I.  Severability: If any provision of this ordinance shall be held invalid or unconstitutional its invalidity shall not effect any other provisions of this ordinance that can be given effect without the invalid provisions, and for this purpose the provisions of this ordinance are hereby declared to be severable. 
    Each violation of this article, except as specifically provided, shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00), or by imprisonment not exceeding thirty (30) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. of 1-16-79, § 1; Ord. of 12-7-82, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89; Ord. No. 07-07-03-17; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 11-61. - Dumping at other than landfill prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall dump solid waste of any form outside of the designated areas at the New London transfer station except in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and pay a fine to the treasury of the city of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. of 12-7-82, § 1; Ord. of 6-4-84, § 1; Ord. of 6-5-89) 
Secs. 11-62-11-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STORAGE, DISPOSAL OR USE OF OIL AND GAS DRILLING AND EXTRACTION WASTE 

Sec. 11-66. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meanings given here, unless otherwise clearly indicated by the context: 
    Application shall mean the physical act of placing or spreading natural gas waste or oil waste on any road or real property located within the City of New London. 
    Hydraulic fracturing shall mean the fracturing of underground rock formations, including shale and non-shale formations, by manmade fluid-driven techniques for the purpose of stimulating oil, natural gas, or other subsurface hydrocarbon production. 
    Natural gas extraction activities shall mean all geologic or geophysical activities related to the exploration for or extraction of natural gas, including, but not limited to, core and rotary drilling and hydraulic fracturing. 
    Natural gas waste shall mean: 
(1)  Any liquid or solid waste or its constituents that is generated as a result of natural gas extraction activities, which may consist of water, brine, chemicals, naturally occurring radioactive materials, heavy metals, or other contaminants; 
(2)  Leachate from solid wastes associated with natural gas extraction activities; 
(3)  Any waste that is generated as a result of or in association with the underground storage of natural gas; 
(4)  Any waste that is generated as a result of or in association with liquefied petroleum gas well storage operations; and 
(5)  Any products or byproducts resulting from the treatment, processing, or modification of any of the above wastes. 
    Oil extraction activities shall mean all geologic or geophysical activities related to the exploration for or extraction of oil, including, but not limited, to, core and rotary drilling and hydraulic fracturing. 
    Oil waste shall mean: 
(1)  Any liquid or solid waste or its constituents that is generated as a result of oil extraction activities, which may consist of water, brine, chemicals, naturally occurring radioactive materials, heavy metals, or other contaminants; 
(2)  Leachate from solid wastes associated with oil extraction activities; and 
(3)  Any products or byproducts resulting from the treatment, processing, or modification of any of the above wastes. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-17-1, § 1, 3-6-17) 
Sec. 11-67. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  The application of natural gas waste or oil waste, whether or not such waste has received beneficial use determination or other approval for use by DEEP (Department of Energy and Environmental Protection) or any other regulatory body, on any road or real property located within the city for any purpose is prohibited. 
(b)  The introduction of natural gas waste or oil waste into any wastewater treatment facility within or operated by the city is prohibited. 
(c)  The introduction of natural gas waste or oil waste into any solid waste management facility within or operated by the city is prohibited. 
(d)  The storage, disposal, sale, acquisition, transfer, handling, treatment, and/or processing of waste from natural gas or oil extraction is prohibited within the city. 
(e)  Nothing in this article shall be interpreted to ban the transportation of any product or by-product described herein on any roadway or real property within New London. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-17-1, § 1, 3-6-17) 
Sec. 11-68. - Provision to be included in bids and contracts related to the construction or maintenance of publicly owned and/or maintained roads or real property within the city. 
(a)  All bids and contracts related to the retention of services to construct or maintain any publicly owned and/or maintained road or real property within the city shall include a provision stating that no materials containing natural gas or oil waste shall be utilized in providing such a service. 
(b)  All bids and contracts related to the purchase or acquisition of materials to be used to construct or maintain any publicly owned and/or maintained road or real property within the city shall include a provision stating that no materials containing natural gas or oil waste shall be provided to the city. 
(c)  The following statement, which shall be a sworn statement under penalty of perjury, shall be included in all bids related to the purchase or acquisition of materials to be used to construct or maintain any publicly owned and or maintained road or real property within the city and all bids related to the retention of services to construct or maintain any publicly owned and/or maintained road or real property within the city: 
"We _______ hereby submit a bid for materials, equipment and/or labor for the City of New London. The bid is for bid documents titled _______. We hereby certify under penalty of perjury that no natural gas waste or oil waste will be used by the undersigned bidder or any contractor, sub-contractor, agent or vendor agent in connection with the bid; nor will the undersigned bidder or any sub-contractor, agent or vendor agent thereof apply any natural gas waste or oil waste to any road or real property within the City of New London as a result of the submittal of this bid if selected." 
(Ord. No. 03-06-17-1, § 1, 3-6-17) 
Sec. 11-69. - Penalties. 
    In response to a violation of this article, the city may require remediation of any damage done to any land, road, building, aquifer, well, watercourse, air quality or other asset, within the City of New London. The city may also impose fines in the amount of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) per violation per day for any violation of this article and any other remedies allowable under the law. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues after the time for correction of violation given in any order has elapsed shall be considered a separaate violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-06-17-1, §§ 1, 2A.,3-6-17) 
Sec. 11-70. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VIII. - LITTER CONTROL[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- An Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1, amended the Code by adding provisions designated Art. VIII of Ch. 11, §§ 11-110-11-118. 
Cross reference- Posting bills, advertisements without consent of owner, § 14-12. 

Sec. 11-110. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article shall be to provide an enforceable and effective set of rules to guide policy for the antilitter program, in order to reduce littering and maintain a healthy and beautiful environment. 
(Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-15-91) 
Sec. 11-111. - Definition. 
    The word "litter" shall mean any discarded, new, used or unconsumed substance or waste material, whether made of aluminum, glass, plastic, rubber, paper, or other natural or synthetic material, or any combination thereof, including, but not limited to, any bottle, jar or can, or any top, cap or detachable tab of any bottle, jar or can, any unlighted cigarette, cigar, match or any flaming or glowing material or any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, grass, clippings, or other lawn or garden waste, newspapers, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers or other packaging or construction material, abandoned automobiles, parts of automobiles, other motor vehicles, furniture, oil, any nauseous or offensive matter, any object likely to injure any person or create a traffic hazard or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature which is not deposited in the proper litter receptacle. 
(Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-15-91) 
Sec. 11-112. - Litter disposal generally. 
    No person shall throw, scatter, sweep, spill or place, or cause to be blown, scattered, spilled, thrown or placed, or otherwise dispose of any litter upon any public property or private property in this city now owned by him or in waters of this city, whether from a vehicle or otherwise, including, but not limited to, any public highway, public park, beach, forest land, recreational area, trailer park, highway, road, street or alley, except: 
(1)  When such property is designated by the city for the disposal of garbage and refuse and such person is authorized to use such property for such purpose; 
(2)  Into a litter receptacle in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried away or deposited by the elements upon any said private or public property or waters. 
(Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-15-91) 
Sec. 11-113. - Accumulations of litter on private property or adjacent sidewalks. 
    The owner, tenant and/or person in control of any private property shall at all times prevent litter from accumulation so as to become a nuisance and shall keep the sidewalk area to the street gutter line in front of this property free of litter; provided, however, it shall be unlawful to sweep litter into the street and leave it. This section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. Private receptacles shall be removed from the curb within twenty-four (24) hours after refuse collection. 
(Ord. of 10-1-79 § 1; Ord. of 4-15-91) 
Sec. 11-114. - Maintenance of dumpster premises by private garbage disposal contractors. 
    Private garbage disposal contractors shall clean up areas around their dumpsters each time the dumpster is emptied. Private garbage disposal contractors shall be solely responsible for maintaining the dumpsters on any public or private property in order to prevent garbage overflow and health hazards. In no event shall any dumpster, full of garbage be allowed to stand for more than ten (10) days without being completely emptied by the owners of said dumpster. 
(Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-15-91) 
Sec. 11-115. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. Covers shall be firmly in place on receptacles. Plastic bags shall be closed, but in no event shall they be considered to be substitutes for approved litter receptacles. 
(Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-15-91) 
Sec. 11-116. - Covering truck loads to prevent scattering, deposit on streets. 
    Truck loads shall be covered if a vehicle is loaded in such a way or with such material that parts of the load may be blown or deposited upon any street. 
(Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-15-91) 
Sec. 11-117. - Notice to remove litter from open private property. 
    The chief executive officer or his designee is hereby authorized and empowered to notify the owner of any open or vacant private property within the city or agent of such owner to properly dispose of all litter located on such owner's property and shall authorize the issuance of citations for violations of this section and other applicable sections of article III of this chapter and the Property Maintenance Code of the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-07-03-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-07-03-17, adopted July 7, 2003, amended § 11-117 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, § 11-117 pertained to notice to remove litter from private property, and derived from an ordinance adopted October 1, 1979; an ordinance adopted March 12, 1990, and an ordinance adopted April 15, 1991. 
Sec. 11-118. - Article violations, penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second and each additional offense. 
(b)  Each day on which a violation occurs or continues after the time for correction in any citation has elapsed shall be considered a separate violation of this article. 
(c)  If any provision of this article or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of any other part of this article that can be given affect without the invalid provisions or applications; and to this end, the provisions of this article and various applications thereof are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. of 10-1-79, § 1; Ord. of 4-15-91; Ord. No. 07-07-03-17) 
Chapter 12 - HOTELS, LODGING AND ROOMING HOUSES, CONVALESCENT HOMES, AND SOBER HOMES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1, amended chapter 12 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, chapter 12 pertained to hotels, lodging and rooming houses and convalescent homes, and derived from an ordinance adopted April 19, 1965, §§ 1-9, 12, 13, and an ordinance adopted October 20, 1969, § 1. 
Cross reference- Buildings and structural appurtenances, Ch. 6; businesses, trades and professions, Ch. 7; health and sanitation, Ch. 11. 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    Convalescent home shall mean a building used as a place for the lodging, care and treatment of five (5) or more persons suffering from abnormal physical conditions, requiring license by the state department of health as a "chronic and convalescent home". This shall include places used for the lodging and long-term care of the infirm and those receiving chronic or convalescent care, but shall not include such places as are defined under the term "hospital" which are equipped for general medical or surgical treatment and are used for short-term care, the lodging and care of one's immediate family within his private dwelling or buildings used for the housing of insane persons or those confined in state prisons, jails or other public penal institutions. 
    Hotel shall mean a building or portion of a building used as a place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for hire or other consideration, with or without board, for twenty-five (25) or more guests or employees of the management, or in which thirteen (13) or more sleeping rooms are maintained for such guests or employees. The term "hotel" shall include all clubs or other buildings which have similar sleeping accommodations, but shall not include apartment houses, hospitals, penal institutions or buildings housing the insane. Members of the management's family shall not be considered as guests or employees. 
    Lodging house as used in this chapter is defined to mean any house patronized by roving, or transient, persons to whom beds or rooms are furnished, and as contain accommodations for not fewer than five (5) persons, or tourist camps wherein houses or cottages are rented by the day. 
    Rooming house as used in this chapter is defined to mean any building which is used in whole or in part as a place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for hire or other considerations, with or without board, for not more than twenty-four (24) guests, or employees of the management, or in which twelve (12) or less sleeping rooms are maintained for such guests or employees. The term shall include all tourists homes advertised as such, which have accommodations as aforesaid but shall not include private dwellings which accommodate not more than two (2) habitational guests or employees, or an apartment house, or hospital, as defined in the State Fire Safety Code. Members of the management's family shall not be considered as guests or employees. 
    Sober house as used in this chapter is defined to mean a dwelling unit occupied by more than five (5) unrelated persons, all of whom are in recovery from a substance use disorder or chemical dependency and considered handicapped under the Federal Fair Housing Act Amendments of 1988. It provides a non-institutional residential environment in which the residents choose to live together and willingly subject themselves to written rules and conditions, including the prohibition of alcohol and drug use (except for prescription medications obtained and used under medical supervision), intended to encourage, support, and sustain their recovery. The residents of a sober house are similar to a family unit, and share kitchen and bathroom facilities and all other common areas of the dwelling unit and property. Sober living homes do not provide on-site formal substance use disorder treatment services. The residents of a sober living home are considered tenants pursuant to Connecticut General Statute Section 47a-1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-2. - Scope of license requirements. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall conduct, operate, or maintain a hotel, lodging or rooming house, or sober house in the city unless licensed so to do under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-3. - Application for license. 
    Application for license to conduct, operate or maintain a hotel, lodging or rooming house, sober house or convalescent home shall be made to the building inspector of the city on forms furnished by him and in said application the applicant shall state his name, address, location of the hotel, rooming or lodging house, or convalescent home, he intends to conduct, operate or maintain, the number of sleeping accommodations contained in said hotel, lodging or rooming house or convalescent home, and such other pertinent information as the building inspector may require and at the time of filing said application shall pay to the treasurer of the city a license fee in accordance with the schedule provided in this chapter, which fee shall be the license fee for one (1) year, or part thereof, which fee shall be returned in the event the license is not granted. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-4. - Inspections of premises for fire, health, safety hazards. 
    Upon filing of such application and the payment of any applicable fee, 
(a)  The fire marshal of the city shall forthwith examine said premises for the purpose of determining their suitability for such occupancy in respect to fire and safety laws and regulations of the state and city. He shall make a written report of his approval or disapproval of said application to the building inspector. In the event of disapproval, he shall set forth in said report the requirements of said fire regulations, or shall report that in his opinion said building cannot be repaired or altered to conform to such requirements; 
(b)  The health officer of the city shall forthwith examine said premises for the purpose of determining their suitability for such occupancy in respect to the health and sanitation laws and regulations of the state and city. He shall make written report of his approval, or disapproval, of said application to the building inspector. In the event of disapproval, he shall set forth in said report the requirements of said health and sanitation regulations, or shall report that in his opinion said building cannot be repaired or altered to conform to such requirements; 
(c)  The building inspector shall forthwith examine said premises for the purpose of determining their suitability for such occupancy in respect to the building code and building regulations and laws of the state and city. He shall file in his office a written report of his approval or disapproval of said application. In the event of disapproval, he shall set forth in said report the requirements of said building code and regulations or shall report that in his opinion said building cannot be repaired or altered to conform to such requirements. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-5. - Issuance of license. 
    Copies of the reports of the fire marshal and health officer shall be transmitted to the building inspector, and if said reports of the fire marshal and health officer are all reports of approval and if the use of said premises as a hotel, lodging or rooming house, or sober house, complies with the zoning regulations of the city, the building inspector shall, if the applicant is a suitable person to carry on the business of operating a hotel, lodging or rooming house, or sober house, as hereinbefore defined, thereupon approve said application and shall issue a license to the applicant to operate and conduct said hotel, lodging or rooming house, or sober house for the number of occupants stated therein. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-6. - Duration, renewal of license. 
    Each license so issued shall terminate on the first day of June next succeeding the issuance of said license, unless sooner revoked. Renewal applications shall be filed with the building inspector on or before May first in each year. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-7. - Use of heating devices. 
    No heating device shall be used, or permitted to remain in any hotel, lodging or rooming house, or sober house, as defined in this chapter unless equipped and installed in accordance with the specifications and requirements contained in the building code of the city, The National Board of Fire Underwriters, The National Fire Protection Association and The American Standards Association which specifications and requirements shall be applied to existing "heating devices" as well as to those hereafter installed. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-8. - Grounds, proceedings to revoke license. 
(a)  At any time the building inspector shall determine that the licensee in conducting and maintaining said hotel, rooming house or lodging house, or sober house, is violating the fire, safety, health or building regulations, or other state or local laws, or regulations pertaining to the operation of said premises, or is violating the conditions of the license in respect to the limitation on the number of occupants of said premises, or otherwise, he shall give the licensee a ten (10) days' written notice of such violation or violations by registered mail directing the licensee to appear before him to show cause why said license should not be revoked. Upon hearing and finding by the building inspector of the existence of such violation or violations, he may thereupon revoke said license and institute necessary proceedings to cause said premises to be vacated. 
(b)  In the event said violation should appear to be, to the fire marshal, the health officer or the building inspector, of such a nature as to create a serious and immediate danger to the life, health or welfare of the occupants thereof, or any other person, the building inspector may forthwith temporarily revoke said license until a hearing may be held, and in the meantime he may cause such measures to be taken as he deems advisable to insure safety in respect to fire, health, building requirements or the general welfare of the public, within ten (10) days after any such temporary revocation, the building inspector shall hold a hearing upon the permanent revocation of said license. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-9. - License fees. 
    The license fee to be paid in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be as follows: 
Lodging and rooming houses with not more than five (5) sleeping rooms ..... $60.00 
Lodging and rooming houses with more than five (5) sleeping rooms ..... 95.00 
Hotels with not more than fifteen (15) sleeping rooms ..... 125.00 
Hotels with more than fifteen (15) sleeping rooms ..... 175.00 
Convalescent homes ..... 175.00 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-10. - Rules and regulations to implement chapter. 
    The building inspector is authorized and empowered to make such reasonable regulations as he deems advisable to carry out the purpose and spirit of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Sec. 12-11. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day during which a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 06-18-18-1, § 1) 
Chapter 13 - HOUSING AND COMMERCIAL STRUCTURES CODES 
ARTICLE I. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE[1] 

Footnotes:

Section 109.6 Hearing (page 4, line 3 of section), is amended by deleting "appeals board" and substituting Code Enforcement Committee. 
Section 111.0 Means of Appeal (page 5), is hereby deleted and amended to read the following: 
SECTION 111.0 MEANS OF APPEAL 
Section 111.1 Appeals: Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this ordinance may request, and upon the payment of fifty dollar fee payable to the City of New London, shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Code enforcement Committee created in Section PM 111.2 of this ordinance; provided that such person shall file in the office of the Code Official a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the grounds thereof within 20 days after the day the notice was served. Upon receipt of such petition the Code Official shall notify said committee to set a time and place for such hearing and shall give the petitioner five days written notice thereof. At such hearing the petitioner shall be given the opportunity to be heard and to show why such notice should be modified, extended or withdrawn or a variance granted. The hearing shall be commenced not later that 60 days after the day on which the petition was filed. Provided that upon application of the petitioner the said committee may postpone the date of the hearing for a reasonable time beyond such 60 day period, if in its judgment the petitioner has submitted a good and sufficient reason for such postponement, but in no event shall said hearing be postponed longer than 60 days. 
The member of the committee whose notice is the subject of the appeal shall not participate as a member of the committee in the hearing on such appeal. 
Such hearing shall be had before a panel of five or more members of the said committee. Said panel, by a majority of the vote of those present, may sustain, modify or withdraw the notice; it may also grant an extension or variance in accordance with the following conditions: 
(1)  The time performance of any act required by the notice may be extended for not more than 18 months subject to appropriate conditions and where the committee makes specific findings of fact based on evidence relating to the particular case. 
(a)  That there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in the way of carrying out the strict letter of any provision of this ordinance; and 
(b)  That such extension is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this ordinance in securing public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  A variance may be granted in a specific case from a specific provision of this subject to appropriate conditions and where the committee makes specific findings of fact based on evidence relating to the particular case; 
(a)  That there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in the way carrying out the strict letter of the provision; 
(b)  That the effect of the application of the provisions would be arbitrary to the specific case; 
(c)  That an extension would not constitute an appropriate remedy for these practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships and this arbitrary effect; and 
(d)  That such variance is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this ordinance in securing the public health, safety and general welfare. 
If the notice is sustained, modified, or extended, it shall become an order as so sustained, modified, or extended. If the notice is withdrawn prior to the hearing, the fifty-dollar fee shall be returned to the petitioner. Any notice served pursuant to Section PM-107.0 of this ordinance shall automatically become an order if a written petition for a hearing is not filed in the office of the Code Official within 20 days after such notice is served. 
After hearing in the case of any notice suspending any permit required by this ordinance, when such notice has been sustained by the said committee, the permit shall be deemed to have been revoked. Any such permit which has been suspended by a notice shall be deemed to be automatically revoked if a petition for hearing is not filed in the office of the Code Official within 20 days after such notice is served. 
The proceedings at such hearings, including the findings, and decision of the Code Enforcement Committee, shall be summarized, reduced to writing, and entered as a matter of public record in the office of the Code Official and open to reasonable pubic inspection. Such record shall also include a copy of every notice or order issued in connection with the matter. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Code Official or the Code enforcement Committee may seek relief therefrom in any court of competent jurisdiction, as provided by the laws of this state. 
Section 111.2 Code Enforcement Committee: There is hereby created a Code Enforcement Committee, which shall consist of the Building Official, the Fire Chief, the Fire Marshal, the Director of Health, the Chief of Police, and the Zoning Enforcement Officer. A Chairperson and a Secretary shall be appointed by said committee. Said committee shall be responsible for the coordination of all code, regulation and law enforcement activities. Any member of the committee may designate one official of his/her department to represent him at meetings of the committee. 
Section 201.3 Term defined in other codes; (page 7) Is hereby amended as follows: 
Delete from lines 2, 3, 4 and 5 the word "International" and from line 5 the initials "ICC" and the words International Existing Building Code. 
Also amended by adding to end of said section the words "listed in chapter 8". 
Section 202 (page 7), amended by adding the following under the definitions of Public Nuisance: 
1.  The physical condition or occupancy of any premises regarded as a public nuisance at common law. 
2.  Any physical condition or occupancy of any premises or its appurtenance considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations and unsafe fences or structures; 
3.  Any premises that has unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities; 
4.  Any premises designated as unsafe or unsecured so as to endanger life, limb or property; 
5.  Any premises that is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or is manifestly unsafe or unsecured so as to endanger life, limb or property; 
6.  Any premises from which the plumbing, heating or facilities required by this code have been removed, or from which utilities have been disconnected, destroyed, removed or rendered ineffective, or the required precautions against trespassers have not been provided; 
7.  Any premises that is unsanitary, or that is littered with rubbish or garbage, or that has uncontrolled growth of weeds; or 
8.  Any structure that is in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or decay; faulty construction; overcrowded; open, vacant or abandoned; damaged by fire to the extent so as not to provide shelter; in a danger of collapse or failure; and dangerous to anyone on or near the premises.
