ARTICLE III. - BLIGHT 

Sec. 13-151. - Declaration of purpose. 
(a)  This ordinance is enacted pursuant to the Connecticut General Statutes (General Statutes), § 7-148(c)(7) and § 14-150a. This ordinance is to be enforced as a blight ordinance, pursuant to General Statute § 7-148(c)(7)(H)(xv), and as a nuisance ordinance, pursuant to General Statute § 7-148(c)(7)(E). 
(b)  It is hereby found and declared that there exist in the City of New London (hereinafter "city") a number of blighted properties and that continued existence of blighted properties constitutes a continuing nuisance and contributes to the decline of our neighborhoods. Existence of blighted properties adversely affects the economic well-being of the city. Many of the blighted properties may be rehabilitated, reconstructed, demolished, cleaned up, groomed, maintained, returned to satisfactory condition or reused to provide decent, safe, sanitary housing or commercial facilities. Such rehabilitation, reconstruction, demolition, cleanup or reuse of the blighted and nuisance properties would eliminate, remedy and prevent adverse conditions. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-152. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this ordinance, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Enforcement officer shall mean the city director of health, a city police officer, a city building official, a housing/property maintenance inspector, or any person duly appointed to be such an enforcement officer by the mayor, all of whom shall be authorized to take such enforcement actions and to issue citations as specified in this ordinance. 
    Citation hearing officer. The mayor of the city shall appoint one or more citation hearing officers, as defined in and pursuant to General Statute § 7-152c(b), as amended. Such officers shall be other than any individual who issues citations under this ordinance. 
    Blight, blighted condition , and blighted property shall be interchangeable terms and shall be when violations of the following city ordinances and property maintenance code sections occur under the provisions of this ordinance: 
New London Property Maintenance Code Sections: 
 301.3 Vacant structures and land. 
 302.1 Sanitation. 
 302.3 Privately owned sidewalks and driveways. 
 302.4 Weeds. 
 302.7 Accessory structures. 
 302.8 Motor vehicles. 
 302.9 Defacement of property. 
 304.1 through and inclusive of 304.18.3 general exterior structure. 
 307.1 Accumulation of rubbish or garbage. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-153. - Creation or continuation of blighted property prohibited. 
    No person, firm or corporation, no owner, agent, tenant, operator, possessor of real property located within the limits of the city, and no other person responsible for the care, maintenance and/or condition of real property located within the limits of the city, shall cause or allow any blight, blighted condition or blighted property, as defined in section 13-152 of this ordinance, to be created, maintained or continued. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-154. - Designation of blighted property. 
    The enforcement officer(s) shall be responsible for determining whether a property which comes to the attention of the city, whether through written complaint or through the normal operations of the city, is blighted according to the definitions in this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-155. - Property owner notification. 
(a)  Whenever the city identifies a blighted property, written notice of the violation shall be given to the owner and/or the occupant of the property, by posting a notice of the violation in a conspicuous location at the blighted property, and delivering a copy of the notice of the violation to an owner, either by hand delivery or by mail. Said notice shall specify that the owner or occupant has five (5) days, from the date notice was posted and mailed, to remediate the blighted conditions, or the city will take enforcement action. In the case of an unidentified owner or one whose address is unknown, the enforcement officer shall publish legal notice in a newspaper having a substantial circulation within the city, stating the property is cited for blight and, if applicable, whether the property has been determined to be abandoned. 
(b)  Prior to the expiration of the five-day period specified in paragraph (a) of this section, the property owner may request additional time for remediation. The enforcement officer may determine an alternate timetable of a reasonable length of time if warranted. Such timetable will be in writing and must be signed by both the enforcement officer and the property owner. Failure to comply with the agreed-upon timetable will make the property owner liable for retroactive fines and penalties as designated in section 13-156, subsections (a) and (b). 
(c)  After the expiration of the five-day period specified in paragraph (a) of this section and without the alternate timetable specified in paragraph (b) above, the city, through its designated agents, may enter blighted property during reasonable hours for the purpose of remediating blighted conditions, provided neither the city nor its designated agents enter any dwelling house or structure on such property. Costs associated with the remediation of blight may be recovered by the city in accordance with General Statute § 49-73(b). 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-156. - Enforcement: criminal violations and civil penalties. 
(a)  Criminal violations. Pursuant to General Statute § 7-148(c)(7)(H)(xv), any person or entity who, after written notice and a reasonable opportunity to remediate blighted conditions as specified in section 14-155 of this ordinance, willfully violates section 14-153 of this ordinance, may be fined by the State of Connecticut not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each day for which it can be shown, based upon an actual inspection of the property on each such day, the blighted conditions continued to exist after written notice to the owner or occupant, as provided in section 14-155. This subsection is designated as a violation pursuant to General Statute § 53a-27. No person or entity shall be found guilty of a violation pursuant to this subsection and a civil penalty pursuant to paragraph (b) of this section for the same occurrence. 
(b)  Civil penalties. Any person or entity which fails to comply with section 13-153 of this ordinance, and, thereafter, fails to remediate the blighted conditions within five (5) days of the notice provided pursuant to section 13-155, may be assessed a civil penalty for each building, structure or parcel of land in violation of this ordinance. The amount of the civil penalty shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day. Each day a building, structure or parcel of land remains in violation of this ordinance shall constitute grounds for the assessment of a separate civil penalty. The issuing officer shall deliver written notice of the civil penalty, either by hand delivery or by mail, to the owner or occupant responsible for the blighted premises. Said notice will include the nature of the violation and the penalty being assessed. 
(1)  Penalties assessed pursuant to paragraph (b) of this section shall be enforceable by citation pursuant to General Statute § 7-152c, as amended. 
(2)  Persons or entities assessed a penalty pursuant to paragraph (b) of this section shall remit fines for said violation within ten (10) days of the mailing of notice thereof. The fine imposed shall be payable to the city and sent to the city's finance department. Uncontested payments received pursuant to this subsection shall be inadmissible in any proceeding, civil or criminal, to establish the conduct of the person or entity making the payment. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-157. - Civil penalty citation hearing procedure. 
(a)  Notification of right to hearing. At the time that the civil penalty is assessed, the property owner shall be notified in writing of the availability of a hearing before a citation hearing officer to contest the determination of blight and/or the assessed penalty. Specifically, the property owner shall be notified: 
(1)  Of the allegations against him and the amount of the fines, penalties, costs or fees due; 
(2)  That the owner may request a hearing to contest the determination of blight and/or the assessed penalty; 
(3)  That the owner must provide a written request for such a hearing within ten (10) days of the date of notification; 
(4)  That if the property owner does not demand such a hearing, an assessment and judgment shall be entered against the property owner; and 
(5)  That the judgment may be issued without further notice. 
(b)  Rights of the respondent. 
(1)  Admission of liability. If the property owner who is sent notice pursuant to paragraph (a) of this section wishes to admit liability for any alleged violation, the owner may, without requesting a hearing, pay the full amount of the fines, penalties, costs or fees admitted to in person or by mail in accordance with subsection 13-156(b)(2) above and remediate the blighted property. Payment shall be inadmissible in any proceeding, civil or criminal, to establish the conduct of the property owner making the payment. 
(2)  Constructive admission of liability. Any person or entity who fails to deliver or mail written demand for a hearing within ten (10) days of the date of the first notice provided for in paragraph (a) of this section shall be deemed to have admitted liability, and the enforcement officer shall certify the property owner's failure to respond to the citation hearing officer. The citation hearing officer shall thereupon enter and assess the fines, penalties, costs or fees provided for in this ordinance including per diem penalties retroactive to the original date of expected remediation as specified in section 13-155, and shall follow the notice procedures set forth in paragraphs (c) and (d) of this section. 
(3)  Right to hearing. Any person or entity who requests a hearing shall be given written notice of the date, time and place for the hearing. The hearing shall be held not less than fifteen (15) days, nor more than thirty (30) days, from the date of the mailing of notice, provided, the citation hearing officer may grant, upon good cause shown, any reasonable request by any interested party for continuance. 
(c)  Formal hearing procedure. The citation hearing officer shall preside over a hearing which shall be held in the manner outlined in General Statute § 7-152c(e), as amended. The citation hearing officer shall render the decision in writing and file it within five (5) days with the enforcement officer and the mayor, and send it by first-class and certified mail, return receipt requested, to the property owner or other responsible person and to all parties in the proceedings. The citation hearing officer may decide one of the following: 
(1)  Dismissal. If the citation hearing officer determines that the respondent is not liable, the citation hearing officer shall dismiss the matter, and enter the determination in writing. 
(2)  Finding of liability; assessment. If the citation hearing officer determines that the respondent is liable for the violation, the citation hearing officer shall enter and assess the fines, penalties, costs or fees against the respondent, as provided by in section 13-156, including per diem penalties retroactive to the expected date of remediation as set forth in subsection 13-154(b). 
(d)  Notice of assessment; effect. 
(1)  Assessments must be paid to the city within ten (10) days of receipt of the citation hearing officer's determination. 
(2)  Not less than thirty (30) days, but not more than twelve (12) months, after the mailing as set forth in paragraph (c) of this section, the citation hearing officer shall file a certified copy of the notice of assessment with the clerk of a superior court designated by the chief court administrator, together with the appropriate entry fee. The certified copy of the notice of assessment shall constitute a record of assessment. Within the twelve-month period, assessments against the same person may be accrued and filed as one record of assessment. 
a.  Entry of judgment. The court clerk shall enter judgment in the amount of the record of assessment, and court costs, allowed by the General Statutes, in favor of the city pursuant to General Statute § 7-152c(f), as amended. 
b.  Effect of judgment; levy of execution permitted. Notwithstanding any provision of the General Statutes, the citation hearing officer's assessment, when so entered as a judgment, shall have effect of a civil money judgment, and a levy of execution on the judgment may issue without further notice, to the respondent. 
(e)  A decision of the citation hearing officer to issue assessments may be appealed to the superior court in accordance with the provisions of General Statutes § 7-152c(g), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-158. - Removal of abandoned, inoperable or unregistered motor vehicles. 
    For all properties declared blighted properties within the meaning of this ordinance as a result of the presence of an abandoned, inoperable or unregistered motor vehicle, which blighted condition has remained in effect for thirty (30) days or which motor vehicle has remained abandoned, inoperable or unregistered on site for thirty (30) days after: 
(1)  Notice by hand delivery or by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the owner of the property on which such motor vehicle remains, or the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle, if different from the owner of the property requesting the removal of such motor vehicle, and 
(2)  Notice in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city. 
    The city council may provide for the removal and storage of said motor vehicle or parts thereof. The costs of the removal and storage of said motor vehicle or parts thereof and the costs of notices shall be borne by the owner of the property from which the motor vehicle or parts thereof are removed or, if the owner of the property is not the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle, by the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle. 
    Any motor vehicle that is removed pursuant to this ordinance may not be returned to the same property unless it has been made operable and has been registered. 
    If the costs of the removal and storage of the motor vehicle remain unpaid for a period of thirty (30) days, the city may order the motor vehicle or parts thereof sold at public auction and no such public auction shall occur without being sent, certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of the property involved or, if the owner of the property is different from the owner of the motor vehicle, the motor vehicle is to be auctioned and the proceeds of the auction applied to the cost of removal and storage. Notice of the auction shall be published in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city at least ten (10) days prior to said auction date. The proceeds of such sale will be used by the city to defray the costs of removal, storage and notice. If there should be any money left over after the payment of said costs, the excess proceeds shall be turned over to the owner of the property involved, or if the owner of the property is different from the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle, or if neither property is known, said funds shall be deposited in the general fund of the municipality. 
    Any person aggrieved by a notice requesting the removal of a motor vehicle or by the removal of same may, within fifteen (15) days of receipt of notice, appeal said ruling to the citation hearing officer. Said appeal shall be heard and appeals may be taken from any such hearing in accordance with the procedures as set forth in General Statutes § 7-152c. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-159. - Collection of fines imposed and costs incurred. 
(a)  All fines imposed for violation of this ordinance shall be payable to the city and deposited in the general fund. 
(b)  Pursuant to General Statutes § 7-148aa, any unpaid fine imposed pursuant to this ordinance shall constitute a lien upon the real estate against which the fine was imposed from the date of such fine. In addition, pursuant to General Statutes § 49-73b, any expenses incurred by the city pursuant to this ordinance shall be subject to a lien. Said lien may be foreclosed upon and enforced in the same manner as property tax liens. The city tax collector is hereby empowered to place a lien on the land records in the manner as specified by the General Statutes, provided a copy of said lien is mailed by first-class mail to the owner as set forth on the most recent tax assessment list. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I) 
Sec. 13-160. - General provisions. 
(a)  The rights and powers under this ordinance shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other rights and powers that the city has under the General Statutes and the City's Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  A violation of this ordinance is a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 09-08-15-1, Art. I)

ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The Ord. of 9-2-80, §§ 3-8, pertaining to fair housing did not expressly amend this Code; hence, codification as Art. II of Ch. 13.1, §§ 13.1-21-13.1-28, is at the discretion of the editor. Provisions of § 8 of said ordinance providing for severability of ordinance provisions have been omitted from codification at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 13.1-21. - Statement of policy and purposes. 
(a)  In accord with title VIII of the United States Code and the Human Rights Law of the State of Connecticut, it is the policy of the city to provide fair housing. 
(b)  The purposes of this article are those in accord with title VIII of the United States Code as such section applies to fair housing. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, § 3) 
Sec. 13.1-22. - Article provisions supplemental. 
    This article shall supersede all laws inconsistent with it to the extent of such inconsistency, but in all other respects shall be deemed supplemental to such laws. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, § 8) 
Sec. 13.1-23. - Definitions. 
    All such definitions of the statutes of the State of Connecticut as they pertain to fair housing are hereby restated by the city as the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, § 4) 
Sec. 13.1-24. - Unlawful discriminatory practices. 
    All such unlawful discriminatory practices contained in the statutes of the State of Connecticut as pertaining to fair housing are hereby restated by the city as the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, § 5) 
Sec. 13.1-25. - Fair housing office-Established; head of office designated. 
    There is hereby established a fair housing office which is designated to administer this article. The head of such office shall be the fair housing officer of the city. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, § 6) 
Sec. 13.1-26. - Same-Power and Duties. 
    The fair housing office, by and through the fair housing officer, shall have the following functions, powers and duties: 
(1)  To establish and maintain a principal office within the city as may be necessary. 
(2)  Upon request, to obtain and utilize the services of all governmental departments and agencies. 
(3)  To formulate policies to effectuate the purposes of this article and to make recommendations to agencies and officers of the city in aid of such policies and purposes. 
(4)  To receive complaints alleging violations of this article and to assist complainants to file with the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities for purposes of investigation and remedy. 
(5)  To develop human rights plans and policies for the city and to assist in their execution, to make investigations and studies appropriate to effectuate this article, to inform persons of the rights assured and remedies provided under this article, to provide good will, and to minimize or eliminate discrimination. 
(6)  To render each year to the city manager and to the city council a written report of all of its activities and of its recommendations. 
(7)  To furnish any person with such technical assistance that the office deems appropriate to further compliance with the purposes or provisions of this article. 
(8)  Such other powers and duties described hereinafter and as may be designated by the city manager or otherwise authorized by the city council. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, § 7) 
Sec. 13.1-27. - Complaint procedures. 
(a)  Filing. Any person claiming to be aggrieved by an unlawful discriminatory practice may, by himself or by his attorney, make, sign and file with the office a verified complaint which shall state the name and address of the person or persons alleged to have committed the unlawful discriminatory practice complained of and which shall set forth the particulars thereof and contain such other information as may be requested by the office. 
(b)  Investigation. After the filing of the complaint, the office shall make a prompt investigation in connection therewith. 
(c)  Disposition. If in the judgment of the office, the circumstances so warrant, it may, at any time after the filing of the complaint, endeavor to eliminate such discriminatory practice by conference, conciliation and persuasion, and/or refer the complaint to the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, § 8(1)-(3)) 
Sec. 13.1-28. - Pursuit of other remedies. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed so as to limit or prohibit investigation by any other governmental unit of competent jurisdiction, nor shall anything contained herein limit any aggrieved party from pursuing any remedy available therefrom. In the event of such a situation, the office is hereby empowered to place any and all of its material obtained concerning a complaint at the disposal of such other governmental unit. 
(Ord. of 9-2-80, § 8(4)) 
Chapter 14 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Crime prevention and police protection, Ch. 7.1; police department, § 15-56 et seq. 
State Law reference- Bribery, § 149 et seq., Penal Code, P.A. No. 828, 1969; criminal mischief, § 117 Penal Code, P.D. No. 828, 1969; loitering on school grounds, § 187, Penal Code, P.A. No. 828, 1969; protection of morals of minors, § 53-21, Gen. Stats. 

Sec. 14-1. - Misusing, mutilating public property. 
    No person shall break or in any manner mutilate, deface, injure or misuse any public toilet, bench, seat, railing, wharf, fence, structure or any other thing in any of the parks, beaches or other public places in the city. 
(Ord. of 8-27-23, § 2) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-2. - Injuring, tampering with public lighting. 
    No person shall injure any street light or interfere or tamper with the lighting of any public park, street or way. 
(Ord. of 8-27-23, § 3) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-3. - Noises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, play or operate, for any purpose whatever, any loudspeaker or sound-amplifying device attached to or on any vehicle moving or standing on any highway or public place in the city, or in any place where the sound from said vehicle is cast directly upon any of said highways or public places, without first obtaining a permit from the chief of police or his/her designee; provided, however, that: 
(1)  Permits shall not be granted for advertising or commercial use. 
(2)  Such devices shall only be operated from 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. on weekdays and Saturday and 1:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m. on Sunday. 
(3)  Repealed (Ord. 02-07-05-1). 
(4)  Such devices shall not be operated in the vicinity of hospitals, or schools while in session, or churches while services are being conducted. 
(5)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to prohibit the use of such devices on vehicles of the City of New London while engaged upon necessary public business or on emergency vehicles. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, play or operate any loudspeaker or sound-amplifying device from any stand, platform or any other structures or part of any structure which abuts or is adjacent to a public place or street or to use, play or operate any loudspeaker or sound-amplifying device which is attached to the outside of any building, or premises abutting or adjacent to a public place or street, without first obtaining a permit from the chief of police or his/her designee, as set forth in subsection (j) of this section, except for public functions or emergency use. Permits shall list the specific days and hours of operation as determined by the needs of the applicant and the comfort of the public. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, play or operate any loudspeaker or sound-amplifying device from any airplane, or any other device or machine used for flying over the city or anywhere over or on the public streets, without obtaining a permit from the chief of police or his/her designee. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, play or operate any portable device, radio or apparatus or any sound-producing device on any public transportation, public beach, street, park or place or in any public building, which can be heard by other than the person using such instrument. 
(e)  Repealed (Ord. 02-07-05-1). 
(f)  Repealed (Ord. 02-07-05-1). 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any person in control of a vehicle, whether inside or outside of such vehicle, to park on a public street, highway, park or place and use, play or operate the car radio, or any device producing sound, which can be heard outside the vehicle. 
(h)  When emergency conditions exist due to gas leaks, water main breaks, etc., necessary repairs may be made at any time to contain the emergency condition until such situation can be corrected properly within acceptable hours. In situations where repairs may produce excessive noise in conflict with this section, a special permit may be issued. 
(i)  Violation of any provision of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(j)  Permit issuance. 
(1)  Upon verifying that a person is eligible to be issued a permit, the chief of police or his/her designee may give permission to a person to allow the use or operation of a loudspeaker or sound-amplifying device between 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 a.m. (midnight) on Fridays and Saturdays, and between 9:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. Sundays through Thursdays, provided that the use of a loudspeaker or sound-amplifying device does not exceed the decibel limits set forth in subsection 14-3.5(c) of the City's Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Any person issued a permit under this subparagraph shall keep a copy of said permit on file at the subject property, and shall produce said copy when requested by any law enforcement personnel. 
(3)  Enforcement of the terms and conditions of any permit issued under this subparagraph shall be by the city police department, and shall be pursuant to policies and procedures established by the chief of police or his/her designee. A copy of said policies and procedures shall be provided to any person at the time that a permit is issued. 
(4)  Any permit issued under this subparagraph may be suspended or revoked by the city after a hearing is conducted by the public safety committee of the city council. Said hearing shall be open to the public and shall be pursuant to terms and conditions established by the public safety committee, which terms and conditions shall be provided to any person at the time that a permit is issued. 
(Ord. of 12-3-62, §§ 1-4; Ord. of 9-15-80, § 1; Ord. No. 07-20-15-3) 
Sec. 14-3.5. - Noise pollution. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this ordinance. Where terms are not defined under this section and are defined in the noise regulations of the state department of environmental protection (sections 22a-69-1.1 et seq.), they shall have the same meaning ascribed to them in those regulations. Otherwise, they shall have ascribed to them their ordinarily accepted meanings. 
    Construction shall mean any and all physical activity at a site necessary or incidental to the erection, placement, demolition, assembling, altering, blasting, cleaning, repairing, installing, or equipping of buildings or other structures, public or private highways, roads, premises, parks, utility lines, or other property, and shall include, but not be limited to, land clearing, grading, excavating, filling, and paving. 
    Daytime hours shall mean the hours between 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday, and between 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. on Sunday (local time). 
    Excessive noise shall mean emitter noise zone levels from noise sources exceeding the standards set forth in subsection (c) beyond the boundary of the emitter's noise zones. 
    Mobile sources of noise shall include, but are not limited to, such sources as aircraft, automobiles, trucks and boats. 
    Nighttime hours shall mean the hours between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Sunday through Friday, and between 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. Saturday (local time). 
    Noise zone shall mean an individual unit of land or a group of contiguous parcels under the same ownership as indicated by public land records and, as relates to noise emitters, includes contiguous publicly dedicated street and highway rights-of-way, railroad rights-of-way, water bodies, and waters of the state. 
    Site shall mean the area bounded by the property line on or in which a source of noise exists. 
    Sound level meter shall mean any instrument that is capable of measuring sound levels. The sound level meter shall conform to all applicable state and federal standards. 
(b)  Classification of noise zones. 
(1)  Noise zone classifications shall be based on the actual use of any parcel or tract under single ownership, or in the case of vacant lands, based on the zoning district in which a parcel is located as described on the zoning map and in the zoning regulations of the town. Where multiple uses exist within a given noise zone, the least restrictive land use category for the emitter and receptor shall apply regarding the noise standards specified in subsection (c). 
(2)  Class A noise zone/uses. Lands designated class A shall generally be residential areas where human beings sleep or areas where serenity and tranquility are essential to the intended use of the land. The land uses in this category shall include, but not be limited to, single- and multiple-family homes, hotels, motels, religious facilities, hospitals, nursing homes, cultural activities, forest preserves, historic and monument sites, and vacant land zoned for residential or related uses requiring such protection. 
(3)  Class B noise zone/uses. Lands designated class B shall generally be commercial in nature. The land uses in this category shall include, but not be limited to, retail trade, professional offices, government services, educational institutions, amusements, agricultural activities, automotive dealers and gasoline service stations, restaurants, bars and nightclubs, marinas and other water dependent uses, and vacant lands zoned for such commercial or institutional uses. 
(4)  Class C noise zone/uses. Lands designated class C shall generally be industrial. The land uses in this category shall include, but not be limited to, manufacturing activities, transportation facilities, warehousing, earth products excavation, processing and mining, and other lands zoned for such uses. 
(c)  Noise zone standards. No person shall cause or allow the emission of excessive noise beyond the boundaries of his/her noise zone as measured at any point on a receptor's tract or parcel of land, so as to exceed the levels stated herein: 
Receptor Noise Zone Class 
C B A-Day A-Night Class C emitter to 70 dBA 66 dBA 61 dBA 51 dBA Class B emitter to 62 dBA 62 dBA 55 dBA 45 dBA Class A emitter to 62 dBA 55 dBA 55 dBA 45 dBA  
(d)  Exclusions. These regulations shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Sound generated by natural phenomena. 
(2)  The unamplified sounding of the human voice. 
(3)  The unamplified sound made by any wild or domestic animal. 
(4)  Sound created by bells, carillons, or chimes associated with specific religious observances and/or organizations. 
(5)  Sound created by a public emergency sound signal attached to an authorized emergency vehicle in the immediate act of responding to an emergency, or located within or attached to a building, pole or other structure for the purpose of sounding or testing an alarm relating to fire or emergency management. 
(6)  Sound created by safety and protective devices. 
(7)  Farming equipment or farming activity. 
(8)  Back-up alarms required by OSHA or other state or federal safety regulations. 
(9)  Sound created by a mobile source of noise. This exclusion shall cease to apply when a mobile source of noise has maneuvered into position at the loading dock, or similar facility, and has begun the physical process of loading or removing the contents of the vehicle. 
(e)  Exemptions. Exempted from this ordinance are the following: 
(1)  Noise generated by engine-powered or motor-driven lawn care or maintenance equipment shall be exempted during daytime hours provided that noise discharged from exhausts is adequately muffled to prevent loud and/or explosive noises therefrom. 
(2)  Noises created by snow removal equipment at any time shall be exempted provided that such equipment shall be maintained in good repair so as to minimize noise, and noise discharged from exhausts shall be adequately muffled to prevent loud and/or explosive noises therefrom. 
(3)  Noise created as a result of, or relating to, an emergency. 
(4)  Construction noise. 
(5)  Noise created by blasting other than that conducted in connection with construction activities shall be exempted provided that the blasting is conducted between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. local time at specified hours previously announced to the local public, or provided that a permit for such blasting has been obtained from local authorities. 
(6)  Noise generated by transmission facilities, distribution facilities and substations of public utilities providing electrical powers, telephone, cable television or other similar services and located on property which is not owned by the public utility and which may or may not be within utility easements. 
(f)  Measurement procedures. All personnel conducting sound measurements shall be trained in the current techniques and principles of sound measuring equipment and instrumentation. The instrument manufacturer's specific instructions for the preparation and use of the instrument shall be followed. Measurements shall be taken and documented at a point that is located approximately one foot beyond the boundary of the emitter's premises within the noise receptor's premises. 
(g)  Enforcement-Penalty. 
(1)  The city police department shall be responsible for making noise level measurements and enforcing this ordinance. Whenever the reasonable police officer makes a determination that there has been a violation of any provision of this ordinance, he shall issue a written order to such person(s) responsible for the violation specifying the nature of the violation and affording a reasonable time for its correction or remedy. If said order is not complied with as directed by the officer, the officer shall issue a citation. 
(2)  Any person in violation of any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be fined in an amount not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Each day on which a violation occurs or continues after the time for correction of the violation given in the order has elapsed shall be considered a separate violation of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 02-07-05-1, § 1; Ord. No. 07-20-15-3) 
Sec. 14-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as the tattoo parlor ordinance was rescinded by council on September 2, 2008, the former section 14-4, which pertained to tattooing and derived from an ordinance of January 15, 1962, §§ 1, 2, has been deleted. 
Sec. 14-5. - Dressing, undressing in vehicle. 
    No person shall dress or undress in any vehicle in any public street or park. 
(Ord. of 7-3-22, § 3) 
Cross reference- Use of bathhouses required for changing into swimming attire in public parks, § 16-54; streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-6. - Immodest conduct. 
    No person while in bathing costume or upon any bathing beach or in the public parks shall conduct himself or herself immodestly. 
(Ord. of 7-3-22, § 4) 
Cross reference- Bathing in public parks, § 16-53; streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-7. - Penalty for violation of sections 14-5 and 14-6. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of sections 14-5 or 14-6 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) or more than thirty dollars ($30.00) payable into the treasury of the city. 
(Ord. of 7-3-22, § 5) 
Sec. 14-8. - Abandoned refrigerators, freezers, similar containers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to abandon, discard, store or keep in any place accessible to children, or for any person as the owner, lessee or manager to permit to remain on his premises under his control, a refrigerator, icebox, freezer cabinet or similar container, of a capacity of one and one-half (11/2) cubic feet or more, which is no longer used for refrigeration purposes, without the attached doors, hinges, lids or latches being removed. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or by imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. of 6-7-54, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 14-9. - Loitering upon quasi-public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter upon any quasi-public property. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section the term "loiter" shall mean one or more of the following acts committed on quasi-public property within the city: 
(1)  Obstructing the free and unhampered passage of pedestrians or vehicles. 
(2)  Obstructing, molesting or interfering with any person lawfully upon any quasi-public property. 
(3)  Congregating with other persons in a public or quasi-public place and failing to comply with a reasonable request or order to disperse by a police officer of the city or other officers having the power of arrest, or the owner of such property or his agent of such quasi-public place in order to preserve or promote public peace and order. 
(c)  "Quasi-public property" shall be deemed to include the area in front of or adjacent to any store, shop, restaurant or other place of business and shall include parking lots adjacent thereto. 
(d)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned for a period not exceeding ten (10) days, or both. 
(Ord. of 3-22-71, §§ 1-4) 
Sec. 14-9.1. - Demonstrating in vicinity of courthouse buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful if, on or along a public street or sidewalk within a radius of seventy-five (75) feet of any building established as a courthouse, any person calls aloud, shouts, holds or displays placards or signs containing written or printed matter, concerning the conduct of a trial or arraignment being held in such courthouse or the character of the court or jury engaged in such trial or arraignment, or calling for or demanding any specified action or determination by such court or jury in connection with such trial or arraignment. 
(Ord. of 10-15-79, § 1) 
Editor's note- An Ord. of 10-15-79, § 1, amended the Code by adding provisions designated § 14-26. For purposes of classification, and at his discretion, the editor has redesignated said provisions § 14-9.1. 
Sec. 14-9.2. - Loitering for solicitation; enforcement, procedure, definitions, penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter or remain in a public place in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of engaging, inducing, enticing, or soliciting another person to engage in sexual activity. The circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such purposes are manifested are: That such person repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop passersby, or engages passersby in conversation, or repeatedly stops or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators by hailing, waving of arms or any other bodily gestures. Other circumstances which may also be considered are whether such person is a known prostitute and/or whether the arresting officer knows such person's actions occur in an area of the city which has a high incidence of prostitution and related activities. 
(1)  No arrest shall be made, or no citation shall be issued for a violation of this section unless the arresting officer, by direct demand, first affords such person an opportunity to explain such conduct. 
(2)  No person shall be convicted of a violation of this section if the arresting officer does not comply with the preceding subsection or if it appears at trial that the explanation offered was true and disclosed a lawful purpose. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
(1)  Known prostitute or panderer means a person who within one year previous to the date of an arrest or issuance of a citation for violation of this section, has been, to the knowledge of the arresting officer, convicted of a violation of an ordinance of the City of New London or statute of the State of Connecticut defining and punishing acts of prostitution, patronizing a prostitute or promoting prostitution. 
(2)  Loitering means remaining idle in essentially one place and shall include the concepts of spending time idly, loafing, or walking about aimlessly. 
(3)  Public place is an area generally visible to public view and includes streets, sidewalks, bridges, alleys, plazas, parks, driveways, parking lots, automobiles (while moving or not), and buildings open to the general public including those which serve food or drink or provide entertainment, and the doorway and entrances to buildings or dwellings and the grounds enclosing them or any other area either publicly owned or to which the public has access. 
(4)  Sexual activity or sexual conduct means acts of prostitution, patronizing a prostitute, or promoting prostitution as such acts are proscribed and defined in this Code and in the Connecticut Criminal Code. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person who violates this section shall be fined one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). This fine shall not be subject to suspension or reduction for any reason. 
(Ord. of 4-18-83; Ord. of 3-20-89, § 1) 
Sec. 14-10. - Playing games, etc., upon streets or sidewalks. 
    No person shall play at ball, or throw stones or snowballs, or fly a kite, or coast with a sled, or make a bonfire, or discharge fireworks or firecrackers in or upon any street or sidewalk. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 8) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-11. - Carrying of weapons, discharge of firearms. 
    No person shall carry any weapon or discharge any firearm within city limits, unless specifically authorized with the limitations and provisions of an active permit from the State of Connecticut or as otherwise authorized by law. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 9; Ord. No. 05-21-12-4) 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted May 21, 2012, changed the title of section 14-11 from "Carrying concealed weapons, discharging firearms" to "Carrying of weapons, discharge of firearms." The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 14-12. - Posting bills, advertisements. 
    No person shall post any bill, placard or advertisement to any tree, hydrant, fence, building, lamp post, or property of another without the license of the owner of said property. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 13) 
Sec. 14-13. - Committing nuisance. 
    No person shall commit any nuisance on any sidewalk, or against any building, hydrant, tree, fence or lamp post. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 14) 
Sec. 14-14. - Smearing, marking property. 
    No person shall daub, besmear or mark any fence, building, sidewalk, tree, hydrant, lamp post, or other property, public or private, without the license of the owner. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 15) 
Sec. 14-15. - Conducting prejudicial, offensive businesses. 
    No person shall erect or use any stationary steam boiler, or shall use any building for the purpose of carrying on any trade, manufacture or business, which is prejudicial to public health, or constitutes an unreasonable annoyance and injury to those living in the vicinity, without authority from the council. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 17) 
Sec. 14-16. - Use of indecent language. 
    No person shall utter any indecent language in any street or public place to the disturbance or annoyance of any other person. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 20) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-17. - False alarms, fire or burglar (intrusion) alarm systems, disturbances. 
(a)  No person shall willfully make a false alarm of fire, or shall make a disturbance by singing, shouting or other disorderly noise. 
(b)  There shall be no more than two (2) false fire alarms or two (2) false burglar alarms, or any combination thereof, from any one (1) alarm system during the calendar year. 
(c)  A charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be imposed on the alarm owner/user for each occurrence of a false alarm response after two (2) within the same calendar year. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the fire marshal or his or her designee, and the chief of police or his or her designee, depending upon whether the false alarm is a fire alarm or a burglar alarm. 
(e)  If the fire marshal, or his or her designee, or the chief of police, or his or her designee, determines that exceptional or unusual circumstances resulted in a false alarm response, then he or she shall have the discretion to waive the charge in subsection (c) for that particular response. 
(Ord. No. 06-01-09-5, 6-1-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-01-09-5, adopted June 1, 2009, amended section 14-17 in its entirety, which pertained to false fire alarms, disturbances, and derived from an ordinance of March 5, 1945, § 21. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 14-18. - Playing musical instrument in public. 
    No person shall play upon any hand organ or other musical instrument in any street or public place after being notified by a police officer to desist. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 22) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-19. - Reserved.

Sec. 14-20. - Misuse of public lighting, hydrants. 
    No person shall, without authority, extinguish the light in any public lamp, or turn on the water at any public hydrant. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 25) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-21. - Obstructing, resisting officer. 
    No person shall resist, hinder or obstruct the president of the council, chief executive officer, director of public works, city engineer, any health officer, chief of police or police officer in the discharge of the duties of his office. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 28; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 14-22. - Playing games, injuring property in cemetery. 
    No person shall play at any game, fly a kite, coast with a sled or mutilate, deface or otherwise injure any grave, tomb, monument or memorial stone, in any burial ground within the limits of the City of New London. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 33; Ord. of 12-29-60) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-23. - Spitting. 
    No person shall spit on any sidewalk or upon the floor or other surface of any bus or other public vehicle for the transportation of passengers or upon the floor or surface of any theatre, railroad station, waiting room, or hall while used for public exhibitions or purposes. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 34; Ord. of 12-29-60) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 14-24. - Obscene matter. 
(a)  As used in this section, the following words shall, unless the context requires otherwise, have the following meanings: 
(1)  Disseminate shall mean to import, publish, produce, print, manufacture, distribute, sell, lease, exhibit or display. 
(2)  Matter shall mean any printed material, visual representation, live performance or sound recording including but not limited to books, magazines, motion pictures, films, pamphlets, phonographic records, pictures, tapes, photographs, figures, statutes, plays and dances. 
(3)  Patently offensive matter shall mean if taken as a whole, that which: 
a.  Appeals to prurient interest of the average person; 
b.  Depicts or describes sexual conduct in a patently offensive way applying the contemporary standards of the state; 
c.  Lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(4)  Sexual conduct shall mean human masturbation, sexual intercourse actual or simulated, normal or perverted, or any touching of the genitals, pubic areas or buttocks of the human male or female, whether alone, or between members of the same or opposite sex, or between humans and animals, any depiction or representation of excretory functions, any lewd exhibitions of the genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship. Sexual intercourse is simulated when it depicts explicit sexual intercourse which gives the appearance of the consummation of sexual intercourse, normal or perverted. 
(b)  Whoever sells or distributes or disseminates or imports or loans or possesses with the intent to sell, or exhibit, prints or publishes for the purpose of selling or distributing a book, pamphlet, ballad, printed paper, phonographic record, tape record, print, picture, movie, figure, image, or description which depicts or describes: 
(1)  Patently offensive representations or descriptions of ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated; or 
(2)  Patently offensive representations or descriptions of masturbation, excretory functions, lewd exhibitions of the genitals; 
    shall be fined in the amount not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) or be imprisoned not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
(c)  Whoever performs or promotes the performance of any act which depicts or describes: 
(1)  Patently offensive representations or descriptions of ultimate sexual acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated; or 
(2)  Patently offensive representations or descriptions of masturbation, excretory functions, lewd exhibition of the genitals; 
    shall be fined in the amount not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) or be imprisoned not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. of 1-20-75, §§ 1-3) 
Sec. 14-25. - Spray paint; sales to certain persons prohibited. 
(a)  Spray paint means any paint or pigmented substance in an aerosol or similar spray container or intended for use in an aerosol or similar spray container. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale to any person under sixteen (16) years of age any spray paint or hobby kit or any similar kind of kit containing spray paint unless such person is accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be subject to a fine not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. of 4-15-85, § 1) 
State Law reference- Formerly, § 14-25 was derived from ordinances adopted Mar. 5, 1945, § 35; Dec. 29, 1960; and contained misdemeanor penalty provisions applicable to certain sections of Ch. 14. In accordance with the city's request, such provisions have been redesignated as § 14-75. 
Sec. 14-26. - Defacing or placing graffiti on property; penalty. 
(a)  Any person who defaces or places graffiti on any public property or private property of another by any means whatever shall be subject to a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a maximum period of ninety (90) days, or both. 
(b)  Any person who is the first person to provide information to the city or any enforcement officer, which information leads to a conviction of a violation of this section, shall be given a reward of two hundred dollars ($200.00) by the city, except that employees of the city, and the immediate families of said employees, shall not be eligible for said reward. 
(Ord. of 4-15-85, § 1; Ord. No. 04-06-09-2, § 1, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 14-27. - Removal of graffiti required; enforcement, penalty. 
(a)  Any person who permits graffiti to remain on his or her property for a period of more than seven (7) days, after notice to remove the same, shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) in addition to other costs outlined in the section. It shall be the duty of a citation officer duly appointed by the chief executive officer to enforce this section. 
(b)  The notice given to a property owner provided for in subsection (a) shall be in writing and sent via certified mail to the address of the owner or owners of the subject property as said address appears in the records of the city assessor. Said notice shall be sent by the chief executive officer. 
(c)  The notice given to a property owner pursuant to this section shall identify the property in violation, shall generally describe the location of the graffiti to be removed, and shall direct that the graffiti be abated within seven (7) days of receipt of said notice. The notice shall state that, in the event the responsible party fails to abate the graffiti, the city may take any and all steps necessary to abate the violation and may bill the responsible party for the costs of said abatement or lien the subject property for the cost of said abatement. The notice shall state that the responsible party may appeal the notice by filing a written notice of appeal within seven (7) days of receiving said notice with the chief executive officer. 
(d)  If the property owner fails to abate the graffiti as required by the notice of violation, the city may take all steps necessary to abate the graffiti, and may bill the owner for the costs of said abatement, or may place a lien against the subject property equal to the cost of said abatement. The city or its authorized private contractor is expressly authorized to enter private property and abate graffiti thereon in accordance with this section. The city police department shall assist in the enforcement of this section. 
(Ord. of 5-20-85, § 1; Ord. No. 07-07-03-17; Ord. of 9-15-08, § 1) 
Sec. 14-28. - Tobacco vending machines. 
    No person shall dispense, or cause to be dispensed, cigarettes, tobacco or smokeless tobacco products from vending machines at any location within the city. A vending machine means a machine used for the purpose of automatically merchandising packaged cigarettes, tobacco or smokeless tobacco products after the proper amount of payment by the purchaser. 
(Ord. No. 09-04-01-2, § II) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-04-01-2, § II, did not specify manner of inclusionl hence, inclusion as section 14-28 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 14-29. - Curfew-Definitions. 
    Loiter or loitering shall mean remaining idle in essentially one location; to be dilatory, to tarry, or to dawdle; and shall include, but not be limited to, standing around, hanging out, sitting, kneeling, sauntering or prowling. 
    Minor shall mean any person under the age of sixteen (16) years. 
Sec. 14-30. - Minors on streets. 
    No minor shall loiter, idle, congregate or otherwise be in or on any public street, highway, alley, park or other public place between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. for the months of September to June or between the hours of 12 midnight to 5:00 a.m. for the months of July and August, unless such minor is: 
(1)  Accompanied by his parent or guardian or some other adult delegated by the parent or guardian to accompany such minor; 
(2)  In any such place in connection with and required by some legitimate work, trade, profession or occupation in which such minor is engaged; 
(3)  On an emergency errand or other legitimate business directed by his parent or guardian; 
(4)  Returning home from a dance, party, or other function held under the auspices of a public, private, or parochial school, or any other function approved by the Police Department; or 
(5)  During the hours of employment in some occupation or business in which such minor may be lawfully engaged under State Law. 
Sec. 14-31. - Responsibility of parent or guardian. 
    No parent or guardian of a minor shall permit such minor to be on any public street, highway, alley, park or public place between the hours of 10:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. for the months of September to June, or between the hours of 12 midnight to 5:00 a.m. for the months of July and August, except as stated above. 
Sec. 14-32. - Violations and penalties. 
    Every parent or guardian who shall allow any child to loiter in violation of this ordinance [sections 14-29-14-31] shall be guilty of a violation and upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each violation. 
    It shall not constitute a defense that such parent or guardian did not have knowledge of the presence of the minor upon any of the streets, alleys or public places. 
    Every minor charged with loitering shall be referred to the Juvenile Court of the Superior Court for the Judicial District of New London in accordance with Connecticut General Statutes, Section 46b-120. 
Sec. 14-33. - Bazaars and raffles. 
(a)  The city hereby adopts the provisions of General Statute § 7-170 to § 7-186, inclusive, as may be amended, for permitting and regulating bazaars and raffles within the city. 
(b)  The fee schedule for the classes of permits issued shall be established by the mayor or his designee, provided that said fees are consistent with the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-18-7, § 1) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 03-05-18-7, § 1, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 14-33 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 14-34-14-74. - Reserved. 
Sec. 14-75. - Chapter violations and penalties generally. 
    Every person who shall violate any of the provisions of any section of this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and except where otherwise provided shall pay a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 35; Ord. of 12-29-60) 
Chapter 15 - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Residence requirement. 
    Officers and employees of the city appointed by the city manager, or the appointment of whom is authorized by the city manager, shall remain bona fide residents of the city during their entire term of employment, except that the council may by a two-thirds vote of all members of the council, after reference to and report by the administration committee of the council, may by resolution suspend this requirement in specific cases. 
(Ord. of 8-7-72, § 2) 
Sec. 15-2. - Bonds of officers and employees-Required, amounts. 
(a)  Each officer and employee listed in subsection (b) hereof shall give bond, with surety, conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office or employment as the case may be, and to indemnify the city against loss from the unfaithfulness, carelessness or default of any such officer or employee. 
(b)  The amount of bond to be given by each officer and employee shall be as follows: 
City manager ..... $1,000.00 
Director of finance ..... 3,000.00 
City treasurer ..... 50,000.00 
Each clerk and employee in the city treasurer's office ..... 5,000.00 
Tax collector ..... 50,000.00 
Each clerk and employee in the tax collector's office ..... 5,000.00 
Assessor ..... 1,000.00 
Cash cashier ..... 10,000.00 
Clerk of police court, city court, and small claims court ..... 2,000.00 
Assistant clerk of police court, city court and small claims court ..... 1,000.00 
Commissioner of charity ..... 5,000.00 
City and town clerk ..... 1,000.00 
Assistant city and town clerk ..... 1,000.00 
Purchasing agent ..... 3,000.00 
Parking meter collector and inspector ..... 1,000.00 
Each city sheriff, not a member of the police force ..... 5,000.00 
Each city sheriff, member of the police force ..... 1,000.00 
City hall investigator ..... 1,000.00 
Fire marshal ..... 1,000.00 
Health inspector ..... 1,000.00 
Building inspector and sealer of weights and measures ..... 1,000.00 
(Ord. of 1-3-49, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 15-3. - Same-Surety; conditions, premiums. 
(a)  The surety on each of such bonds shall be a surety company authorized to issue indemnity surety bonds, and having an office and license to do business in this state. The bond to be given by each officer and employee and the surety thereon shall be approved in each instance by the council. No person shall enter upon the discharge of his duties as an officer or employee of the city without first giving the bond hereinbefore required of him, nor until such bond and the surety thereon have been approved by the council. Whenever the interest of the city so demands, or the statutes of the State of Connecticut so require, the council may require an additional bond from any officer or employee in such amounts, and with such surety as the council may determine, or the statutes of the State of Connecticut shall require. Failure to give a required bond shall cause a vacancy in office or employment as the case may be. 
(b)  All premiums on bonds shall be paid by the city except the premium on the bonds of the city sheriffs who are not members of the police force, which premiums shall be paid by such city sheriffs. 
(c)  Whenever a receipt, memorandum or certificate is issued renewing any such bond, such receipt, memorandum or certificate shall be submitted to the council for its action. 
(d)  Such bonds and the renewals thereof shall be kept in the custody of the director of finance, except the bond and the renewals thereof of the director of finance, which shall be kept in the custody of the city manager. 
(e)  The director of finance shall keep a record giving the name of the officer, or other person for whom the bond is issued, the name of the company issuing or joining in such bond, the number, date and time of expiration of the same, and shall also keep a record of all renewals thereof. 
(f)  It shall be the duty of the city manager from time to time to obtain the premium rates for such bonds from the various companies and present same to the council whenever the council shall have before it the question of the approval of any such bond. 
(g)  The director of finance shall give the city manager two weeks' notice of the expiration of any such bond, and the city manager shall cause necessary steps to be taken to obtain renewal thereof and submit same to the council together with premium rates in all companies and all obtainable data as to the responsibility of the company issuing such renewal, for its consideration before the expiration of the bond proposed to be renewed. 
(Ord. of 1-3-49, § 3) 
Sec. 15-4. - Reserved. 
Sec. 15-5. - Salaries of officers and employees. 
(a)  The salary of the director of law, the city clerk and assistant city clerk shall be fixed by the council and shall be such sum per annum as may be appropriated by the council for that purpose. 
(b)  The salary of other officers and employees of the city, except those fixed by the board of education, shall be fixed by the chief executive officer but shall not exceed in amount the appropriations made by the council for such purpose. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, §§ 2, 3; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Sec. 15-6. - Sick leave-Allowance. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby authorized to grant leave of absence on account of illness, without any deduction in pay, to any policeman, fireman, regular full-time employee in the Public Works Department and any other regular full-time employee of the city, except an employee whose compensation is fixed by the board of education. 
(b)  In making such allowance for sick leave the city manager is directed to examine the record of employment of any such employee and the total leave with pay for the entire employment period shall not exceed twelve (12) days for each year that such employee has been in the regular full-time employment of the city, and in no event shall it exceed one hundred and twenty (120) days in any one fiscal year. 
(Ord. of 4-5-37, § 1; Ord. of 9-3-63, § 1) 
Sec. 15-7. - Same-Right additional to disability benefits. 
    The right to sick leave as above granted is in addition to the benefits which any employee of the city is entitled to by reason of disability incurred in line of duty. 
(Ord. of 4-5-37, § 2) 
Sec. 15-8. - Private employment of police, firemen. 
    No paid member of the police or fire departments of the City of New London shall accept employment on private premises except as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. of 11-17-41, § 1) 
Sec. 15-9. - Assignment of police, firemen to special duty-Authorized. 
    The heads of the police and fire departments of the City of New London shall assign any members of their departments to special duty on private premises whenever, in the city manager's opinion, said special duty is necessary for the preservation of public health and safety. 
(Ord. of 11-17-41, § 2) 
Sec. 15-10. - Same-Obtaining, paying for special duty. 
(a)  Owners of private premises desiring the assignment of a member of the police or fire department to special duty on their premises shall make application for said assignments to the heads of the police and fire department, as the case may be, and if consent is received for said special duty, shall pay the head of the police or fire department for such service at the rate as stipulated by the existing, applicable union contract provisions establishing the rates for private jobs plus a twenty (20) per cent surcharge. All monies collected by the heads of the police or fire department, as provided herein, shall be remitted in full to the treasurer of the City of New London. 
(b)  When such service shall be rendered to a permittee of the liquor control commission of the State of Connecticut, payment for said service shall be at the rate as stipulated by existing, applicable union contract provisions establishing the rates for private jobs plus a twenty (20) per cent surcharge. 
(c)  When such special duty shall be performed on New Year's Eve, payment for said service shall be at the rate as stipulated by the existing, applicable union contract provisions multiplied by 1.625 plus a twenty (20) per cent surcharge. 
(Ord. of 11-17-41, § 3; Ord. of 11-16-64, § 1; Ord. of 12-15-69, § 1; Ord. of 7-20-81, § 1) 
Sec. 15-11. - Same-Compensation, applicability of departmental rules and regulations. 
(a)  Policemen or firemen assigned to special duty as provided herein shall receive compensation at the rate as stipulated by the existing applicable union contract provisions establishing the rates for such special duty. 
(b)  Payments for special duty are to be made by the treasurer of the City of New London. The balance of any sums collected under the provisions hereof are to be retained by the City of New London to be applied toward the cost of compensation insurance and other incidental expenses connected herewith. 
(c)  Any member of the police or fire department assigned to special duty shall be subject to the rules and regulations governing the performance of regular duty in these departments. When such special duty shall be performed for a permittee of the liquor control commission of the State of Connecticut, policemen or firemen assigned to such duty shall receive compensation at the rate as stipulated by the existing, applicable union contract provisions establishing rates for such special duty. When such special duty shall be performed on New Year's Eve, policemen or firemen assigned to such duty shall receive compensation at the rate as stipulated by the existing, applicable union contract provisions multiplied by 1.625 plus a twenty (20) per cent surcharge. 
(Ord. of 11-17-41, § 4; Ord. of 11-16-64, § 1; Ord. of 12-15-69, § 1; Ord. of 7-20-81, § 2) 
Sec. 15-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An ordinance of April 18, 1977, repealed an ordinance of April 24, 1922, pertaining to a sealer of weights and measures, codified as § 15-12. 
Sec. 15-13. - Special constables; appointment, compensation, duties. 
(a)  The city manager may appoint, in writing, for such terms of service as he may determine not exceeding one year from the date of such appointment, such number of special constables as he may deem necessary to preserve the public peace and order, who shall have the powers of constables to serve criminal process and arrest for crimes or misdemeanors within the limits of the city or upon any property of the city outside of the limits thereof, and to bring offenders before the proper authority. Such constables shall receive such compensation as the city manager may determine. The city manager may at any time revoke any such appointment. 
(b)  The city manager may, upon the written application of any financial, mercantile, manufacturing, or amusement concern or of any cemetery corporation or association, located within the limits of the city, appoint, in writing, any suitable person designated by such concern, corporation or association, as special constable, who shall in the buildings and upon the grounds of such concern, corporation or association, or in the immediate vicinity thereof, have the powers of constables to serve criminal process and arrest for crimes or misdemeanors and to bring offenders before the proper authority. Such constables shall receive no pay from the city for their services as such constables. The application of any such concern, corporation, or association shall contain an agreement that it will save the city harmless from any damages or costs because of any act or omission of such constable in connection with the performance of his duties as such constable. 
(c)  The city manager may appoint, in writing, the janitor or watchman of any school or public building as a special constable, who shall, in and about such school or building and the grounds connected therewith or in the immediate vicinity thereof, have the powers of constables to serve criminal process and arrest for crimes and misdemeanors and to bring offenders before the property authority. Such constables shall receive no pay from the city for their services as such constables. 
(d)  All constables appointed under the provisions of this section shall be citizens of this state, shall be sworn to the faithful discharge of their duties, shall wear, when on duty, a shield bearing the words "Special Constable, New London," shall be under the jurisdiction of the police department and shall be removable at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(e)  The shields to be worn by special constables when on duty shall be furnished by the city manager, who shall require all special constables appointed in accordance with subsection (b), and all special constables appointed for one year's service to deposit the sum of five dollars ($5.00) before receiving said shield, which deposit shall be refunded upon the resignation of, or revocation of the appointment of, or expiration of the term of service of any such special constable and the return of said shield. 
(Ord. of 12-5-21, §§ 1-5) 
Sec. 15-14. - Justices of the peace; number. 
    The number of justices of the peace for the city shall not exceed one hundred fifty (150). 
(Ord. of 6-6-88, § 1) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-06-88-3, § 1, adopted June 6, 1988, did not specify manner of codification; hence, such provisions have been designed as § 15-14 by the editor. 
Sec. 15-15. - GASB 45 retirement health care trust. 
A.  There shall be established a GASB 45 retirement health care trust. 
B.  Said trust shall be funded by appropriations of the city council as they deem appropriate. 
C.  The finance director of the city shall be tasked to coordinate the establishment of said trust and selection of a trustee with city council's approval. 
D.  The finance director shall on a yearly basis provide to the city council a report of the trust's activities and recommendations for future funding. 
(Ord. No. 02-22-11-3, § 1, 2-22-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-22-11-3, § 1, adopted February 22, 2011, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 15-15 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 15-16-15-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9. 

Sec. 15-25. - Organized. 
    There shall be in and for the city a fire department consisting of a chief, a deputy chief, such drivers and other employees as the chief, subject to the approval of the city council, may find necessary, and the members of the following companies of volunteer firemen; viz: F.L. Allen Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, Niagara Engine Company No. 1, W.B. Thomas Hose Company No. 3, C.L. Ockford Hose Company No. 5, Pequot Hose Company No. 6, and Northwest Hose Company No. 7. 
(Ord. of 4-17-22, § 1; Ord. of 6-16-69, § 1; Res. No. 04212008) 
Sec. 15-26. - Paid fire forces; organization, personnel. 
    The paid fire forces of the City of New London shall consist of one chief, one deputy chief, and such other officers as the council may from time to time designate, and such number of regular and substitute firemen and other employees as the city manager, with the approval of the council, may from time to time determine. The chief and deputy chief shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Ord. of 4-20-64, § 1; Res. No. 04212008) 
Sec. 15-27. - Authority of chief. 
    Subject to the general supervision of the city manager the chief shall have charge and control of the department, all fire apparatus of all real and personal property and all volunteer companies used for the purpose of the department. 
(Ord. of 4-17-22, § 2; Res. No. 04212008) 
Sec. 15-28. - Duties, responsibilities of chief. 
    The chief shall have power to suspend temporarily for cause any member of the paid force under him but shall immediately report such suspension to the chief executive officer. 
(Ord. of 6-7-43, § 2; Res. No. 04212008) 
Sec. 15-29. - Appointment, duties, responsibilities, authority of deputy chief. 
    The deputy chief, in the absence or disability of the chief, shall act as chief and shall assume all the powers, duties, and responsibilities of that office. 
(Ord. of 6-7-43, § 3; Ord. of 11-16-53; Res. No. 04212008) 
Sec. 15-30. - Powers of chief, deputy chief as police officers. 
    See C.G.S. § 7-313e. 
(Ord. of 4-17-22, § 3; Res. No. 04212008) 
Secs. 15-31-15-34. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Res. No. 04212008 repealed §§ 15-31, 15-32 and 15-34 in their entirety, which pertained to captain, lieutenants; appointment, duties, duties of city electrician, and substitute fireman; appointment, qualifications, respectively, and derived from an ordinance of June 7, 1943, §§ 4-6; an ordinance of May 16, 1949; an ordinance of November 16, 1953; an ordinance of June 14, 1956, an ordinance of February 18, 1957; an ordinance of January 3, 1961; an ordinance of April 20, 1964, § 1; an ordinance of June 17, 1968; an ordinance of May 21, 1973; and ordinance of July 6, 1976, and an ordinance of August 16, 1976, § 1. 
Sec. 15-35. - Appointments to paid force. 
    Refer to personnel rules and regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-7-43, § 7; Ord. of 6-17-46; Ord. of 2-18-57; Ord. of 6-21-65, § 1; Res. No. 04212008) 
Secs. 15-36-15-39. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Res. No. 04212008 repealed §§ 15-36-15-38, which pertained to use of substitute firemen, vacations in paid force, and payment of salary during disability of illness, respectively, and derived from an ordinance of June 7, 1943, §§ 9-10; an ordinance of September 19, 1949, and an ordinance of January 3, 1961. 
Sec. 15-40. - Volunteer fire companies-Organization. 
    Each company of volunteer firemen shall be officered by a foreman, an assistant foreman and a second assistant foreman elected by the company subject to the approval of the chief executive officer. Each company may adopt such by-laws for the government of its affairs and specifying and regulating the duties of its officers and members as may be approved by the chief executive officer. 
(Ord. of 4-17-22, § 5) 
Sec. 15-41. - Same-Qualifications of members. 
    No person shall hereafter become a member of any fire company unless he is a resident of the city, is at least eighteen (18) years of age, and his membership in the company is approved by the chief executive officer. No member of any fire company shall be expelled by the company except upon the approval of the fire chief. 
(Ord. of 4-17-22, § 6; Res. No. 04212008) 
Sec. 15-42. - Same-Suspension of member. 
    Any officer or member of any fire company who shall refuse or neglect to obey or execute any order given him by his superior officer in connection with any duty of such officer, or member as a part of the fire department of the city shall be subject to immediate suspension by such superior officer, which suspension shall continue until revoked by the fire chief. 
(Ord. of 4-17-22, § 7; Res. No. 04212008) 
Sec. 15-43. - Duty to operate emergency ambulance service; fees. 
    The fire department shall operate an emergency ambulance service using such equipment and personnel as are available for such purpose. 
(Ord. of 6-20-66, § 1; Ord. of 7-17-72, § 1; Res. No. 04212008) 
Secs. 15-44-15-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-04-88-1, § 1, adopted Apr. 4, 1988, repealed §§ 15-56-15-70, being the substantive sections of Art. III, Police department, Ord. No. 04-04-88-2, § 1, adopted Apr. 4, 1988, added new provisions pertaining to the same subject matter and designated as §§ 15-56-15-60 to read as herein set out. Prior to repeal, former Art. III was derived from ordinances enacted on the following dates: 
Date Sec. Date Sec. Date Sec. 6-19-33 1-6, 11-19-56 - 6-21-65 1 9-13, 12-29-60 - 12-18-67 1 16, 17 2-6-61 - 8-19-68 1 6-3-46 - 12-17-62 1 5-21-73 1 6-17-46 - 2-3-64 - 3-18-74 1 9-19-49 - 3-15-65 1 10-6-75 1  
Cross reference- Police/community relations committee, § 2-42; crime prevention and protection, Ch. 7.1; offenses generally, Ch. 14. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-56. - Organization.
