(6)  Hearings. After there is a finding of probable cause, hearings shall be open to the public. Oral evidence shall be taken under oath. The respondent shall have the right to be represented by counsel, to present evidence and to examine and cross examine witnesses. Hearings shall be recorded by a stenographer or a recording device provided by the board. If the board does not provide a stenographer, the complainant or respondent may employ a stenographer at his/her own expense. If a transcript is made, a copy shall be made available to the other party upon payment [of] one-half the cost of obtaining the transcript. 
(7)  Finding. No finding of violation of this Code shall be made except upon concurring vote of five (5) members of the board. The chairman shall render the finding of the board within thirty (30) days after conclusion of the hearing. A copy of the finding shall be sent to the complainant, the respondent, and the city. 
(8)  Board initiated complaints. Upon a concurring vote of five (5) or more members, the board may initiate its own complaints. In doing so, it is not required that the complaint be sworn. 
(Ord. No. 06-20-11-1, § 1, 6-20-11) 
Sec. 15-212. - Sanctions. 
    Upon finding of a violation of any provision of the code, the board may take appropriate disciplinary action, as permitted by law or take no action, or may recommend to the appropriate appointing or managerial authority, a reprimand, reduction in rank or grade, suspension, dismissal or other disciplinary action. The authority affected will report within thirty (30) days to the board of ethics the action taken or lack of action and the reasons therefore. 
(Ord. No. 06-20-11-1, § 1, 6-20-11) 
Sec. 15-213. - Secretary of the board of ethics. 
    The secretary of the board shall record the minutes of the meetings and any hearings and shall supervise the transcription of the tapes. The secretary shall prepare minutes of the meetings. The secretary shall provide administrative support as necessary to conduct the business of the board. 
(Ord. No. 06-20-11-1, § 1, 6-20-11) 
Sec. 15-214. - Distribution of code; appeals. 
(a)  Distribution of code. The director of personnel shall cause a copy of this code of ethics to be distributed to every public employee and public official within sixty (60) days after enactment of this code. Each new public employee shall be furnished a copy as part of their orientation process. A signed receipt recording same shall be maintained by the personnel department. 
    The city clerk shall cause notice to be given to all elected officials and members of the boards and agencies. 
(b)  Appeals. Any person aggrieved by any final decision of the board may appeal such decision in accordance with the provisions of Section 4-175 or Section 4-183 of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 06-20-11-1, § 1, 6-20-11) 
Chapter 16 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]

--- (1) ---

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Conflicting provisions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall prevail when at variance with the following Code provisions: Sections 5-1, 5-2; chapter 7, article VIII; sections 11-5, 14-16, 14-19, 15-87; chapter 18, article V. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 6) 
Secs. 16-2-16-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 16-15. - Established, membership. 
    There is hereby established a parks and recreation commission, consisting of nine (9) regular members and two (2) alternate members who shall be appointed by the city council in the first meeting of July and shall serve without compensation. Regular members shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years except that the initial term shall be staggered terms as follows: 
Three (3) members for three (3) years; two (2) members for two (2) years; and two (2) members for one year. Thereafter, at the expiration of the original term of office of each of the nine (9) members, each may be reappointed or his successor may be appointed for a term of three (3) years. 
    Alternate members shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years, and when seated shall have all the powers and duties of a regular member. 
    The director of recreation shall be an ex-officio member of the commission. 
(Ord. of 11-4-71, § 1; Ord. of 3-4-74, § 1; Ord. of 3-18-74, § 1; Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1; Ord. No. 07-02-07-1, § 1; Ord. No. 08-01-16-3, § 1) 
Sec. 16-16. - Functions. 
    The primary function of the commission is to serve as an advisory board and make recommendations to the council with respect to the policies, rules and regulations of the City of New London relative to the leisure time of its citizens. The recommendations may concern the planning establishment, conduct, maintenance, operation, and supervision of our public parks, playgrounds, athletic fields, recreation centers and other like facilities. The commission may also make recommendations with respect to fees and charges which it deems appropriate to partially defray the cost of providing recreational services and facilities. Additionally, the commission may make recommendations with respect to the capital improvement of our parks and recreation facilities, regarding the acquisition, operation, improvement and maintenance of existing and proposed facilities. 
(Ord. of 11-4-71, § 2) 
Sec. 16-17. - Organization, rules. 
    The commission shall organize by choosing from among its members, a chairman and secretary and shall have the power to determine its own rules of procedure. 
(Ord. of 11-4-71, § 3) 
Sec. 16-18. - Participation in selection of director. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall participate in the director selection process by constituting two (2) of the six (6) members of the interview panel. 
(Ord. of 11-4-71, § 4; Ord. of 7-7-86, § 2) 
Sec. 16-19. - Authority to receive gifts, bequests, donations. 
    The parks and recreation commission may also solicit or receive any gifts or bequests of money or other personal property, or any donations to be applied, principal or income, for either temporary or permanent use for playgrounds or other recreational purposes, subject to the approval and the appropriation of such gifts, bequests or donations, by the council. 
(Ord. of 11-4-71, § 5) 
Sec. 16-20. - Duty to submit reports. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall make to the municipality full and complete annual and other required reports and may also make reports requested by other agencies. 
(Ord. of 11-4-71, § 6) 
Secs. 16-21-16-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENT OF RECREATION AND PARKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 16-32. - Established. 
    There shall be in and for the city a department of recreation and parks. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 1) 
Sec. 16-33. - Responsibility. 
    The department of recreation and parks shall be responsible for the operation and use of public parks and recreation facilities. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 1; Ord. of 4-28-86, § 1) 
Sec. 16-34. - Director. 
    The department of recreation and parks shall be under the charge of a director of recreation who shall be appointed by the chief executive officer. The director shall have primary authority and responsibility for regulation and supervision of municipal parks areas and related recreational activities under the jurisdiction of the department of recreation and parks. The director and his assistants will regulate the use of picnic and recreational facilities so as to prevent congestion and shall distribute patrons of the park over the park area in order to ensure the maximum use of park areas and in behalf of the comfort of the patrons. All patrons must, at all times, comply with the directions of the director and his assistants. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 4-28-86, § 2; Ord. No. 10-03-11-2, § 1, 10-3-11) 
Secs. 16-35-16-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 16-41. - Use of parks by social groups; deposit; exception for city sponsored events. 
(a)  Locally-based political, fraternal, religious and social groups of fifty (50) or more persons shall apply to the parks and recreation commission, through the director of recreation, to use city parks, playgrounds, and the city's sports complex, with the exception of Ocean Beach Park, McKinley Park, and the city's Waterfront Park and Parade Plaza, for nonprofit events. Non-locally based political, fraternal, religious and social groups of fifty (50) or more persons shall apply to the city council to use city parks, playgrounds, and the city's sports complex, with the exception of Ocean Beach Park, McKinley Park, and the city's Waterfront Park and Parade Plaza, for nonprofit events. Each group applying for use of a park or playground identified hereunder shall submit one hundred dollars ($100.00) as a deposit to be used to refurbish and/or maintain the condition of the facility after use by the group. If a portion of none of the deposit is required to place the facility back into the condition it was prior to use, and to discard all debris in the surrounding areas, a refund will be made. 
(b)  Locally based groups under fifty (50) persons shall apply to the parks and recreation commission, through the director of recreation, to use city parks, playgrounds, and the city's sports complex, with the exception of Ocean Beach Park, McKinley Park, and the city's Waterfront Park and Parade Plaza, for nonprofit events. Non-locally based groups of less than fifty (50) persons shall apply to the city council to use city parks, playgrounds, and the city's sports complex, with the exception of Ocean Beach Park, McKinley Park, and the city's Waterfront Park and Parade Plaza, for nonprofit events. 
(c)  City sponsored recreation programs and non-fund-raising events are not subject to the deposit requirement for the use of city owned parks, playgrounds and the city's sports complex. The director of recreation shall coordinate and schedule such events. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 3; Ord. of 4-28-86, § 3; Ord. of 7-7-86, § 1; Ord. No. 02-05-18-8, § 1) 
Sec. 16-42. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former § 16-42, which pertained to the application of article to Captain's Walk, and derived from an ordinance adopted July 15, 1974, § 5, has been deleted at the direction of the city. 
Sec. 16-43. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter or idle in any public park or beach during the hours from sunset until sunrise of the following day and during such hours no person shall enter, remain upon, or use any part of any public park or beach, except that the walks and drives of any such public park may be used for the purpose of traveling through such park. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Sec. 16-44. - Use of vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any commercial vehicle into any park except on business of the department of recreation and parks, or to give instruction to any person in driving an automobile at the rate of speed exceeding fifteen (15) miles per hour, or to drive or propel any automobile, bicycle or other vehicle except on regular park roads, or to clean or polish cars in any park, or to drain any crankcase, or to park any car off any park road except in areas designated for public parking. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 20. 
Sec. 16-45. - Dogs to be leashed; horses prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to take any dog into any public area except on a leash. For purposes of this section, "public area" shall include, but not be limited to, any public grounds, streets, highways, rights-of-way, sidewalks, parkways, parks or playgrounds. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to any city police department K-9 units. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride horseback in any park or playground. 
(d)  A violation of any subsection of this section shall constitute an infraction. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4; Ord. No. 03-02-15-2, § 1) 
Editor's note- Connecticut General Statutes 46a-44 allows access of guide and assistance dogs to modes of public transportation and in places of public accommodation including public parks and beaches. 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 16-46. - Animals on public beaches or at large prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take any animal on any public beach or let it run at large and any such animal found at large will be impounded at the public pound. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Editor's note- Connecticut General Statutes 46a-44 allows access of guide and assistance dogs to modes of public transportation and in places of public accommodation including public parks and beaches. 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 16-47. - Entertainment and speeches. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to provide any music or entertainment or make or cause to be made any public speech or address except in accordance with section 16-34 or by permission from the director of recreation. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4; Ord. of 4-28-86, § 4) 
Sec. 16-48. - Peddling, soliciting, advertising prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall engage in the vending or hawking in any park of the city of any goods, wares, or other merchandise without first obtaining a license therefore from the chief of police and approval of the city council. It shall be unlawful for any person to display any sign for advertisement of any nature, except that a sign or banner of a business or product that is sponsoring an activity in the park may be allowed upon approval of the city council. 
(b)  The city police department and the chief executive officer, or his duly authorized agent, shall be responsible for the enforcement of this section. When it has been determined that a violation has occurred it shall constitute an infraction of a local ordinance and shall be prosecuted as such. 
(c)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined not more than $100.00 for each occurrence. Each day on which a violation occurs or continues after the time for correction of the violation given in any order has elapsed shall be considered a separate violation of this section. 
(d)  If any provision of this section or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held to be invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of any other part of this section which can be given effect without the invalid provisions of applications; and to this end, the provisions of this section and the various applications thereof are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4; Ord. No. 07-07-03-1, § 1) 
Cross reference- Businesses, trades and professions, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 16-49. - Distributing or posting written matter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute any circulars, cards or written matter, or post, plaster or affix any placard, notice or sign without permission from the director of recreation. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4; Ord. of 4-28-86, § 5) 
Sec. 16-50. - Discharge of firearms prohibited; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or have any firearms or fireworks in any park, but this section shall not apply to display of fireworks by municipal authorities. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Sec. 16-51. - Fires. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to kindle, build, maintain or use a fire in any park except in fireplaces provided for the purpose or under special permit. Any fire shall be continuously under the care and direction of a competent person over eighteen (18) years of age from the time it is kindled until it is extinguished, and no fire shall be built beneath the branches of any trees or in any underbrush, and no person shall throw away or discard any lighted match, cigar or cigarette within, on or against any building, structure, car, vehicle or enclosure, or under any tree or in underbrush or grass. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9. 
Sec. 16-52. - Boating in bathing area prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring a boat of any kind in the bathing area except such boating as is necessary to keep such areas properly protected and policed. The bathing area includes the water adjacent to and within three hundred fifty (350) feet of a bathing beach. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Cross reference- Boats, docks and waterways, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 16-53. - Bathing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bathe, wade or swim in any waters under the jurisdiction of the department of recreation and parks except at such times and in such places as the department of recreation and parks may designate as bathing areas, and then only when decently and modestly clothed. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Cross reference- Boats, docks and waterways, Ch. 5; immodest conduct while in bathing costume or upon bathing beaches in public parks, § 14-6. 
Sec. 16-54. - Use of bathhouses required for changing to swimming attire. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change from street clothes to swimming attire in any park or beach except in such bathing houses or dressing rooms as may be maintained by the department of recreation and parks. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Cross reference- Public bathhouses, Ch. 7, Art. VIII; dressing, undressing in vehicles on public streets or parks prohibited, § 14-5. 
Sec. 16-55. - Fishing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fish in any bathing area from any bridge, pier, dock, bulkhead or other structure along the edge of, or extending into or over any waters under the supervision of the department of recreation and parks, unless a sign installed by the city indicates fishing is permitted. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Cross reference- Boats, docks and waterways, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 16-56. - Littering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit or leave any litter or rubbish in any park or on any beach except in established receptacles. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Sec. 16-57. - Intoxicating liquors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have intoxicating liquors or to be intoxicated on beaches and game areas. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 16-58. - Use of glass and metal containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any glass or metal containers on any beach, except in designated picnicking areas. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Sec. 16-59. - Camping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to camp in any park area except under permit and at such particular places and for such specified periods as may be designated. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Sec. 16-60. - Injury to property or vegetation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, misuse or abuse park property, or to injure trees, shrubs or plants in any park. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Sec. 16-61. - Destruction of signs and protective devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, remove or destroy any sign or notice or protective device placed in any park by the department of recreation and parks. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Sec. 16-62. - Annoyance of persons and animals; committing of nuisances. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to annoy other persons or to disturb the animals, birds or fish, or commit any act of nuisance in any park. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 16-63. - Planting of trees or shrubs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to plant trees or shrubs without permission of the director of recreation. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4; Ord. of 4-28-86, § 6) 
Cross reference- Trees, Ch. 18, Art. V. 
Sec. 16-64. - Designated areas for active games. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to play baseball, golf, football or other active games except in areas established by the director of recreation for such purposes. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4; Ord. of 4-28-86, § 7) 
Sec. 16-65. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- City council action of February 16, 2010, repealed the former section 16-65 in its entirety, which pertained to gambling prohibited, and derived from an ordinance adopted July 15, 1974, § 4. 
Sec. 16-66. - Golf. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hit, drive or putt golf balls on any or all parks, playgrounds, baseball fields or school grounds, except in areas so specified. 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4) 
Sec. 16-67. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any violation of the provisions of this article will be subject to a penalty not less than five dollars ($5.00) and not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. of 7-15-74, § 4)

ARTICLE II. - REGIONAL PLANNING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- For purposes of classification, and to facilitate inclusion of Ordinances of April 7, 1980, pertaining to coastal site plans, the editor has redesignated former §§ 17-1-17-3 as §§ 17-11-17-13 of a new Art. II of Ch. 17. 

Sec. 17-11. - Statutes relative to regional planning adopted, regional agency joined. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of section 8-31a of the General Statutes of Connecticut, Revision of 1958, the city hereby adopts sections 8-31a to 8-37a, inclusive, of the General Statutes of Connecticut, Revision of 1958, and joins the regional planning agency for the Southeastern Connecticut Planning Region as defined or redefined by the Connecticut Development Commission under the provisions of section 32-7 of the General Statutes. 
(Ord. of 4-19-65, § 1) 
Sec. 17-12. - Representatives on regional agency. 
    The city, having a population of 34,182 according to the federal census of 1960, shall have three (3) representatives on said agency. Pursuant to section 8-31a of the General Statutes, the planning board of the city, duly constituted by special act, is hereby authorized to appoint to the regional planning agency one (1) elector of the city for a term of two (2) years. The council of the city shall appoint to the agency two (2) electors of the city in the following manner: one (1) representative to serve one (1) year and one (1) representative to serve two (2) years. Thereafter all appointments shall be made for a period of two (2) years. Appointees under this section shall continue to serve after expiration of their terms until their successors are appointed and take office. Appointees may be reelected for successive terms. 
(Ord. of 4-19-65, § 2) 
Sec. 17-13. - Vacancies on regional agency. 
    Any representative who is absent from three (3) successive regular meetings of the regional planning agency and any intervening duly called special meetings thereof shall be considered to have resigned from said regional planning agency and the vacancy shall be filled by the appointing body until the term expires, except that the requirements of this section may be waived where illness or other extenuating circumstances makes it impossible for a representative to meet the attendance requirements of this section. 
(Ord. of 4-19-65, § 3) 
Secs. 17-14-17-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COASTAL DEVELOPMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Included herein as Art. III of Ch. 17 are two Ordinances of April 17, 1980. Said ordinances did not expressly amend this Code; hence, inclusion of § 1 of the first ordinances as § 17-21, and §§ 1 and 2 of the second ordinance as § 17-22, is at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Coastal Management Act, § 22a-90 et seq., Gen. Stats. 

Sec. 17-21. - Site plan review requirements; exceptions. 
    All buildings, uses, and structures fully or partially within the coastal boundary as defined by section 4 of Public Act 79-535 entitled "An Act Concerning Coastal Management" shall be subject to the coastal site plan review requirements and procedures in sections 11 through 15 of Public Act 79-535 with the exception of the following activities which are hereby exempted from coastal site plan review requirements under the authority of subsection (b) of section 15 of Public Act 79-535: 
(1)  Gardening, grazing and the harvesting of crops; 
(2)  Minor additions to or modifications of existing buildings or detached accessory buildings, such as garages and utility sheds; 
(3)  Construction of new or modification of existing structures incidental to the enjoyment and maintenance of residential property, including, but not limited to, walks, terraces, driveways, swimming pools, tennis courts, docks and detached accessory buildings; 
(4)  Construction of new or modification of existing on-premises fences, walls, pedestrian walks and terraces, underground utility connections, essential electric, gas, telephone, water and sewer service lines, signs and such other minor structures as will not substantially alter the natural character of coastal resources as defined by section 3(7) of Public Act 79-535 or restrict access along the public beach; 
(5)  Construction of an individual conforming single-family residential structure except in or within three hundred (300) feet of the following coastal resource areas as defined by section 3(7) of Public Act 79-535: tidal wetlands, coastal bluffs and escarpments, beaches and dunes; 
(6)  Activities conducted for the specific purpose of conserving or preserving soil, vegetation, water, fish, shellfish, wildlife and other coastal land and water resources. 
(Ord. of 4-7-80, § 1) 
Sec. 17-22. - Site plan review fee schedule; costs of public hearing before council. 
(a)  As prescribed in Public Act 79-535 of the State of Connecticut, an act concerning coastal management, the following fee schedule is hereby established with respect to site plan review: 
Type of Development Site Plan 
Review Fee (1) One- and two-family dwellings, per review ..... $25.00 (2) Multifamily and commercial developments: First $100,000.00, or portion thereof, for development costs (minimum fee) ..... 50.00 Each additional $100,000.00, or portion thereof, thereafter ..... 50.00  
(b)  All costs related to and resulting from any public hearing held by the city council shall be borne by the applicant. 
(Ord. of 4-7-80, §§ 1, 2) 
Secs. 17-23-17-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HISTORIC DISTRICTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- The Ordinance of September 15, 1980, from which this article is derived, did not expressly amend this Code; hence, codification as Art. IV of Ch. 17, §§ 17-41-17-44, is at the discretion of the editor. 
State Law reference- Establishment of historic districts by municipalities, § 7-147a et seq., Gen. Stats. 

Sec. 17-41. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article to promote the educational, cultural, economic and general welfare of the city through the preservation and protection of buildings, places and districts of historic interest within the city by maintenance of such landmarks in the history of architecture of the city, the state or nation, and through the development of appropriate settings for such buildings, places and districts. 
(Ord. of 9-15-80, § 3) 
Sec. 17-42. - District established; designation, boundaries. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of section 7-147c, Connecticut General Statutes, Revision of 1958, as amended, there shall be the following historic district within the city: Starr Street. The boundaries of this district are described as follows: 
Beginning at a point, said point being at the intersection of the westerly line of Green Street and the southerly of Starr Street; 
Thence, southerly along the westerly line of Green Street to the intersection of the southerly property line of 6 Starr Street; 
Thence, westerly along the southerly property line of properties on southerly side of Starr Street, to the intersection of the easterly line of Washington Street; thence, northerly along the easterly line of Washington Street to the point of intersection with the northerly property line of 44 Washington Street; 
Thence, easterly along the northerly property lines of the properties on the northerly side of Starr Street to the intersection of the westerly line of Green Street; thence southerly along the westerly line of Green Street to the intersection of the southerly line of Starr Street and the point of beginning. 
(Ord. of 9-15-80, § 1) 
Sec. 17-43. - Historic district commission-Established, functions. 
    There is hereby established an historic district commission which shall hereafter perform all the functions of the historic district study committee relative to the Starr Street District and otherwise administer the provisions of sections 7-147a to 7-147k, inclusive, of the Connecticut General Statutes, as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. of 9-15-80, § 2) 
Sec. 17-44. - Same-Membership, qualifications; terms of office; officers; alternate members; compensation. 
(a)  The historic district commission shall consist of five (5) members, who shall be electors of the city holding no salaried municipal office and whose terms of office shall be fixed by ordinance. The appointments to membership in the commission shall be so arranged that the term of at least one (1) of the members shall expire each year and their successors shall be appointed in like manner for terms of five (5) years. 
(b)  The commission shall elect annually a chairman, a vice-chairman and a clerk from its own number. 
(c)  Ordinances adopted hereunder may provide for the appointment in like manner of alternate members not exceeding in number the principal members. In case of inability to act, because of absence, sickness or self-interest, on the part of a member of the commission, his place shall be taken by an alternate member designated by the chairman. 
(d)  All members shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. of 9-15-80, § 4) 
Secs. 17-45-17-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FEES 

Sec. 17-51. - Schedule. 
(a)  Where the city planning and zoning commission, zoning board of appeals, or inland wetlands commission, upon recommendation of the director of the city office of development and planning ("director") and/or his/her designee, in its sole discretion, determines that additional expertise, technical assistance, or general assistance will be required in reviewing and evaluating an application before it, the city through the director and/or his/her designee may retain an expert for said technical review. 
(b)  The expense of the additional expertise and technical assistance shall be estimated by the director and/or his/her designee, based on a preliminary estimate prepared by a qualified party or expert, and the estimated cost of reviewing the application times one hundred fifty (150) percent shall be paid by the applicant and deposited with the city in a separate account segregated from other funds of said city. Such deposit shall be made prior to review of the application and/or submission to the planning and zoning commission, zoning board of appeals, or inland wetlands commission. If the city expenditures exceed the estimate the applicant shall submit additional funds within five (5) days upon receiving notice from the city. Any fees remaining after the completion of the application review will be returned to the applicant. 
(c)  Said qualified party or expert shall be chosen from a list kept by the director and/or his/her designee which shall be made up of persons who have given their names and resumes to the city as potential consultants. Notwithstanding, the qualified party or expert may be a person not on the list kept by the city if it is determined by the director and/or his/her designee, that all persons on the list have conflicts of interest, conflicts of schedules, or are not qualified in the field of expertise that is needed for a particular application. 
(d)  Upon completion of the technical review and final action by the planning and zoning commission, zoning board of appeals, or inland wetlands commission on the application, the director and/or his/her designee shall determine the costs incurred for the review and refund any excess monies to the applicant. Applicants shall not be responsible for costs incurred for technical assistance which exceed one hundred fifty (150) percent of the original estimate. 
(e)  Applications that are withdrawn prior to the publication of any legal notices or withdrawn prior to being placed on the agenda of a board or commission are entitled to a return of fifty (50) percent of the application fee. 
(f)  The city staff may charge an additional fee (up to the actual costs incurred) for those applications, which require the duplication of costs such as the publication of additional legal notices or multiple plan reviews by city staff. 
(g)  For projects which require the issuance of more than one approval from one of the commissions (i.e. a special permit that also requires a facade review) only one fee will be charged. The fee associated with the application that requires the higher fee shall apply. 
(h)  Every application, including a resubmission of a previously withdrawn application, will require a new fee. Not withstanding anything herein to the contrary, the commissions may, in cases where unusual circumstances exist waive all or a portion of any of the foregoing fees. Where the city or any agency of the city is the applicant, fees may be waived by the city council. 
(i)  If any application is made, other than those specifically cited above, the commissions may establish a reasonable fee for processing the application that is equivalent to the fee for similar applications listed above. 
(j)  Additional fees. In addition to the other fees set forth in this section, city staff may collect payment for direct costs of materials and services performed by professionals, other than city employees, including but not limited to specialized inspection, third party professional certifications, legal, stenographic and transcription services associated with an application, or require an applicant to provide certifications, inspections, and/or professional consultant reports at the applicant's expense. The payment of additional fees shall not prohibit the planning and zoning commission from requiring performance or forfeiture bonds to ensure the successful completion of all work as may be prescribed in the respectively applicable regulations. 
(k)  Fee schedule. The following fee schedule is established for applications to the commissions or its designated agents or officers.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Obstructing travel or passage upon public ways. 
    No person, except in accordance with the regulations of the city manager, shall place, keep or knowingly suffer to remain any box, bale, case, barrel, bundle, package, goods, merchandise, cart carriage vehicle, lumber, refuse, waste, rubbish, or any article, material, or thing of whatsoever kind or description upon any highway, street, sidewalk, or public place in said city, so as to obstruct, impede or cause inconvenience to public travel. No person shall loiter or idle upon any highway, sidewalk or bridge, or upon any fence or structure adjacent thereto so as to hinder or inconvenience travel or obstruct free passage. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 32) 
Sec. 18-2. - Awnings over sidewalks, minimum clearance. 
    No person shall place or keep over any sidewalk, any awning, unless the same shall be made of cloth or canvas, and supported by braces fastened to the building, nor unless every part of said awning, and of its supports, shall be at least seven (7) feet above the sidewalk. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 2) 
Sec. 18-3. - Extension of rope, wire or pole across street or highway. 
    No person shall suspend any rope, wire or pole, across any street or highway, without authority from the city manager. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 3) 
Sec. 18-4. - Doors, gates, shrubbery impeding public travel. 
    No person shall place or keep any door or gate which swings over any sidewalk. No person owning land abutting upon any highway, street, sidewalk or public place, in the city shall keep or maintain on said land any shrub, bush, hedge or tree so as to obstruct, impede or cause inconvenience to public travel. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 5; Ord. of 9-2-69, § 1) 
Sec. 18-5. - Open cellar-way, coal-hole, excavation; protection required. 
    No person shall leave open without proper protection, any cellar-way, door, coal-hole, or any excavation in any street or sidewalk. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 6) 
Sec. 18-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former section 18-6, which pertained to animal, vehicle standing upon crosswalk or sidewalk, and derived from an ordinance of March 5, 1945, § 11, has been deleted at the direction of the city. The user's attention is directed to section 20-20 of this Code, and Connecticut General Statutes § 14-251. 
Sec. 18-7. - Unlawful removal of dirt, turf, stone. 
    No person shall dig up or remove any dirt, turf or stone from any street, highway, park, sidewalk, crosswalk, burial ground, or public place, without authority from the city manager. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 1) 
Sec. 18-8. - Drains discharging waste into street. 
    No person shall place or keep any drain which discharges into or upon any street; or spout which discharges upon or over any sidewalk. All leader pipes or spouts of any building hereafter erected or the exterior of which is hereafter structurally altered, shall, when such building is located on any street containing an accessible storm drainage system, be connected to such storm drainage system. 
(Ord. of 3-5-45, § 4; Ord. of 4-5-48) 
Sec. 18-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-16-94-4, adopted May 16, 1994, repealed § 18-9 in its entirety, which pertained to using street stand to sell merchandise, and derived from an ordinance of March 5, 1945, § 7, and an ordinance of July 15, 1974, § 1. 
Cross reference- Businesses, trades and professions, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 18-10. - Using stand in Bates Woods Park to sell goods. 
    No person shall use any part of Bates Woods Park as a stand, from which to sell, or expose for sale, goods or other things, without authority of the council. 
(Ord. of 6-21-65, § 1) 
Cross reference- Business, trades and professions, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 18-11. - Use of construction equipment. 
(a)  No person who owns, operates or has charge of any power-operated shovel, crane, backhoe, bulldozer or other power-operated equipment with a boom or other part of which raises or lifts off the ground by means of power, or with a non-fixed mast, shall leave said equipment unattended by a competent operator unless said boom or said other part of such equipment is lowered and resting on the ground and any non-fixed mast or other vertical support member is rigidly secured to prevent movement, and the equipment is locked and properly secured to prevent accidental or unauthorized operation thereof. 
(b)  Such equipment, when wholly located within private property such that the equipment is not closer to any public street or public place of the city than the length of said boom or other raising or lifting part of said equipment, may be left rigged and raised if temporarily wedged, locked, or otherwise secured and if under the surveillance of a full-time security guard. 
(c)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense, not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a second offense, and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a third, or more, offenses; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. of 6-17-63, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 3-17-80, § 1) 
Sec. 18-12. - Moving buildings-Permission required. 
    Whenever any person shall desire to remove any building upon, or through any street or highway, he shall apply in writing to the city manager, for permission so to do, describing said building and the place where the same is situated, and to what location and through what streets it is proposed to remove the same, and the purpose for which said building is designed to be used. 
(Ord. of 1-3-61, § 1) 
Cross reference- Buildings and structural appurtenances, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 18-13. - Same-Grant of permission; bond, insurance required. 
    The city manager to whom such petition shall be referred, may, if in his judgment the public interest will not be prejudiced thereby, grant a license in writing therefor, specifying the time to be occupied in such removal and taking such security as may be sufficient to protect any public property which may be injured by such removal. Such security shall be by a bond with surety satisfactory to the city manager, and shall not be for a sum less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Such applicant shall procure and carry public liability insurance covering and protecting the applicant and the city against claims for personal injuries (including death) and damage to private property caused by or resulting from such removal, in an amount satisfactory to the city manager. 
(Ord. of 1-3-61, § 2) 
Sec. 18-14. - Same-Charges. 
    The fee for such license shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) a day for every day in which the streets shall be occupied, and in addition the applicant shall pay the city for each policeman required at his regular hourly rate, with a minimum of four (4) hours for each policeman. 
(Ord. of 1-3-61, § 3) 
Sec. 18-15. - Same-Appeal from denial of permission. 
    In the event that the city manager refuses to grant a license after application has been made to him in manner aforesaid, the person whose application has been thus denied may appeal such denial to the council, in writing, within thirty (30) days after such denial. 
(Ord. of 1-3-61, § 4) 
Sec. 18-16. - Construction of sidewalks, driveway ramps. 
    All sidewalks and driveway ramps hereafter laid shall be of Portland cement concrete construction and in accordance with City of New London standard specifications approved by the council and on file in the department of public works and utilities. Temporary driveway ramps of asphaltic concrete may be constructed at the sole expense of the owner in places abutting property used for residential purposes where no sidewalks and curbing exist adjacent to both sides of the temporary driveway ramp, but shall be replaced at such time as sidewalks are constructed adjacent to either side of said temporary driveway ramp. 
(Ord. of 1-4-1886, § 1; Ord. of 5-7-06; Ord. of 6-12-07; Ord. of 1-16-61; Ord. of 7-3-78, § 1) 
Sec. 18-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The former section 18-17, which pertained to sidewalk repairs and derived from Ord. No. 08-03-98-1, § 1, adopted August 3, 1998, has been deleted at the direction of the city. 
Sec. 18-18. - Pocket bikes. 
(a)  No person may operate any motorized scooter or pocket motorcycle within the limits of a public street or public sidewalk. 
(b)  No person may ride as a passenger in or upon a motor scooter or pocket motorcycle within the limits of a public street or public sidewalk. 
(c)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall receive a citation and be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(d)  In addition to the issuance of a citation and fine pursuant to subsection (c), any police officer who observes a violation of this section may cause the motorized scooter or pocket motorcycle in question to be removed from the public street or public sidewalk and into the custody of the city police department or to a storage facility at the owner's expense. Such motorized scooter or pocket motorcycle shall be held until such time as: 
(1)  All fines and removal costs are paid for; and 
(2)  Arrangements are made by a responsible adult for said motorized scooter or pocket motorcycle to be transported to private property. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the use of an electronic assistive mobility device, as defined by these ordinances, on any public street, right-of-way, sidewalk or public property. 
(Ord. No. 05-02-05-11, § 1, 5-2-05; Ord. No. 01-21-14-4, § 1, 1-21-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-02-05-11, § 1, adopted May 2, 2005, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 18-18 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 18-19. - Use of sidewalks. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provision of any other city ordinance, any person who operates a commercial business within the limits of the city may apply for a limited license from the city, through its office of development and planning, to use a portion of the city's sidewalk that abuts the commercial business for the placement of temporary seating and chairs for patrons, guests and invitees of said commercial business (hereinafter "license area"). 
(b)  This city, through its office of development and planning, shall have the ability to grant or deny a license under this section. However, applicants who have been denied a license by the office of development and planning, or who have not received a determination within thirty (30) days of submittal of application, may appeal to the city council for reconsideration. Any license granted by the city, through its office of development and planning, pursuant to this section shall be subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Use of the license area shall be limited to the placement of tables and/or chairs only. Tables shall not be made of glass, and no hooks, fasteners, or holes may be made or affixed to the sidewalk in the license area; 
(2)  Music and other entertainment is prohibited on the license area; 
(3)  The license area shall be properly enclosed with a barrier to separate patrons, guests, and invitees of the commercial business and the general public. The sufficiency of a barrier shall be determined by a representative from the office of development and planning in its sole discretion, provided that said barrier be no more than four (4) feet in height and no less than two (2) feet in height. Approved license area must provide a minimum width of four (4) feet six (6) inches to remain unobstructed on the public sidewalk for pedestrian foot traffic. Said measurement shall be from the face of curb to the start of barrier; 
(4)  Applicant shall provide the city with proof of adequate insurance, naming the city as an additional insured, to cover the use of the license area. Said insurance shall be for no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per incident or occurrence. Applicant shall indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all claims, costs, and damages as a result of the applicant's use of the license area; 
(5)  All tables, chairs, barriers, and other personal property of the applicant shall be completely removed from the license area at least twelve (12) hours prior to the National Weather Service predicted time of arrival of any storm event involving winds in excess of forty-five (45) miles per hour, snowfalls in excess of two (2) inches and/or flooding; 
(6)  Applicant shall abide by the rules and regulations of all municipal, state and federal boards and agencies that may have control and oversight of the applicant's commercial business; 
(7)  Applicant shall abide by all noise ordinances and regulations of the city and state; 
(8)  Applicant shall secure all necessary permits and approvals from the health district for the city prior to using the license area, if applicable; 
(9)  Applicant shall be responsible for the upkeep and maintenance of the license area while in use, and the license area shall be swept and/or cleaned on a daily basis; and 
(10)  Applicant shall be solely responsible for the security of all tables, chairs, and other personal property at all times. Method(s) of securing personal property shall be subject to approval by the office of development and planning. 
(c)  Upon the granting of a license under this section, the city and the applicant shall execute a written license agreement outlining all terms and conditions of said license and shall provide a plan or sketch drawn to scale illustrating the dimensions and layout of the tables and chairs to be positioned on the license area. 
(d)  The office of development and planning and/or the city council shall have the authority to terminate any license granted pursuant to this section in their sole discretion at any time with thirty (30) days written notice to the applicant. 
(e)  Any license granted under the authority of this section shall be personal to the applicant and may not be assigned or transferred to any other party without the express written consent of the city council. 
(f)  The office of development and planning, or its designee, shall enforce the terms and conditions of any license agreement issued pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 08-04-08-1, § 1, 8-4-08; Ord. No 09-16-13-1, § 1) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-04-08-1, § 1, adopted August 4, 2008, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as section 18-19 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 18-20. - Electronic assistive mobility devices. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Electronic assistive mobility device shall mean a self-balancing, two (2) non-tandem wheeled device, designed to transport one person, with an electric propulsion system whose maximum speed on a paved level surface is 12.5 miles per hour or less. Electronic assistive mobility devices shall include devices such as the Segway&reg;, but shall exclude wheelchairs. 
(2)  ANSI Level 2 vest shall mean any class of safety vest meeting the requirements and/or standards of the American National Standards Institute for Performance Class 2 vests, which vest is properly labeled as meeting the standards. 
(b)  Operation. 
(1)  Every operator of an Electronic Assistive Mobility Device within the limits of the City of New London under the age of sixteen (16) shall wear a safety helmet. 
(2)  Pedestrians shall have the right-of-way on all sidewalks and in all crosswalks located within the limits of the City of New London, and any person operating an electronic assistive mobility device shall yield to all pedestrians in all traffic situations. 
(3)  Any person operating an electronic assistive mobility device shall ride at a speed no greater than an ordinary walking speed when operating on a sidewalk within the limits of the City of New London, or while entering or exiting a sidewalk. 
(4)  No person shall operate, park, idle, or stand an electronic assistive mobility device upon any sidewalk, street or right-of-way, or any public property located within the limits of the City of New London in such a manner that endangers, or would potentially endanger, the health or safety of any person, or cause damage to any personal or real property. 
(5)  No person shall operate, park, idle, or stand an electronic assistive mobility device upon any sidewalk, street or right-of-way, or any public property located within the limits of the City of New London in such a manner that obstructs vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
(6)  No person shall operate an electronic assistive mobility device after sunset and before sunrise without utilizing headlights and taillights so that said electronic assistive mobility device is properly lit and visible to pedestrians and vehicles. 
(c)  Commercial tours. The City of New London, acting through its chief of police or the chief's authorized designee, may grant a license to any person or entity to offer group tours within the limits of the City of New London utilizing electronic assistive mobility devices, subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Any person or entity offering commercial tours shall be required to have a training session on the use and operation of electronic assistive mobility devices for all tour participants prior to any tour being conducted to ensure that all tour participants can safely use and operate said device. 
(2)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (b)(1) of this section, all persons participating in a commercial tour shall wear a safety helmet. 
(3)  The minimum age of any participant of a commercial tour shall be twelve (12) years old. 
(4)  Reserved. 
(5)  All commercial tours must be guided by a representative or employee of the person or entity receiving the license. Tour group sizes shall have at least one tour guide for every six (6) participants. 
(6)  No person or entity offering commercial tours shall be permitted to conduct multiple tours in such a manner that results in more than one tour group being at the same location on a tour route at the same time. 
(7)  All participants of a commercial tour, including the guide, must wear an ANSI Level 2 vest at all times while on the tour. 
(8)  All participants of a commercial tour shall sign and execute a liability waiver and hold harmless agreement in favor of the city, which waiver and agreement shall have been prepared and approved by the city. 
(9)  Any person or entity wishing to operate commercial tours shall provide the city with proof of insurance for said business at minimum amounts acceptable to the city in its sole discretion, and said insurance policy shall name the City of New London as an additional insured. 
(10)  A non-refundable application fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid at the time an application is submitted to the city. 
(11)  Licenses granted pursuant to this section shall be valid for three (3) years from the date they are granted, provided however, that the city shall have the authority to terminate any license early in the event that a licensee violates any provision of this ordinance. 
(12)  In addition to any early license termination provided under section 18-20, any person who violates any provision of this section shall receive a citation and be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 01-21-14-4, § 2, 1-21-14; Ord. No. 04-04-16-1, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 18-21. - Tobacco-free community recreation and entrances and exits of city buildings. 
(a)  Findings and purpose. 
(1)  The city council endorses the following: 
a.  The mission of the City of New London (hereinafter "city") is to provide recreational and leisure opportunities that enhance the quality of life for its citizens and provide safe environments, the city has an obligation to prohibit those activities which it deems contrary to this mission. 
b.  The city cares deeply about promoting the good health and quality of life for its citizens and visitors. 
c.  Tobacco use is the single most preventable cause of death and disease in the United States. 
d.  Secondhand smoke contains many harmful chemicals and cancer-causing agents and is a serious health risk to humans, especially to infants, children and pregnant women; and increases a nonsmoker's risk for asthma, heart disease, and lung cancer. 
e.  Tobacco use in and around city facilities creates the contradictory message of young people and adults being encouraged to engage in healthy activities and lifestyles, while at the same time being exposed to adults and older youth using tobacco products which cause adverse health effects as the result of exposure to secondhand smoke. 
f.  The city hosts many recreational programs on fields and other facilities owned by the city. 
g.  Tobacco use and exposure to secondhand smoke are clearly contrary to enhancing the quality of life and providing safe environments. 
(2)  Based on the endorsements listed in subsection (a)(1) above, the purpose of this section is to provide for the health of and protect the safety of the inhabitants of the city by regulating, pursuant to section 7-148(c)(7)(H)(xvi) of the Connecticut General Statutes, activities deemed to be deleterious to public health on property owned by the city. This section will enhance the enjoyment of all persons using said property. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings indicated: 
    Recreational property means property owned by the city and which is under the supervision and control of the recreational department and used in connection with recreational programs, including athletic facilities, parks, playgrounds, beaches, trails and other areas where people may assemble for recreational purposes. Recreational property shall not include school grounds. Recreational properties at the time of the adoption of this section are: Bartlett Playfield, Bates Woods Park, Blackhall/Garfield Tot Lot, Calkins Field, Green Harbor Park, Mahan Parklet, McDonald Park, Mercer Park, Olde Town Mill, Richard Martin Center, Toby May Playfield, Veteran's Field, Williams Memorial Park, Williams Park, and Winthrop Cove Park. 
    School grounds means a parcel of land or portion thereof used for school purposes and operated by the City of New London Board of Education. 
    Smoke or smoking means the lighting or carrying of a lighted cigarette, cigar, pipe, or similar device. 
(c)  Violation. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to smoke on or within any recreational property, except within designated smoking areas. 
(d)  Penalties for offenses. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subjected to a warning, and/or a forty-nine dollar ($49.00) fine for each separate offense or violation. Any and all remedies, which the city has in enforcing this section, at law or in equity, shall be cumulative and two (2) or more or all of such remedies may be exercised at the same time. 
(e)  Recreation department. The city shall post a sign or signs on a recreational property stating such recreational property is a "Tobacco-Free Zone" to indicate that said recreational property is subject to this section. Said sign or signs shall identify this section by number and shall state the penalty amount for violating this section. 
(Ord. No. 09-04-12-7, §§ 1-5) 
Secs. 18-22-18-27. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LAY-OUT OF STREETS, WAYS 

Sec. 18-28. - Maps of city required. 
    The planning board shall cause to be made a map or maps of the entire city showing all the streets, alleys, ways, walks and parks of said city and building lines established, and showing the location proposed by said board for new streets, avenues, highways, boulevards, walks and park ways, and new building lines to be established and the grades of all highways, streets, avenues, boulevards, walks and park ways. Such map shall be submitted to the city engineer for his approval, and if approved by him shall be submitted to the council for its approval, and if so approved by the council, shall be lodged with the city clerk and shall within the appropriation made for that purpose by the council be public maps. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 12) 
Sec. 18-29. - Approval required. 
    No street, alley, way or walk for public use shall be laid out, constructed or opened for travel or use, except by and with the express consent of the council of the City of New London; nor unless the grade, lay-out, location and width of the same have been approved by vote of the council of the city. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 1) 
Sec. 18-30. - Width of streets, curbing, grading. 
    No street for public use shall be laid out, constructed or opened for travel, unless the same be at least fifty (50) feet in width and curbs have been laid and said street graded and otherwise constructed to comply with the ordinances of the city and the requirements of the council. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 2; Ord. of 1-3-61) 
Sec. 18-31. - Arrangement of streets in new developments. 
    The arrangements of streets in every new development of land shown on the plat or plan referred to in this article shall make provision for the direct continuation of the principal existing streets in the neighborhood, as may be required by the council, or the proper projection of such streets where the adjoining property is not subdivided, insofar as may be necessary for public requirements to be determined by the council. In general such streets shown on said plat shall be of a width at least as great as the existing streets. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 3) 
Sec. 18-32. - Public mains, pipes, other utilities. 
    No public water mains or pipes, sewer pipes or other public utilities shall be laid in any street opened or constructed in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 4) 
Sec. 18-33. - Minimum lot size. 
    No house lot shall be laid out on any street unless such house lot be at least fifty (50) feet in width and at least one hundred (100) feet in depth, except by vote of the council after approval by the planning board and upon its finding that the property cannot be otherwise reasonably laid out or platted. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 5) 
Sec. 18-34. - Width of sidewalks. 
    All sidewalks on streets hereafter laid out, opened and constructed shall be not less than eight (8) feet in width. The paved portion of the sidewalk on any such street shall be of a uniform width and location to be determined by the planning board and approved by the council. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 6) 
Sec. 18-35. - Prerequisites to dedication of public streets, ways. 
    Whenever the owner of land desires to subdivide land into building lots or to dedicate and convey to the city any streets, alleys, ways, walks, parks or other lands for public use, he shall cause such land to be accurately surveyed and platted and laid out into lots and projected streets, ways, alleys, walks, parks or other lands for public use, as the case may be, by a surveyor, and submit such plat to the planning board and city engineer for approval. Such plat shall contain a profile of all projected streets, showing grade of the curbline on each side of such projected streets and shall bear the certificate of such surveyor that such plat is correct. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 7) 
Sec. 18-36. - Plats of land. 
    All plats of land within the corporate limits of the city platted by any person shall be on good quality of white drawing paper or upon white drawing paper mounted on muslin, shall be thirty (30) inches long by twenty-five (25) inches wide, shall be drawn to a scale of fifty (50) feet to the inch, and shall be laid out on said plan so that the top of the map or plan so drawn shall represent the north. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 8) 
Charter reference- Platting, subpart A, §§ 93-95. 
Sec. 18-37. - Prerequisites to approval of plats. 
    No plat shall be approved by the city engineer unless the same is in accordance with the foregoing rules and with the provisions of this article nor until the lay-out of the streets, alleys, ways, walks, parks and lots shown on said plan have been approved by the council, nor until the city engineer shall have endorsed his written approval on said plan; nor until proper deeds of conveyance fully executed, conveying title, to said streets, alleys, ways, walks, parks and other land for public use shall have been delivered to the city by the person or persons platting said land, or in any way interested therein, and approved by the council and the director of law. Said deed shall be accompanied by a waiver of all claims for damages occasioned by the establishment of grades as approved and the present or future alteration of the surface of any portion of streets, alleys, ways and walks, conveyed to conform to the grade so established. The fee for filing such map or plat shall be paid by the person platting such land. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 9) 
Sec. 18-38. - Streets, ways in violation of article. 
    No street or way laid out or opened except in compliance with the provisions of this article shall become a public highway, nor shall any improvement or repairs be made thereon by said city; and in case any way is opened for the public use in violation of this article, it shall be the duty of the chief executive officer to post a notice on or near to the same stating that it is not a public highways, and to report the name of the person so offending to the prosecuting attorney to be prosecuted. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 10) 
Sec. 18-39. - Laying curbing in public highway. 
(a)  No person shall lay any curbing in any public highway until first obtaining a permit from the city engineer. 
(b)  Curbing used in connection with any sidewalk in any public highway of the city and in any street laid out and opened for travel in accordance with this article shall be of granite. 
(c)  Curb used in laying curbing shall conform to the following specifications: 
Width not less than four (4) inches; height not less than eighteen (18) inches. The curb shall have a sawed top and split face. 
Sections of curved curb when used shall be of the same dimensions as straight curb. The length of curved sections shall be subject to approval of the city engineer. 
(Ord. of 12-18-33, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 12-29-60; Ord. of 4-15-74, § 1; Ord. of 12-2-75, § 1) 
Sec. 18-40. - Violations and penalties. 
    Every person who shall open any way for public use in violation of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) payable to the treasurer of the City of New London. Every person who shall keep open any such way for public use after the first conviction therefor, shall be guilty of a like misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each day of twenty-four (24) hours in which such way shall be so kept opened after each conviction therefor. 
(Ord. of 2-19-23, § 11) 
Secs. 18-41-18-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-15-15-2, § 1, adopted Oct. 5, 2015, amended Art. III in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Art. III, §§ 18-52-18-63, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. of Dec. 1, 1950, § 3; Ord. of Dec. 1, 1952, § 1; Ord. of Dec. 29, 1960; Ord. of April 15, 1974, § 1; Ord. of July 19, 1982, § 1; Ord. of Nov. 4, 1985, § 1; Ord. of April 28, 1986, §§ 1-3; and Ord. of Aug. 6, 1990, § 1. 

Sec. 18-52. - General provisions. 
    This article shall govern all excavation and encroachments within the right-of-way of any public street, roadway, sewer or drainage right-of-way of the City of New London. 
    The director of public works may, from time to time, adopt such reasonable general rules, regulations, and specifications for such excavation, digging, or encroachments, and may reasonably rule, regulate, or specify any said particulars with respect to any particular excavation, digging, or encroachments as aforesaid. 
(Ord. No. 06-15-15-2, § 1) 
Sec. 18-53. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    Contractor means an individual, partnership or corporation approved by the city to excavate or encroach within the city roadway or street. 
    Roadway means a street, public way or public right-of-way maintained by the city, including the entire width between the street lines or right-of-way lines. 
    Inspector means the person duly authorized by the director of public works who shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of these regulations. 
    City means the City of New London, Connecticut, or any board, commission, officer or agent duly authorized to act for it. 
(Ord. No. 06-15-15-2, § 1) 
Sec. 18-54. - Permit required; application. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation shall make any excavation in or tunnel under any street, roadway, alley, park or other public place within the limits of the City of New London, or use any portion of any such street, roadway, alley, park, or other public place for the purpose of depositing or keeping any material to be used in the construction or repair of any building or other work, or place or suspend on or over any such street, roadway, alley, park or other public place any ladder, barricade, scaffolding, staging or any other material, equipment or apparatus used in the construction, alteration, repair of any building or other work or blockade or obstruct any such street, roadway, alley, park or other public place unless a permit shall have been granted in accordance with the terms of this article and such permit is visibly displayed at the site of said construction, repair, or other work. 
(b)  Application for permit. 
(1)  All applications for permits for work governed by these rules and regulations shall be directed to the public works department for approval. 
(2)  All applications for permits shall be made on a form prescribed by the director of public works or their appointed representative and shall contain all information necessary to evaluate the application for compliance with these regulations. The director of public works or their appointed representative shall make the determination as to what information is required. 
(3)  Application fee. For area requirements of fifty (50) square feet and less, the permit fee will be fifty dollars ($50.00). For area requirements greater than that amount, the permit fee will be calculated as the product of the rate of one dollar ($1.00) per square foot and the area requirement in square feet. 
(c)  Work performed under contract for the City of New London shall be subject to all requirements of these regulations except that the application fee and the cash deposit/bond may be waived by the director of public works. 
(d)  The provisions contained in subsection (a) of this section prohibiting the opening or cut of any pavement or the making of any excavation without first obtaining a permit for such work, shall not apply to emergency work performed by a public utility for the restoration of service due to the breakage or failure of water lines, sewers, electric lines or communication facilities, but the emergency openings shall be reported to the City of New London Police Department and the department of public works immediately. A permit for the work shall be obtained on the next business day. 
(Ord. No. 06-15-15-2, § 1) 
Sec. 18-55. - Inspections. 
(a)  The director of public works, inspector, or their agent(s) are empowered to inspect, or cause to have inspected, at any time, any or all work being performed under a permit issued under this article. 
(b)  If the director of public works, inspector, or their agent(s) believes that the work being performed does not meet the specifications and conditions approved or required by these articles, the permit, or approved work zone traffic and/or pedestrian control plans, he/she shall immediately notify the permittee. Upon receiving such notice, the permittee shall immediately commence work to correct such condition, unless the director of public works or their appointed representative provides for a longer period of time. If the permittee cannot immediately address safety requirements called for in the work zone traffic and/or pedestrian control plan, the work zone will be closed by the director of public works or their appointed representative until such time as safety requirements can be met. Penalties for violations of this article III may be assessed in accordance with section 18-60. 
(c)  In addition to any license or permit fees that may be required by the ordinances of the City of New London or by the rules and regulations of any department hereof, any person, firm or corporation, or combination thereof, who shall perform any work on any Saturday, Sunday, legal holiday, or any other day when city departments are not working or who shall perform any work on any day at such times as necessitate the employment of city personnel beyond eight (8) hours in any day or forty (40) hours in any week, shall pay to the City of New London or the proper department thereof any extra costs incurred by the city or any department of the city for inspection, supervision, or employment of city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 06-15-15-2, § 1) 
Sec. 18-56. - Bonding and insurance. 
(a)  Before a permit is granted, the applicant will be required to provide the public works department with a permit bond. This is required to ensure the faithful performance of the work contemplated. The bond shall be issued by an approved surety company licensed in the state, a passbook in the name of the City of New London or a letter of credit issued with the City of New London as beneficiary. It shall be for a minimum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), or an amount equal to the estimated cost of restoring the ground, reconstructing the sidewalk, resetting the curb, and laying of the pavement; if any, and the compliance with the provisions of this article as hereinafter set forth, said cost to be estimated by the contractor, and approved by the director of public works or their appointed representative, to ensure the proper restoration of the ground, reconstructing the sidewalk, resetting the curb, and laying of the pavement, if any, and the compliance with the provisions of this article requiring the control of dust, mud, and erosion, and the protection of the public by barricades, lights, temporary ramps, railings, covers, roadways, walks and approaches as required by the city. 
(b)  The bond shall be kept in force for the duration of the work, and in the case of excavations for a period of one year after final inspection of the work. In lieu of a separate deposit for each permit, the applicant may make an annual cash deposit in an amount four (4) times the amount required for the separate deposit herein required, which shall cover all permits issued to such applicant during a period of one year following the making of such deposit. All bonds shall continue in force until one year after final acceptance of satisfactory completion of work. 
(c)  The contractor shall produce evidence satisfactory to the city of insurance as will protect him/her from claims set forth below which may arise out of or result from the contractor's execution of the work, whether such execution be by himself/herself or by a subcontractor or by anyone directly employed by any of them, or by anyone for whose acts any of them may be liable. 
(1)  Claims under workmen's compensation, disability benefit and other similar employee benefit acts. 
(2)  Claims for damage because of bodily injury, sickness, disease or death of any person other than his/her employee. 
(3)  Claims for damages because of injury to or destruction of tangible property, including loss of use resulting therefrom. 
(d)  Certificates of insurance acceptable to the city shall be filed with the public works department prior to the issuance of a permit for the work. These certificates shall contain a provision that coverages afforded under the policies shall not be cancelled unless thirty (30) days' prior written notice has been given to the public works department. 
(e)  The contractor shall procure and maintain, at their own expense, liability insurance as hereinafter specified: 
Bodily injury liability insurance, including wrongful death, and property damage insurance in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each occurrence, two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate; products or completed operations insurance in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each occurrence, two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate; professional liability insurance, including errors and omissions, in the minimum amount of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) each occurrence; Special risk insurance covering underground explosion and collapse hazard in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00); automobile liability insurance in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit for each accident. 
(f)  The contractor shall procure and maintain, at their own expense, during the permit time, in accordance with the laws of the State of Connecticut, workers' compensation insurance, including occupational disease provision, for their employees at the site of the project, and in case any work is sublet, the contractor shall require such subcontractor similarly to provide workmen's compensation insurance, including occupational disease provision for all the latter's employees, unless such employees are covered by the protection afforded by the contractor. In case any class of employees engaged in hazardous work is not protected under workmen's compensation statutes, the contractor shall provide and shall cause each subcontractor to provide adequate and suitable insurance for the protection of his/her employees not otherwise protected. 
(g)  The contractor shall provide the city with a certificate of insurance designating the city public works department, and the City of New London and its agents as additional insured. 
(h)  The contractor will indemnify and hold harmless the city, its public works department, and its agents and employees from and against all claims, damages, losses, and expenses, including attorney's fees, arising out of or resulting from the performance of work pursuant to or within the scope of this article, provided that any such claims, damage, loss or expense attributable to bodily injury, sickness, disease or death or injury to or destruction of tangible property, including the loss of use resulting therefrom, is caused in whole or in part by any negligent or willful act or omission of the contractor, any subcontractor or anyone for whose acts any of them may be liable. Additional policies of owner's protective liability and builder's risk coverage on larger projects may also be required in addition to the above hold-harmless clause at the discretion of the director of public works or their appointed representative, the limits of such insurance to be determined by the director of public works or their appointed representative. 
(i)  In any and all claims against the City of New London, its engineering department, the director of public works or any of their agents or employees, by any employee of the contractor, any subcontractor, anyone directly or indirectly employed by any of them, or anyone for whose acts any of them may be liable, the indemnification obligation shall not be limited in any way by any limitation on the amount or type of damages, compensation, or benefits payable by or for the contractor or any subcontractor under workmen's compensation acts, disability benefit acts, or other employee benefits acts. 
(Ord. No. 06-15-15-2, § 1) 
Sec. 18-57. - Performance standards. 
(a)  The contractor shall give written notice to the director of public works or inspector of their intent to begin work at least two (2) business days prior to commencement of work. 
(b)  The contractor shall comply with all requirements of the "Call Before You Dig" regulations of the State of Connecticut. 
(c)  Excavations shall be made in open cut. Requests for tunneling require the public works director's special permission and under such additional conditions as he/she may impose. All excavated material shall be compactly piled and shall not interfere with public travel to any greater extent than necessary. 
(d)  Trench box and/or sheeting shall be utilized as required by Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulations to maintain safe working conditions in and around the area of the excavation and additionally as directed by the director of public works or their appointed representative to protect the roadway or adjacent properties.
